head.label.name: Appendix
head.headtext: Remedies Table—Misuse of Confidential Information

para.paratext: Selected cases have been chosen for inclusion in the remedies table. The remedies table has been organized under the following remedies:

head.headtext: GasTOPS Ltd. v. Forsyth, 2012 CarswellOnt 2539, 2012 ONCA 134, 2012 C.L.L.C. 021, 2012 C.L.L.C. 210-021, 288 O.A.C. 201, 99 C.C.E.L. (3d) 62, 26 D.E.L.D. 112 (Ont. C.A.)

para.paratext: Permanent injunction refused.
Corporate defendant to disgorge profits from military contracts in its first ten years of operation.
Damages awarded against the personal appellants equivalent to the profits earned by MxI from military contracts in its first ten years of operation.
All appellants ordered to pay this amount jointly and severally quantified at $12,306,495.00.

The trial judge found the personal appellants liable to the respondent for breach of fiduciary duty, breach of confidence and breach of their contract of employment. He found the corporate appellant liable for breach of confidence.

headtext.bold: Reasons Given by Court for Award:

para.paratext: The respondent cross-appealed from the dismissal by the trial judge of its request for a permanent injunction enjoining the appellants from using the misappropriated confidential information in any way. The trial judge declined to grant permanent injunctive relief on two bases. First, he held that a permanent injunction was inappropriate given the length of time that had passed between October 1996, when the corporate appellant began and the trial judgment in September 2009. Second, he found that the profits he ordered to be disgorged and the damages he ordered together provided the respondent with adequate redress. The trial judge's exercise of discretion in declining the equitable remedy of injunctive relief deserved deference.

head.headtext: Pat's Off-Road Transport v. Campbell (2010), 500 A.R. 377, 75 C.C.L.T. (3d) 300, 2010 CarswellAlta 1354, 191 A.C.W.S. (3d) 236, 2010 ABQB 443

para.paratext: Defendants jointly and severally liable to the plaintiff for damages of $80,000.00.

Order that the defendants not disclose to any third party by way of selling, leasing, renting, lending out, assigning any interest in or making available to third parties in any way the Camko Fluid Heating Ltd. heating unit or any material relating to the trade secrets of the plaintiff.

The plaintiff's principal over a 20-year period culminating in 2001, developed, by trial and error, and with the investment of a great deal of time and money, a truck mounted heating unit that was commercially advantageous over its competitors. The plaintiff claimed this technology was being kept secret from the public and its competition, and the technology that was developed for the truck mounted heating unit was a trade secret.

In April 2001 the plaintiff hired the defendant as a truck driver. He was trained to operate, maintain and clean the trucks with the mounted heating units. The defendant's employment was terminated by the plaintiff on July 3, 2003. Two years after he left the plaintiff's employment, the defendant developed and built a truck mounted heating unit that was virtually identical to that of the plaintiff.
The design over which the plaintiff claimed a trade secret consisted of a truck mounted, low maintenance fluid heater with an easy to maintain, removable burner.

headtext.bold: Reasons Given by Court for Award:

para.paratext: At minimum, the defendant used, as part of his recipe for making his own hot oiler unit, some private information from the plaintiff. The building of the unit was not a simple process. Notwithstanding all of his research on the internet, his reverse engineering and his consultation with suppliers and manufacturers, the defendant could not have built his unit without the information and knowledge gained from working with the plaintiff.

The defendant's knowledge of the process was the springboard which led to the construction of his unit. The reasonable man would see an “equitable obligation of confidence”. By taking the confidential information that he gained while employed at the plaintiff, the defendant clearly used that as a “springboard” to build his own unit. The defendant personally and through his company breached his duty of confidence to the plaintiff.
The court was not satisfied that the plaintiff had set out sufficient facts and thereby met the legal test to prove either breach of his fiduciary agreement or breach of his employment agreement.

There was no actual monetary loss suffered by the plaintiff. In fact, the plaintiff's sales increased considerably. There was no expert evidence led on the defendants' gain. The onus was on the plaintiff to establish its damages on the basis of credible evidence.

While the court could not accept the amount of damages put forward in argument by the plaintiff that did not mean the defendants should escape from any award of damages. Allowing the defendant and his company no penalty by way of damages even though his company made money by misappropriating his former employer's confidential information could not be countenanced. The defendant Camko Fluid Heating Ltd. earned a net income of $39,693.00 for the year end of May 31, 2007. No evidence was led from either side for the year end May 31, 2008, which was the last year the defendant operated the truck before selling the truck and shutting down operations. The court imputed income of the same amount as 2007 for the last year of operation of Camko Fluid Heating Ltd.

headtext.bold: Dell Chemical & Marketing Ltd. v. Aquasol International Inc.

head.headtext: Dell Chemical & Marketing Ltd. v. Aquasol International Inc. (2000), [2001] 4 W.W.R. 51, 85 Alta. L.R. (3d) 118, 273 A.R. 216, 2000 CarswellAlta 943, [2000] A.J. No. 1025, 2000 ABQB 587

para.paratext: The defendants consented to a declaration that the formula, blending procedure, all other rights and information in and concerning a product called Value 100 belongs to Dell Chemical Limited and a permanent injunction restraining the defendants from ever utilizing or disclosing any knowledge or information they have or may acquire concerning V100, its formula and blending procedure and any variations thereof, in any way whatsoever.

In addition, the plaintiffs established their entitlement to a finding that MV100/Aquasol and Hydrosol cannot be manufactured without first or concurrently manufacturing V100 or some variation thereof; a permanent injunction restraining the defendants from ever manufacturing, using, possessing, licensing or otherwise dealing with the products V100, MV100, Aquasol or Hydrosol unless such manufacturing, possession, licensing or other dealings are conducted with the express written permission of Dell Chemical Ltd. or with V100 produced by Dell Chemical or its licencee, successor or agent; a finding of contempt against Aquasol, Storey, Heinz and 623397 for deliberately breaching the injunctions set out in the May 20, 1994 Order of Agrios J. in action number 9303 23074 and the injunctions of Justices Wilson and O'Byrne dated June 11, 1998 and January 11, 1999; an order that Aquasol, Storey, Heinz and 623397 account for all proceeds from sale of MV100/Aquasol products or rights associated therewith since March 1996 with the exception of the period during which no injunction was in place; an order that the defendants immediately turn over all documents, formulas and records which could be used to manufacture, modify, reverse engineer or otherwise determine or disclose the ingredients and blending process for the Value 100 component of MV100, Aquasol, or any variation thereof; an order for an expedited trial to quantify the damages suffered by Dell Chemical for the use of its secret information to manufacture the Value 100 component of MV 100 and to determine the plaintiffs' rights to MV100.

Dell Chemical alleged that the defendants were illegally producing an environmentally friendly metal cleaning product, Hydrosol, made primarily with a Dell Chemical compound which the defendants were counterfeiting, Value 100 to which Dell Chemical had exclusive rights, thereby breaching the fiduciary, contractual and equitable obligations the defendants owed to Dell Chemical. In particular, Dell Chemical alleged that the defendants had breached an interim injunction which prevented them from manufacturing V100. The plaintiffs sought a permanent injunction preventing the defendants from producing Modified Value 100.

In earlier proceedings, the court forced the defendants to respect their obligations to the plaintiffs by issuing interim injunctions preventing the defendants from manufacturing Value 100 which was a necessary ingredient in the defendants' product. The evidence on the motion for summary judgment established that the defendants knew of the existence of the injunction and respected it until they ran out of Value 100 which they acquired legally; then they illegally used the plaintiff's formula and manufactured their own version of Value 100. The defendants cannot produce their current product without using Value 100 as a base.

headtext.bold: Reasons Given by Court for Award:

para.paratext: Where the plaintiffs have moved promptly to protect their secret chemical formula, the protection of confidential information takes precedence over the development of a new product. It would not be appropriate to order the defendants to pay the plaintiffs some reasonable sum for having used Value 100 as the “springboard” to Modified Value 100.

The parties agreed that Dell Chemical had exclusive rights to Value 100 including all licenses, patents, registrations, approvals, applications, engineering, customer lists, product names, product formulas and blending procedures. The formula for V100 was secret and was unpatented. The secret formula was blended for Dell by Raylo Chemicals.

It is not in every case of breach of confidentiality that an award of financial compensation will be granted instead of an injunction; on the contrary, the Supreme Court of Canada has narrowly circumscribed the circumstances in which such a drastic relief will be appropriate. This case did not come within the ambit of the Supreme Court of Canada's decision; the facts were very different from those in Cadbury Schweppes. There were small differences, including the fact that the breach here occurred recently—in 1996—rather than 16 years before as in the Cadbury Schweppes case. There were also major differences including the fact that there existed a fiduciary and contractual relationship among the parties and in the case before the Supreme Court of Canada there was no such relationship.
A permanent injunction continues to be available, in appropriate circumstances, to restrain the continued misuse or disclosure of confidential information.

Importantly, there was no delay by the plaintiffs in asserting their rights. On the contrary, the plaintiffs protected their rights as well as they could in 1993 when the arrangements between the parties broke down and before there was any misuse of V100. The plaintiffs continued to protect their interest in V100 in 1998 as soon as they became aware through an article in the financial press that the injunction which they had obtained to protect their secret formula may have been breached.

In addition, the ingredients used in the manufacture of the cleaning agents that were relatively unusual—being available only from a chemical supply business—as opposed to the common ingredients in Cadbury Schweppes, tomato juice and clam juice, which could be found on the shelves of any grocery store.
Significantly, there was no fiduciary obligation in that case whereas the classical fiduciary obligations in this case arose out of the relationship of principal and agent, and employer/employee.

headtext.bold: Cadbury Schweppes Inc. v. FBI Foods Ltd.

para.paratext: Permanent injunction vacated.
The Referee was directed to calculate the amount of compensation required to restore to the respondents what the respondents had lost as a result of the appellants' breach of confidence.
The period of calculation was to be restricted to the 12-month period commencing April 15, 1983.

Clamato juice is a confection of tomato juice and clam broth. By the early 1980s it had developed a market in Canada about ten times the size of its market in the United States, where it originated. The appellants and their predecessors manufactured Clamato juice under licence from the respondents. The respondents terminated the licence effective April 15, 1983. The courts below concluded that thereafter the appellants misused confidential information related to the Clamato recipe obtained during the licence period to continue to manufacture a rival tomato-based drink. Liability for breach of confidence was no longer contested.

Caesar Canning Ltd. of British Columbia, now bankrupt, obtained the territory consisting of Ontario and Western Canada for a series of 12-month periods, indefinitely renewable provided the licensee achieved a minimum volume of sales in each 12-month period. Caesar Canning easily exceeded the minimum volumes in each 12-month period. By the spring of 1979, Caesar Canning's territory was extended to include the rest of Canada. Local sources were obtained for the ingredients except the premixed portion of the dry seasonings, which was provided by the licensor. Neither Caesar Canning nor the other appellants ever did discover the precise formula of the respondents' secret “dry mix”. Nevertheless, to enable Caesar Canning to produce Clamato, Duffy-Mott communicated related information about its recipe and manufacturing procedures which the trial judge found to be confidential.

On May 11, 1981, Caesar Canning entered into a contract with the appellant FBI Foods Ltd. to manufacture Clamato and related products. To enable it to manufacture Clamato, FBI Foods was given information about the Clamato recipe and methods of manufacture which Duffy-Mott regarded as, and FBI Foods now acknowledges was, confidential.

In 1982, the respondent Cadbury Schweppes acquired the shares of Duffy-Mott and, in a switch of business strategy, decided that Duffy-Mott would take back the production and marketing of Clamato in Canada. It notified Caesar Canning on April 15, 1982 that the Licence Agreement (and consequently the sub-agreement with FBI Foods) would terminate in 12 months.

The Licence Agreement left Caesar Canning, and therefore FBI Foods, free to compete with the respondent in the juice market after termination. The Licence Agreement provided only that Caesar Canning would not, for a period of five years, manufacture or distribute any product “which includes among its ingredients clam juice and tomato juice”. Caesar Canning immediately began work to develop a competing product, utilizing the formula and process information about Clamato. Caesar Canning could have developed a product as much like Clamato as Caesar Cocktail without using the Clamato recipe by hiring the appropriate skills. It could have done so within the 12-month notice period at modest cost. Caesar Cocktail went on the market immediately after the licensing agreement terminated on April 15, 1983. Unbeknownst to the appellants, the respondents had surreptitiously discovered the exact formula of Caesar Cocktail at the end of March 1983 by slipping a technical expert onto the team for the final financial audit of Caesar Canning under the Licence Agreement. Despite this knowledge, the respondents did not take any action to enjoin the manufacture and sale of Caesar Cocktail, or otherwise protest. The respondents mistakenly believed (as did Caesar Canning) that the absence of clam broth in the reformulated recipe would be fatal to their claim. Caesar Canning ran into serious financial problems, ceased production on October 23, 1985, and shortly thereafter made an assignment in bankruptcy. The appellant FBI Foods purchased the assets of Caesar Canning, including the Caesar Cocktail brand. The sale of assets was completed on January 10, 1986. Since that time, FBI Brands has produced and sold Caesar Cocktail under various brand names throughout Canada.

headtext.bold: Reasons Given by Court for Award:

para.paratext: Injunctive relief, whether interim, interlocutory or permanent, is available in appropriate circumstances to restrain the apprehended or continued misuse or disclosure of confidential information. The problems here were, firstly, the delay of the respondents in asserting their rights coupled with the appellants' change of circumstances in the interim, relying at least in part on the respondents' inactivity; secondly, the trial judge's finding that the protected information was “nothing very special”; and thirdly, the conclusion of the trial judge that any loss could be adequately remedied by financial compensation.

The delay of the respondents, combined with the ongoing investment and commercial activity of the appellants based on Caesar Cocktail in the interim, argued powerfully against the grant of injunctive relief.

Eleven years had passed since Caesar Cocktail went into production, using “nothing very special” information that could promptly have been replaced by substitute technology accessible to anyone skilled in the art of juice formulation. At the date of trial, it would have been manifestly unfair to allow information of peripheral importance to control the grant of injunctive relief. The equities in favour of the respondents' claim for an injunction to put Caesar Cocktail off the market rightly yielded to the appellants' equities in continuing a business to whose success the confidential information had so minimally contributed.

The case essentially involved the settlement of financial accounts between business entities. The injunction, if granted, would have inflicted damage on the appellants disproportionate to the legitimate interest of the respondents. An injunction in the circumstances of the present case would inflict competitive damage on the appellants in 1999 far beyond what is necessary to “restore” the respondents to the competitive position they would have enjoyed “but for” the breach 16 years ago on April 15, 1983.
The trial judge was correct to refuse a permanent injunction, and the permanent injunction issued by the British Columbia Court of Appeal should be vacated.

headtext.bold: Apotex Fermentation Inc. v. Novopharm Ltd.

head.headtext: Apotex Fermentation Inc. v. Novopharm Ltd., 1998 CarswellMan 318, 162 D.L.R. (4th) 111, 80 C.P.R. (3d) 449, 129 Man. R. (2d) 161, 180 W.A.C. 161, [1998] 10 W.W.R. 455, 42 C.C.L.T. (2d) 133 (Man. C.A.)

para.paratext: Compensatory damages of $3,718,369.
The cross-appeal by Apotex with respect to the duration of the permanent injunction was allowed, and it was extended by an additional 19 months to July 31, 1999.

The trial judge found that Dahiya brought over to the appellant Novopharm technology that he had developed for the respondent Apotex for making Lovastatin, a “miracle” anti-cholesterol drug with an international market potential in the billions of dollars. Dahiya misappropriated Apotex's comprehensive process, thereby committing a breach of confidence and breach of fiduciary duty, and Novopharm was liable for Dahiya's conduct. A pre-trial injunction was continued to prevent Novopharm from performing any research or other activities relating to the production of Lovastatin until December 31, 1997.

As a result of its interest in Lovastatin, Apotex entered into a research agreement with ABI Biotechnology Inc. In June of 1988, Dahiya commenced employment with ABI as a scientist. The trial judge made a finding that the DTP was created by Dahiya during the term of the research agreement that he had signed and was the property of ABI/AFI. In the spring of 1991, ABI was in a difficult financial position, partly because of a dispute with Apotex over funding of the research agreement. When Dahiya left AFI he took with him documents belonging to AFI and relating to the technology which had been developed. ABI's strain selection and improvement work on A. terreus was a significant undertaking. There was no evidence that Dahiya subsequently developed a process independent of what he had learned at ABI.

The trial judge concluded that the fermentation conditions used at ABI were basic but remained a trade secret; the extraction process used at ABI was a trade secret; Novopharm was vicariously liable for the acts of Dahiya; Apotex was entitled to compensatory damages in the sum of $3,718,369 representing the total cost of ABI's Lovastatin project up to the time Dahiya left ABI; and the interlocutory injunction against Dahiya and Novopharm prohibiting Novopharm from performing any research or other activities relating to the production of Lovastatin (and certain other drugs) was made permanent until December 31, 1997.
The trial judge found Novopharm liable for breach of confidence and breach of trust of its employee Dahiya since he was acting within the scope of his employment.

headtext.bold: Reasons Given by Court for Award:

para.paratext: The facts demonstrated actual knowledge on the part of Novopharm and its senior officials of Dahiya's misconduct. Novopharm willfully abstained from making any inquiries whether the technology supplied by Dahiya was given in breach of confidence, a very important factor in the pharmaceutical industry. Far beyond this, Novopharm knew full well that Dahiya's remarkable progress could be due to one factor only, namely, his misuse of Apotex's confidential technology. There was active knowledge on the part of Novopharm through all of its senior officers.

The issue concerning the scope and duration of the injunction was dealt with in light of the finding made that Novopharm and senior officials of Novopharm were fully aware of and took advantage of Dahiya's breach of confidentiality to the distinct benefit of Novopharm. Given the nature of the defendants' wrongful conduct, including their willful evasion of the terms of the injunction and contemptuous conduct, the intensely competitive nature of the generic drug business, and the interrelated aspect of Apotex's confidential technology for the production of Lovastatin, it was entirely appropriate and necessary for the scope of the injunction to prohibit entirely Novopharm's activity with respect to Lovastatin.

By its cross-appeal Apotex asked that the injunction be extended by a further 32 months as follows: a) sixteen months to take account of the “holiday” unknown to the trial judge from February 1995 to June 1996 during which Novopharm continued to work on Lovastatin; b) for the three-month “relaxation period” permitted by the order dated March 22, 1994, until it was reversed on June 13, 1994; and c) lastly, a further 13 months, on the basis that the trial judge in awarding the initial injunction, ought to have extended it for a further 13 months so as to take complete account of the springboard advantage to Novopharm.

During the 16-month period when the interim and trial injunctions were in place, Novopharm deliberately flouted the injunction and continued research into the production of Lovastatin. Similarly, following the relaxation period permitted by the order of March 22, 1994, Novopharm failed to return all documentation and research results from that period. Novopharm cheated on the injunction for 19 months. The potential impact of such activity was especially significant to Apotex given the reality of the marketplace and the nature of the rivalry between the two corporate giants. It was fit and proper that the original period of the injunction be effectively restored by adding back the 19 months. The court was not persuaded that the further 13 months ought to be added to the injunction. This time period would have been within the contemplation of the trial judge when he ordered that the term of the injunction expire on December 31, 1997, and there was no error in the exercise of his discretion in this regard.

head.headtext: International Tools Ltd. v. Kollar, 1968 CarswellOnt 32, 38 Fox Pat. C. 66, [1968] 1 O.R. 669, 54 C.P.R. 171, 67 D.L.R. (2d) 386 (Ont. C.A.)

para.paratext: The plaintiff was entitled to an injunction restraining the defendants from using or disclosing the trade secret. The duration of the injunction should not continue beyond the time the plaintiff's trade secret remains a secret exclusively known to the plaintiff or to those to whom it has been voluntarily disclosed under conditions imposing an obligation of confidentiality upon them.
The judgment further directed payment by the defendants of the profits accruing from the use of the trade secrets and knowledge enjoined, after a determination of the amount thereof on a reference.

The plaintiff sought an injunction to restrain the defendants from putting to their own use trade secrets and knowledge relating to devices and processes employed in the manufacturing and bundling of reflex pins used in the manufacture of moulds for plastic reflectors; it also claimed damages.

The defendants N and G were, prior to December 31, 1963, employees of the plaintiff performing some part of the bundling procedure developed by the plaintiff. In October 1963, the defendants N and G entered into a partnership with the defendant K in a tool and die making business, and shortly after terminating their employment with the plaintiff, for which they gave spurious reasons, the three defendants began pin-making and bundling, largely by the secret processes of the plaintiff imported into their business from that of the plaintiff. The pin-making was a trade secret of the plaintiff and in its factory was carried on in an enclosed area, access to which was controlled very strictly. The defendants had been engaged in the bundling, concerning which, the same measures of secrecy and security were not maintained. In their capacity as workmen engaged in bundling the defendants N and G were accorded access to the pin-making area for the sole purpose of using an electrosonic cleaner located therein, this use being in connection with the process of bundling. Due to the lack of security and secrecy maintained in the process of bundling this process had ceased to be secret and confidential. The trial judge concluded that there was no ground for granting an injunction restraining the defendants from the use of the bundling process.

The trial judge made several findings of fact that were not interfered with by the Court of Appeal. Even if it be said that the size, shape and angles of the face of the pins were in the realm of knowledge which the defendants could have acquired without relying on the information and knowledge they acquired while in the plaintiff's employ, the process by which the plaintiff manufactured the reflex pin was a trade secret and included special practices which were not common in tool making and tools which were peculiar to the plaintiff's manufacturing. The defendants N and G knew that the process was confidential or secret, having been warned with respect to secrecy when they started to work on the bundling process. The defendants N and G during their employment did acquire knowledge of the trade secret of the plaintiff or a material part thereof. The defendants, in their work pertaining to bundling, were authorized to enter the locked area for the sole purpose of using a cleaning unit located therein, an exercise which, without some deliberate and unauthorized extension of their activities while in the room, would not have added to their store of knowledge relating to the secrets of pin-making. Any attempt to take or measure a pin or to acquire subjective knowledge as to the distinctive features of the die used in the formation of the hexagon strip for pins, or the manner in which the temperature was controlled, would have been an unauthorized attempt to gain information beyond that which would have accrued to them in the proper discharge of their duties in bundling. Had they looked at any drawings, blueprints or manufacturing instructions maintained in that controlled area for the guidance of those actually engaged in pin-making, what they would have added to their source of knowledge would not come within the category of skill or knowledge acquired in the proper discharge of their own duties. The legitimate presence of these defendants in the pin-making area would not have afforded ample opportunity to observe the process to the end that it could be reproduced. If the defendants came to that knowledge while legitimately in the pin-making area, it was by the surreptitious extension of their observance, beyond the scope of that which they were authorized to make; the knowledge they gained could not be said to be of a character “they could not help acquiring in the activities they were authorized to carry on”. This was not knowledge, skill and experience which as a result of this service would become their own. It was something beyond the scope of the employment which, in the matter of their subsequent conduct, would seem to have been acquired in order to equip themselves for the commercial production of the very article in one stage of the manufacture of which they were engaged, having been warned that the employer considered the whole process of manufacture to be secret. The defendants used substantially in their entirety the devices and processes used by the plaintiff in pin-making and bundling which the defendants copied from those of the plaintiff.

headtext.bold: Reasons Given by Court for Award:

para.paratext: N and G were guilty of improper use of the secret process of the plaintiff from knowledge gained from the plaintiff while employed by the plaintiff, and the plaintiff was entitled to relief against them.

The position of the defendant K differed from that of his co-defendants. He was never an employee of the plaintiff. He was joined in the action because of his association with the other defendants in the business which involved the unauthorized use of the plaintiff's trade secrets. It was undisputable that if the secrets became known to the defendant K they were communicated to him by either or both of his co-defendants. If it had been established that K was an innocent purchaser from his co-defendants for value without notice he might have been in a position where he could successfully resist the plaintiff's claim for an injunction, but he did not plead this ground of defence. The circumstances of the formation of the partnership between the defendants before the termination of the employment of the defendants N and G and the failure of the defendants to adduce any evidence to the effect that the relationship of the defendant K to his co-defendants was that of an innocent purchaser leads to no possible inference other than that the defendant K was well aware that his co-defendants would bring to their new association information about the plaintiff's trade secret extracted from the plaintiff, intended to be used and actually used in the defendants' process.

There is ample authority for restraining the ex-employees of the plaintiff from using the plaintiff's trade secrets. There is also authority for granting an injunction in proper cases, not only against the persons who have acquired the information directly from the plaintiff, but against others to whom they have communicated it. This was a proper case for restraining not only the employees but also the defendant K.
There was no reason for varying the provisions of the judgment relating to the determination and payment of profits.

head.headtext: Reliable Toy Co. v. Collins, 1950 CarswellOnt 96, 13 C.P.R. 53, 11 Fox Pat. C. 5, [1950] O.R. 360, [1950] 4 D.L.R. 499 (Ont. H.C.J.)

para.paratext: Damages of $2,500.

The plaintiffs were also entitled to an injunction restraining the defendant from further disclosure of the trade secrets with respect to the mask, but because of the rapid developments in the plastics fields it should be of limited duration.
This was a restraint of trade action in which the plaintiffs sought to restrain the defendant from disclosing certain of their trade secrets and for damages in respect of such disclosures.
The toy company employed the defendant as a chemist in its chemical laboratory from October 1, 1945, to September 20, 1948, when he was discharged. In the laboratory Collins was chief chemist.
The main disclosures were alleged to have been made to the plaintiffs' chief competitors, Dulev.

Up to the time of Collins' discharge there was not on the market in Canada a suitable lacquer for decorating styrene toys and in having such a lacquer the plaintiffs had an advantage over their competitors.

headtext.bold: Reasons Given by Court for Award:

para.paratext: The matters in respect of which the defendant made improper disclosure were secret and confidential information and the secrecy agreement extended to cover them, altogether apart from the obligations imposed upon a servant arising out of the confidential relationship with his master.

The result of the action was that the plaintiffs' claims failed in all respects save that related to the mask for decorating styrene toys. The plaintiffs suffered increased competition from its competitor, Dulev Plastics.

headtext.bold: XY, LLC v. Canadian Topsires Selection Inc.

head.headtext: XY, LLC v. Canadian Topsires Selection Inc., 2016 CarswellBC 1648, 2016 BCSC 1095

para.paratext: Order that all of the Confidential Information in the possession, power or control of the Enjoined Parties, and each of them, was impressed with a constructive trust for the benefit of XY

The major issue was the determination of damages with respect to: firstly, Tang, Zhang and Ai De, if liability was established; and, secondly, the other defendants against whom liability had already been established.
XY sought compensatory damages arising in the period after that considered by the Court in the Original Action after the end of 2008, on the basis of conspiracy and breach of confidence.

In the original action, the Court had granted judgment in favour of XY against JingJing, Zhu, and two of his employees, Tang and Zhou in the amount of $8.5 million on the basis of breach of contract, breach of confidence, conspiracy and deceit. The Court had also granted a permanent and mandatory injunction designed to protect XY's intellectual property and technology rights.

The Original Action concerned a licencing arrangement between XY and JingJing, one of Zhu's companies. XY granted a licence to JingJing in February 2004 which required JingJing to pay certain royalties to XY for its use of its technology relating to sexed semen and sexed embryos. In accordance with arrangements between the parties, JingJing originally acquired two SX cytometers for use in its semen-sorting business. XY terminated the Licence in November 2008 after disputes with JingJing arose. The trial judge in the original action found that XY's technology included certain confidential matters including a number of specified components of the SX cytometer, including its configuration; XY's protocols, and all other information and techniques imparted from XY during training, or otherwise, to any of the defendants in the Original Action or their employees relating to the use and operation of SX cytometers; and, XY's confidential patent information. Having found a breach of confidence by the widespread misuse of XY's technology and protocols, the trial judge in the original action issued a prohibitory injunction against the defendants, including Zhu and others, to prevent future use of the Confidential Information, either directly or indirectly. The trial judge also issued a mandatory injunction by which Zhu, Tang and others were to deliver all Confidential Information in their possession, power or control to XY.

The foundation of XY's present claims rested on its now-proven allegations that the defendants in the Original Action were in possession of information confidential to XY, and that they breached their duty in respect of that confidence. In particular, XY relied on the trial judge's findings concerning what he defined as XY's “Confidential Information” in the Trial Order. In the present action, XY alleged that Zhu and Tang continued to breach that duty of confidence to XY after the events that were addressed in the Original Action, and even during the trial itself and beyond. In addition, XY alleged that many other persons, being the other defendants in this action, assisted Zhu and Tang in breaching this duty, and they also benefitted or were unjustly enriched from their actions, although in differing degrees.

In the Original Action, the trial judge found that there had been “widespread misuse” of XY's Confidential Information. XY, and hence the Court, were not fully aware of the misuse that was occurring at the time of the Original Action. Indeed, to some degree, Zhu used the course of the Original Action to aid in the execution of his plan, assisted by the non-disclosure of his true activities. During the course of the Original Action, Zhu and the other defendants continued to assert that JingJing had been put out of business. XY did not know that the IND Group continued to use the three cytometers in their possession to sort semen during the course of the Original Action despite the termination of the Licence. Zhu considered the termination of the Licence, in November 2008, to be entirely irrelevant. It was business as usual for Zhu's semen-sorting operations after November 2008.

The evidence overwhelming supported the following findings of fact: a) Zhu, along with his key employees in the IND Group, used XY's Confidential Information to continue JingJing's operations past the date of termination of the Licence in late 2008 to create sexed semen. They did so until Zhu and the IND Group's key employees concocted a plan in 2010 that would place JingJing into bankruptcy with a view to disguising their ongoing operations and use of XY's Confidential Information; b) concurrent with placing JingJing into bankruptcy, the IND Group companies (IND, IEI, IDI, CTS and FBI), its employees and Zhu expressly planned to use XY's Confidential Information for their own purposes in the future. They succeeded in doing so by January 2012, which saw a resurrection of their operations in the Lower Mainland (through CTS), and either a continuation or commencement of their operations in China. These activities arose, in part, from their use of both “real” SX parts withheld from XY and the Trustee, and also the copying of manufactured SX parts (the BSO and tips) based on further misuse of XY's Confidential Information; and c) the plan was implemented by Zhu and his key IND Group employees, while knowing full well as to the confidential nature of XY's technology, and to exacerbate matters, while doing so in the face of litigation (i.e. the Original Action) commenced by XY to protect its interests in its technology.

headtext.bold: Reasons Given by Court for Award:

para.paratext: The constructive trust relief recognized the proprietary nature of XY's Confidential Information and was consistent with enforcing XY's rights until (and if) the defendants complied with the injunctive relief granted and the injunctive relief that remained in place per the Trial Order.

The fact that Zhu and the IND Group employees, both in Canada and China, took such pains to keep their plans secret, indicated that all these individuals were well-aware that their actions were breaches of confidence. In execution of this plan, Zhu and his employees made extensive efforts to hide their efforts. This included: a) lying to the Trustee and XY in various respects and, in particular, misleading XY and the Court about who was the true purchaser of the cytometers; b) making misrepresentations as to the Missing Parts and withholding the Missing Parts for their future (mis)use; c) using false names, in terms of sourcing materials and parts for the retrofitting process of the cytometers, all in aid of hiding the IND Group's efforts from XY; and d) attempting to remove the serial numbers from the SX parts and making counterfeit labels for the newly-copied parts and machines.

In addition to copying the SX cytometer parts, the defendants used the newly-retrofitted SX cytometers to make substantial quantities of sexed semen and sexed embryos, all in breach of confidence relating to XY's Confidential Information. All of the defendants received XY's Confidential Information knowing that it had been provided by XY to JingJing in confidence. Their surreptitious actions and misrepresentations taken in relation to the Court, the Trustee, and XY to avoid detection of their true activities were indicative of this knowledge. Equity will pursue the information into the hands of a third party who receives it knowing, or later learns, it was communicated in breach of confidence and impose its remedies. Zhu, both personally and through his various companies, being IND, IDI, IEI, FBI, CTS and Ai De, all participated in this breach of confidence.

Zhu, both personally and through his various companies by which he operated, received the Confidential Information and expressly and improperly misused it for his own purposes through the corporate actions of IND, IDI, IEI, FBI, CTS and Ai De. While the evidence was not sufficient to specify clearly the exact roles of some of the companies, Zhu was acting in his capacity as owner of these corporations in directing their improper activities through the means of the various IND Group employees. All of these corporations took some action in aid of Zhu's goals, and while in possession of knowledge that it was acting for the purpose of improperly using XY's Confidential Information. In addition, Zhu and Zhang were participating as “directors” or directing minds of various IND Group companies, and their actions amounted to a deliberate knowing pursuit or conduct to commit acts which could not be said to be in the best interests of the companies through whom they acted. As such, they were personally liable for those acts. FBI and CTS, were involved (and in CTS' case, created) for the express purpose of acting to improperly use and exploit XY's Confidential Information. There was no evidence that IND, IDI, IEI and Ai De were expressly created for the purpose of using XY's Confidential Information, but corporate actions taken by them were used to further the improper activities relating to XY's technology, as directed by their owner, Zhu. Accordingly, Zhu and the IND Group companies, being IND, IDI, IEI, FBI, CTS and Ai De, and Zhang, as a director of CTS, are all liable to XY for breach of confidence. The evidence, as to Tang's involvement in the plan to misuse XY's technology, was manifestly clear. Accordingly, Tang was liable to XY for breach of confidence. As with Tang, the involvement of Ai De and Zhang in the intentional misuse of XY's Confidential Information had been clearly proven. Zhang and Ai De both played a direct role in receiving and misusing XY's Confidential Information. Zhu, IND, IDI, IEI, FBI, CTS, Tang, Ai De and Zhang were all jointly liable for breach of confidence by reason of their conduct.

headtext.bold: Minera Aquiline Argentina SA v. IMA Exploration Inc.

head.headtext: Minera Aquiline Argentina SA v. IMA Exploration Inc., 2007 CarswellBC 1291, [2007] 10 W.W.R. 648, 68 B.C.L.R. (4th) 242, 246 B.C.A.C. 1, 32 B.L.R. (4th) 242, 43 C.P.C. (6th) 45, 2007 BCCA 319, leave to appeal to S.C.C. refused [2007] 3 S.C.R. x (note), 2007 CarswellBC 3065 (S.C.C.)

para.paratext: Constructive trust with an injunction in aid.
The order provided that:
Inversiones holds the mining claims in Argentina (the “Navidad Claims”), and any assets related thereto, pursuant to a constructive trust in favour of Minera Aquiline;
Inversiones transfer the Navidad Claims, and any assets related thereto, to Minera Aquiline or its nominee within 60 days of this Order;

the transfer of the Navidad Claims and any assets related thereto is subject to the payment to Inversiones of all reasonable amounts expended by Inversiones for the acquisition and development of the Navidad Claims to date.

IMA and Inversiones appealed from the order of a trial judge awarding Aquiline judgment against the appellants for unlawful use of confidential information. That information was referred to as the “BLEG A data” was used by the appellants to stake valuable silver mineral claims in Argentina.

Newmont arranged for various prospective purchasers, including IMA, to receive the brochure and, if desired, to participate in site visits after signing a standard form confidentiality agreement prepared by Newmont. IMA signed the confidentiality agreement. Thereafter, IMA sent three representatives to conduct a site visit. During the site visit, L also expressed interest in a satellite map on the wall of C's office which depicted the locations of the BLEG A samples. L asked if the data generated from these samples was available. Subsequently, the release of the data to L was authorized. On October 31, 2002, Aquiline offered to purchase the Calcatreu Project from Newmont for $2 million. At that time, Aquiline was unaware of the BLEG A data. On November 6, 2002, IMA advised Newmont that it would not be bidding on the project.

On November 27, 2002, L opened the BLEG A data. Shortly thereafter, he noticed the silver anomalies that had been identified as medium targets in a written report. L sought and received permission from IMA's management to stake the surrounding area, and Inversiones did so on December 6, 2002. On January 28, 2003, Aquiline completed the purchase of the Calcatreu Project through the purchase of Minera's shares. The BLEG A data was an asset of Minera and, as such, was included in the purchase. In May 2003, Aquiline examined the BLEG A data and discovered the silver anomalies which had drawn L's attention and which had led to the staking of the Navidad Project. Aquiline decided to stake the area but, when it moved to do so, it discovered that Inversiones had staked the area approximately six months earlier.

headtext.bold: Reasons Given by Court for Award:

para.paratext: The trial judge addressed the issue of whether the BLEG A data was covered by the Agreement. She concluded that, although the BLEG A data was not specifically mentioned in the Agreement, it was covered by the Agreement, and that the appellants had breached the Agreement by using that data to stake the Navidad Project. Although she was not required to do so, the trial judge then went on to consider whether the BLEG A data was also protected by confidentiality at common law. She concluded that the data met the criteria for confidentiality at common law. In coming to this conclusion, the trial judge repeated her finding that the information had been requested and provided solely within the context of the sale of the Calcatreu Project. In determining the question of remedy, the trial judge found that but for the prior staking of the Navidad Project by IMA, Aquiline would have staked the Navidad Project in or around May 2003 when it reviewed the data for the first time and realized its significance. The trial judge rejected damages as an appropriate remedy on the basis that there were too many unknowns related to the value of the claims and that an award of damages could operate unfairly to the detriment of one of the parties.

The trial judge did not make any palpable and overriding errors in her assessment of the evidence and did not err in finding that IMA had breached both the confidentiality agreement between the parties and its common law duty of confidentiality in using the BLEG A data to stake the Navidad Project and related claims. The trial judge did not err in concluding that a constructive trust with an injunction in aid were appropriate remedies.

Aquiline's argument that the court's in personam jurisdiction is well established in Canadian law and was properly exercised by the trial judge was a complete response to the appellants' position. The authorities cited by Aquiline for the in personam exception to the rule that the court will not make orders affecting property interests in foreign lands were precedents binding on the Court. The trial judge's order was enforceable in British Columbia against the appellants, who were British Columbia resident corporations. They would be required to carry out a transfer of the Navidad claims in Argentina under local law, but the courts of Argentina would not be involved. The appellants had not suggested there was any obstacle to carrying out the transfer.

The remedy should be the one that is most appropriate on the facts bearing in mind that in choosing the “appropriate relief from the full gamut of available remedies”, “[t]he objective in a breach of confidence case is to put the confider in as good as position as it would have been in but for the breach”. In LAC and Cadbury, the appropriate remedy was considered in the context of a breach of confidence. That was the appropriate consideration in this case, and the reasoning in LAC that led the Supreme Court to order a constructive trust of the mineral claims in favour of the plaintiff was apt here as well. The factual parallels between LAC and this case were apparent. The facts and reasoning in LAC were equally applicable. The appellants' argument that Aquiline suffered no detriment because it attached no specific value to the BLEG A data had no merit. Confining the choice of remedies to those available in a breach of contract claim was inconsistent with the law.

head.headtext: Visagie v. TVX Gold Inc., 2000 CarswellOnt 1888, 187 D.L.R. (4th) 193, 49 O.R. (3d) 198, 6 B.L.R. (3d) 1, 132 O.A.C. 231 (Ont. C.A.)

para.paratext: Respondents not entitled to a constructive trust over all of Kassandra but was entitled to a 12% carried interest and, having purported to exercise its option to purchase, a further 12% participating interest in Kassandra upon payment of the costs associated with that interest.

This was an appeal and cross-appeal from a judgment in an action for breach of a confidentiality agreement, breach of confidence and breach of fiduciary duty arising out of a joint venture between the parties for the acquisition and operation of certain gold mines in Greece.

In October 1993, the respondents, collectively referred to as the Alpha Group, approached the appellant TVX to propose that it become Alpha's joint venture partner for the purpose of acquiring certain mines in Greece known as the Kassandra mines.

Alpha insisted that TVX sign a confidentiality agreement, which it did on October 26, 1993. Alpha then gave TVX its information about Kassandra. After some further inquiries, TVX entered into a joint venture funding agreement with Alpha on November 25, 1993. Under the terms of the agreement, Alpha was to bring to the joint venture what was referred to as “Proprietary Information” and an “exclusive right to negotiate the acquisition of all of the mining assets” of Kassandra for a price of US$32,000,000. TVX was to bring the ability to fund the acquisition and the expertise to develop Kassandra. The agreement further provided that Alpha was to receive a 12% carried interest and the option to take up a further 12% participating interest in the operation once acquired by TVX.

Once the joint venture funding agreement was in place, TVX took control of the negotiations with the Greek government and attempted to make an acceptable bid for the mines. However, it became clear that the Greek government was not prepared to allow the mines to be sold privately but only through a public tender process. On July 22, 1994, TVX terminated its obligations under the joint venture funding agreement with Alpha, as it was entitled to do under its terms. TVX bid for the mines on its own in the tender process and was successful, ultimately paying U.S. $47 million.

In April 1995, after it was announced that TVX was the successful bidder, Alpha claimed its 12% carried interest and the right to purchase a further 12% participating interest. TVX denied that Alpha had any interest in the mines.

headtext.bold: Reasons Given by Court for Award:

para.paratext: The trial judge held that TVX was entitled to terminate the joint venture funding agreement according to its terms. The trial judge, however, held that, as a result of the relationship between the parties as joint venturers and the nature of their agreement, TVX owed a fiduciary duty to Alpha not to acquire Kassandra except for their joint benefit, which duty survived the termination of the joint venture funding agreement. Consequently, she held that TVX breached its fiduciary duty when it acquired Kassandra for its own account. The trial judge found that the information provided to TVX by Alpha was not readily available in the public domain. She held further that Alpha's information had the necessary quality of confidentiality to be worthy of protection in law. The trial judge found that TVX used this confidential information in acquiring Kassandra in breach of the terms of the confidentiality agreement and in breach of its common law duty of confidence. The trial judge rejected TVX's argument that Alpha had no standing to sue because the information belonged to Curragh and held that Alpha clearly had standing based on the agreements between the parties. The trial judge noted that no argument was advanced by TVX that it had entered into an illegal contract with Alpha with respect to someone else's information. She concluded that, without a complaint by Curragh and an action involving Curragh where the issues could be properly litigated, the court had insufficient facts upon which to conclude that the confidentiality agreement, to the extent that it concerned Curragh information, was an illegal contract.

The trial judge held that Alpha was not entitled to a constructive trust over all of Kassandra but was entitled to a 12% carried interest and, having purported to exercise its option to purchase, a further 12% participating interest in Kassandra upon payment of the costs associated with that interest.

The trial judge erred in finding that there was a fiduciary relationship between TVX and Alpha and that this fiduciary relationship survived the termination of the joint venture funding agreement. Nothing precluded TVX from acquiring Kassandra for its own account after terminating the joint venture funding agreement.

TVX remained bound, however, by the terms of the confidentiality agreement and by its common law duty of confidence not to use confidential information obtained from Alpha, except for the joint benefit of the parties. The trial judge's findings that Alpha provided TVX with information that had the necessary quality of confidentiality to be worthy of protection at law and that TVX used this information as a springboard in its acquisition of Kassandra are based on correct legal principles, are entirely reasonable and supported by the evidence. Consequently, the Court of Appeal did not interfere with the trial judge's conclusion that TVX breached the terms of the confidentiality agreement and its common law duty of confidence.
The remedy awarded by the trial judge was available not only for breach of fiduciary duty but also for breach of confidentiality and, in the circumstances of this case, was appropriate.

The trial judge made a number of findings of fact in support of her conclusion that Alpha brought a new and novel approach to the mine, that this information was not public, it was confidential and it was valuable. She also held that TVX first became interested in acquiring Kassandra because of the information provided to it by Alpha and that it used this information as a springboard in the ultimate acquisition. The appellant had not succeeded in attacking any of them. Further, no basis was provided to support its contention that a consultant's fee would be an appropriate remedy. The remedy was reasonable and entirely appropriate. It was the best remedy available to restore Alpha to the position in which it would have been if no wrong had been committed.

headtext.bold: Ontex Resources Ltd. v. Metalore Resources Ltd.

head.headtext: Ontex Resources Ltd. v. Metalore Resources Ltd., 1993 CarswellOnt 164, 12 B.L.R. (2d) 226, 13 O.R. (3d) 229, 103 D.L.R. (4th) 158, 63 O.A.C. 258, 40 A.C.W.S. (3d) 778 (Ont. C.A.)

para.paratext: The trial judgment was amended as follows:

Paragraphs 1, 2, 4, 5 and 6 were set aside. In place of paragraph 1 an order was granted that the May 16, 1983 agreement was set aside and that the 18 mining claims were subject to the terms of the July 1, 1981 agreement on the basis that the 1981 agreement should be treated as having been renewed as of July 1, 1991, the expenditures on the property while the 1983 agreement was in effect were to be treated as satisfying the obligations imposed on the defendant by the 1981 agreement, and the defendant should have the right to make further payments that may be due to the plaintiff under the agreement within six months.
The action, in so far as it claimed rescission of the July 1, 1981 agreement, a constructive trust respecting the 478 outlying claims, and punitive damages against C was dismissed.

This was an appeal from a judgment setting aside the 1981 agreement and the 1983 agreement between a predecessor of the plaintiff and the defendant with respect to some mining properties near Beardmore, Ontario. The result of these declarations was to return to the plaintiff 18 mining claims owned by its predecessor prior to the 1981 agreement free from any interest of the defendant and to return to the defendant 39 mining claims it owned prior to the 1983 agreement. Additionally, the plaintiff was required to repay to the defendant $40,000 paid by the defendant as part of the consideration for entering into the 1983 agreement. The judgment further provided that 478 mining claims staked by the defendant adjacent to the claims were to be held by the defendant in a constructive trust for the plaintiff. The judgment awarded the plaintiff punitive damages of $80,000 against the president of the defendant.

The defendant performed the 1981 contract with respect to its commitment to expend money on a drilling program. The issue with respect to the 1981 agreement related to its obligation to make the disclosure of information called for under the 1981 agreement.

The 1983 agreement provided that the plaintiff's predecessor assign to the defendant 100% of its interest in the leased property which covered the 18 claims in return for a 10% net profit interest quarterly on all profits the defendant derived from the “Property and the Staked Claims”. Entitlement to access and information was reduced.

V visited the property at Beardmore on behalf of the plaintiff in July of 1984. He was shown certain material and was told that the defendant had drilled in the area where the discovery was made. He was not told that there had been a discovery. He was told only that the result of the drilling was “encouraging”. He was still not shown the assay results for hole B31. He did not examine the core samples and appears to have been relatively passive in his approach to obtaining information. He appeared satisfied with the explanation provided by the defendant's principal C that he would provide information before the defendant's annual meeting in September. From February 1984 until March 1986, the defendant decided to keep its deep drilling results confidential. The purpose of its confidentiality was its desire to secure claims along the geological fault line where the discovery had been made. It was particularly anxious to acquire the Cherbourg property and, additionally, embarked on an extensive staking program of its own. The defendant acquired 478 claims along this geological fault between February of 1984, when C had the assay from hole B31, and March 15, 1986, when there was a public announcement of the discovery. These claims are the subject of the constructive trust in favour of the plaintiff awarded by the trial judge.

headtext.bold: Reasons Given by Court for Award:

para.paratext: The order for a constructive trust was not justified in this case. It was not the appropriate remedy, and since no other was pursued, this portion of the claim was dismissed.

The primary issues to be determined on this appeal were whether the trial judge erred in law, first, in rescinding the 1983 agreement and, second, in rescinding the 1981 agreement. The Court of Appeal agreed with the trial judge's conclusion that the 1983 agreement should be rescinded but did not agree that the 1981 agreement should also be rescinded.

Under the terms of the 1981 agreement, the defendant was granted “the exclusive right to acquire a leasehold interest” in the plaintiff's predecessor's leased mining property “for the purpose of conducting mining operations thereon”.

This agreement could not be interpreted as having created a relationship involving fiduciary rights and duties. Until the “joint venture” contemplated had come into existence, the parties could not be said to have agreed to be “co-venturers”, as the trial judge described them, in this mining exploration. At this stage, the defendant was obliged to make annual payments, incur exploration and development costs, and disclose information to the extent provided for in the agreement. The plaintiff's predecessor, while entitled to specified information, had no role in the management of the operation; no control over the manner in which the defendant chose to conduct the exploration; and bore no responsibility, financial or otherwise, for any aspect of the work. This agreement was “a lease-option agreement”.

Accepting that the failure to deliver the Winter Report constituted a breach of the 1981 agreement, the real issue was whether a failure of this nature in the context of this agreement amounted to a fundamental breach. The damage which the plaintiff suffered from the non-delivery was completely remedied by the rescinding of the 1983 agreement. To go further and also set aside the 1981 agreement would grant relief which was wholly disproportionate to the harm done by the non-disclosure.

Under the terms of the 1983 agreement, the plaintiff's predecessor assigned the whole of its interest in the 18 claims which comprised the leased property in return for 10% of the net profit derived both from the property and the 39 claims the defendant had staked adjacent to the property. This agreement superseded the 1981 agreement Under the agreement the plaintiff's predecessor was entitled to enter upon the property to examine the mining operations and, at its request, to be provided with the results of any diamond drilling, sampling and assaying, and to be permitted to examine relevant data, maps, reports and other records. The defendant was no longer required to provide the annual disclosure report previously mandated by the 1981 agreement.

The 1983 agreement rests for its validity on proper disclosure having been made under the 1981 agreement. Given the defendant's intentional failure to make proper disclosure, the 1983 agreement cannot stand. The significance of the Winter Report in assessing the property's mining potential was manifest.

The trial judge also found that, under the 1981 and 1983 agreements, the defendant had acquired valuable geological information which it used to the exclusion of the plaintiff and in breach of its obligation to make disclosure. He found that this information was confidential and its exclusion from the plaintiff amounted to a breach of confidence.

Applying the reasoning in LAC to the findings of the trial judge in this case, it was clear that the defendant breached the duty of confidence which it owed to the plaintiff. The facts were not the same as those in LAC in that the intended flow of confidential information was not from the owner of the mineral rights to the defendant but the reverse. However, the distinction is irrelevant since the defendant was able to acquire the confidential information only because the plaintiff had given it access to its property subject to the terms of the 1981 and 1983 agreements. The confidential information was to be shared under the two agreements but was not so shared. It was used exclusively by the defendant to advance its own interests. Therefore, the Court of Appeal did not interfere with the trial judge's finding that the conduct was a misuse of confidential information.

The trial judge made only a limited finding with regard to the issue of detriment, and even the limited finding that he did make did not reflect any analysis of the relevant evidence. The finding by the trial judge that the plaintiff would have shared in the staking was incapable in law of establishing that the appropriate remedy was the imposition of a constructive trust wherein the plaintiff would receive, unburdened by any costs, the exclusive benefit of three years of exploration by the defendant on these 478 claims. Moreover, the relevant evidence did not support the finding made. The complaint about being left out of a joint venture for further exploration was not developed at trial and the Court of Appeal was driven to the conclusion that a restitutionary remedy for the additional 478 claims was not seriously pursued. What little evidence there was might have been directed to a claim for damages though no such claim was advanced. However, the evidence did not conform with what was required by La Forest J. for establishing a constructive trust. The trial judge did not make the affirmative finding that, but for the actions of the defendant, the plaintiff would have acquired the claims in question. No evidence was led as to what the plaintiff's predecessor would have done with respect to staking if it had known of the Winter Report in the spring of 1982. Accordingly, the evidentiary basis for a restitutionary remedy of constructive trust of the 478 claims was restricted to the misuse of confidential information relating to the drill hole results from the summer of 1983 forward.

It was apparent that Ontex would have required public financing to do any exploration and this would have mandated public disclosure of the drill hole assays. It was conceded that a public announcement would have brought other players into the field. Such a public disclosure would have lost the advantages of the confidential information that both were to share privately. Accordingly, it is most unlikely that, but for the conduct of the defendant in withholding confidential information, the plaintiff would have staked any of the 478 claims for itself. The plaintiff never contemplated acquiring any adjoining claims. Its strongest claim was merely that it would have “shared” in the staking.

headtext.bold: International Corona Resources Ltd. v. LAC Minerals Ltd.

head.headtext: International Corona Resources Ltd. v. LAC Minerals Ltd., 1989 CarswellOnt 126, 44 B.L.R. 1, (sub nom. LAC Minerals Ltd. v. International Corona Resources Ltd.) 26 C.P.R. (3d) 97, 69 O.R. (2d) 287, 61 D.L.R. (4th) 14, 6 R.P.R. (2d) 1, [1989] 2 S.C.R. 574 (S.C.C.)

para.paratext: The Court ordered LAC to deliver up to Corona land (the Williams property) on which there was a gold mine, on being compensated for the value of improvements LAC has made to the property ($153,978,000) in developing the mine.
Corona was a junior mining company. LAC was a senior mining company which owned a number of operating mines.

This action arose out of negotiations between Corona and LAC relating to the Corona property, the Williams property and the Hughes property, all of which are located in the Hemlo area of northern Ontario.

In October 1980, Corona had retained Mr. David Bell, a geologist consultant to carry out an extensive exploration program on its property which involved extensive diamond drilling. Mr. Bell concluded that in all likelihood, the distribution of gold could be spread over quite a large area and there could be pools or puddles of ore, indicating to him that the exploration programme should be extended along the zone to adjoining properties. This increased the interest in surrounding properties and Bell, on behalf of Corona, requested Mr. Donald McKinnon, a prospector who was familiar with the properties, to attempt to acquire the Williams property. Representatives of LAC read about these results and arranged to visit the Corona property. This property visit took place on May 6, and Bell had arranged for Dadds to have core, assay results, sections, maps and a drill plan available at the core shack. The visitors were shown cores, sections, and logs with assay results added and a map showing the staking in the area. Bell indicated that the formation was continuing to the west on the Williams property and that Corona wanted to continue its exploration there. There were no discussions regarding confidentiality during the May 6 property visit. Following the site visit, Sheehan and Pegg returned quickly to LAC's exploration office in Toronto and instructed LAC personnel to gather information on the Hemlo area from the LAC library of files.

On June 15 a meeting was also arranged for June 30 at LAC's head office in Toronto, at which Bell was to make a presentation. Following the meeting, Peter Allen, the president of LAC, advised Bell to be aggressive in his pursuit of the Williams property and Bell responded that Corona had somebody pursuing this property on their behalf. Allen told Sheehan to get a proposal out to Corona and Sheehan indicated that he would have such a proposal out within 3 weeks. The trial Judge found that it was agreed that a proposal would be sent by LAC to Corona within 3 weeks, and that the purpose of the meeting was to discuss a possible deal between Corona and LAC in order to provide Corona with the financing needed to develop a mine. Meanwhile, on June 8, McKinnon had spoken to Mrs. Williams by telephone and made an oral offer for the Williams property, which was followed by a written offer prepared by solicitors. On July 3, after some searching, Sheehan located Mrs. Williams by telephone and made an oral offer to her. She asked for a written offer and by letter dated July 6, 1981, LAC's legal counsel put it in writing. On July 21, McKinnon again spoke to Mrs. Williams who told him that she had another offer and that he should contact her Toronto solicitor. On July 22, McKinnon told Bell of the other offer and it was agreed by Bell and Dragovan that Corona should make an offer to Williams directly. At this time, no one from Corona knew that the other offer was from LAC. On July 23, Corona's solicitor prepared an offer, which was delivered on July 27. Also on July 23, Mrs. Williams' Toronto solicitor disclosed LAC's name to Corona's solicitor. LAC's offer was accepted on July 28 and a formal agreement was signed on August 25, 1981.

Corona had conducted an extensive exploration program on its own property. The information which it obtained was pertinent in evaluating the Williams property. Its geologist, Bell, had developed a theory that the source of the zone of gold mineralization on Corona's property was volcanogenic. This meant that gold could be spread over a large area with “pools” of ore throughout. This led him to conclude that the exploration program should be extended to the neighbouring properties which included the Williams property. This information was developed from the results of the exploration program and the application of Bell's knowledge as a geologist. LAC got the benefit of this information. It had the advantage of several discussions with Bell who interpreted his findings and explained his volcanogenic theory. Bell allowed LAC's representatives to examine the drill cores and the individual assays. LAC's representatives were also advised that Corona was actively pursuing the Williams property. The trial Judge found as a result that the site visit and the information disclosed by Corona to Lac was of assistance to Lac not only in assessing the Corona property but also in assessing other property in the area and in making an offer to Mrs. Williams. This information was the springboard which led to the acquisition of the Williams property. Sheehan admitted that the offer to Mrs. Williams was based in part on information obtained from Corona. The degree of reliance on Bell's input is graphically illustrated by the fact that after LAC had optioned the Williams property, it located its three drill holes on the Williams property in the same area in which Bell would have located his next three holes, westerly from the Corona property.

The information obtained from Corona by LAC went beyond what had been imparted publicly in the George Cross Newsletters or the public investors' meeting. Furthermore, it put LAC in a preferred position vis-à-vis others with respect to knowledge of the desirability of acquiring the Williams property.

They were working toward a joint venture or other business arrangement which would involve participation by Corona. Acquisition by LAC of the Williams property to the exclusion of Corona was not an authorized use of the confidential information which it received from Corona and which was of assistance in enabling LAC to get the property for itself.

headtext.bold: Reasons Given by Court for Award:

para.paratext: Of the five members of the Court who heard the appeal, only two (La Forest and Wilson JJ.) held that Lac Minerals had breached a fiduciary duty to Corona. Applying fiduciary principles, and aiming at disgorgement, they held that a constructive trust should be impressed on the gold mine in favour of Corona.
La Forest J. considered that a constructive trust could be imposed “regardless of the basis of liability”
Justices McIntyre, Lamer and Sopinka concluded that the imposition of a fiduciary duty was inappropriate in light of the commercial nature of the relationship, but split on the appropriate remedy.

Justice Lamer J. agreed with Wilson and La Forest JJ. that a constructive trust ought to be imposed. The other judges considered that it was inappropriate to impose a constructive trust, on the gold mine and would have awarded financial compensation only.

The majority view on remedy (per Lamer, Wilson and La Forest JJ.) therefore imposed a constructive trust even though it was the majority view on liability (per McIntyre, Lamer and Sopinka JJ.) that the parties were not in a fiduciary relationship.

paratext.ital: La Forest J. (Wilson and Lamer JJ. concurring in part)

para.paratext: La Forest, J. agreed with Sopinka J. that LAC misused confidential information confided to it by Corona in breach of a duty of confidence.

There is no doubt that but for the actions of LAC in misusing confidential information and thereby acquiring the Williams property, that property would have been acquired by Corona. That finding is fundamental to the determination of the appropriate remedy. Both Courts below awarded the Williams property to Corona on payment to LAC of the value to Corona of the improvements LAC had made to the property. The trial Judge dealt only with the remedy available for a breach of a fiduciary duty, but the Court of Appeal would have awarded the same remedy on the claim for breach of confidence.
The constructive trust is one available remedy, and in this case it is the only appropriate remedy.

In breach of confidence cases, there is considerable flexibility in remedy. Injunctions preventing the continued use of the confidential information are commonly awarded. Obviously that remedy would be of no use in this case where the total benefit accrues to the defendant through a single misuse of information. An account of profits is also often available. Indeed in both Courts below an account of profits to the date of transfer of the mine was awarded.

Having specific regard to the uniqueness of the Williams property, to the fact that but for LAC's breaches of duty Corona would have acquired it, and recognizing the virtual impossibility of accurately valuing the property, it was appropriate to award Corona a constructive trust over that land.

Lamer J. (concurring in part) was in agreement with that the evidence did not establish the existence of a fiduciary relationship. He was in agreement with both Justices La Forest and Sopinka and concurred in their reasons that there was a breach of confidence on the part of LAC Minerals Ltd. As regards the appropriate remedy, the approach taken by La Forest J. in ordering a constructive trust was the proper one.

Wilson J. (concurring in part) agreed with Justice La Forest, as to the appropriate remedy. Since the result of LAC's breach of confidence or breach of fiduciary duty was its unjust enrichment through the acquisition of the Williams property at Corona's expense, the only sure way in which Corona can be fully compensated for the breach in this case is by the imposition of a constructive trust on LAC in favour of Corona with respect to the property. Full compensation may or may not be achieved through an award of common law damages depending upon the accuracy of valuation techniques. It can most surely be achieved in this case through the award of an in rem remedy. The remedy of constructive trust is available for breach of confidence as well as for breach of fiduciary duty. The distinction between the two causes of action as they arise on the facts of this case is a very fine one. Where the consequence of the breach of either duty is the acquisition by the wrongdoer of property which rightfully belongs to the plaintiff or, ought to belong to the plaintiff if no agreement is reached between the negotiating parties, then the in rem remedy is appropriate to either cause of action.

headtext.bold: Pre-Cam Exploration & Development Ltd. v. McTavish

head.headtext: Pre-Cam Exploration & Development Ltd. v. McTavish, 1966 CarswellSask 28, 56 W.W.R. 697, [1966] S.C.R. 551, 57 D.L.R. (2d) 557, 50 C.P.R. 299 (S.C.C.)

para.paratext: Constructive trust.

An action was brought to compel the defendant, who had been employed on the inspection of certain mining claims, to transfer other mining claims which he staked around the first group after he had severed his employment. The information which led him to stake these claims was acquired in the course of his employment. The trial judge held that the defendant held these claims as trustee and that he must transfer them to the owner of the other claims. The Court of Appeal held that the defendant was free to stake these claims for his own benefit.

headtext.bold: Reasons Given by Court for Award:

para.paratext: Without the information acquired during the course of his employment, the defendant would not have staked the adjoining claims. This was highly confidential information and the purpose for which it was being sought was obvious—the acquisition of other connected claims which would be of advantage to the existing claims. It was a term of his employment which the defendant understood that he could not use this information for his own advantage. The severance of his employment on December 27, was an empty formality which could not improve his position. The constructive trust is imposed in a case of this kind because of the mere use of confidential information for private advantage against the interest of the person who made the acquisition of the information possible.

head.headtext: GasTOPS Ltd. v. Forsyth, 2012 CarswellOnt 2539, 2012 ONCA 134, 2012 C.L.L.C. 021, 2012 C.L.L.C. 210-021, 288 O.A.C. 201, 99 C.C.E.L. (3d) 62, 26 D.E.L.D. 112 (Ont. C.A.)
