In effect, TDC's information educated the Project members in a highly complicated technology where otherwise its only apparent source of technical information was Dan MacDonald, who was not an expert in the field. Learning what the issues were and determining the ways to address those problems made that information a valuable asset. However, what ultimately ended up in the RFP was an identification of the issues and not a lot of the answers arrived at by TDC. However, the RFP designers were not experts in the industry and so the TDC information that the Project members sought and obtained provided a shortcut, which the defendant did not have the permission to take and did not pay for. The Province gained from the knowledge acquired by TDC's principals over an extended period of time. There is an important difference though between what the Rural Broadband Project team members knew of the TDC delivery system and Business Proposal, and what it misused. The defendant was only liable for that which it provably misused. There was no basis upon which to conclude that members of the Rural Broadband project passed on any TDC confidential information to Seaside or the other bidders in ways other than that set out in the pilot RFP. Once the pilot RFP was released the extent of the damage to TDC had crystallized. There was no basis upon which the defendant would have required TDC's further assistance, unless it was prepared to seek the undisclosed and more valuable TDC information held by Dennis Cockerill. It did not and so TDC could not be compensated for that which it did not provide. The value of the plaintiff's economic loss was to be measured by considering the value to the Province of retaining TDC to assist the Rural Broadband Project between the Project's inception in March 2006 and the release of the RFP in September 2006; and also as a product of the intrinsic value of the information that was lost by TDC and gained by the defendant. A way of looking at the value of the misused information is the cost that would be agreed to by a willing buyer and a willing seller where the product purchased was the provision of TDC's information and in person expertise, together with the right for the Project to use the information for the development of the Rural Broadband project and the construction of the pilot RFP. In giving up this information to the Province there would be a corresponding diminishment in the overall commercial value of the information provided by TDC, once published in the RFP. The value of the plaintiff's economic loss was $125,000.

The bankruptcy of TDC was not causally connected to the defendant's tortious conduct. The bankruptcy was an inevitable result of the Plaintiff's inability to find new capital or to develop an adequate revenue stream to maintain its operations. The market place was still open to TDC after the Province initiated the Rural Broadband project. Any ISP that was not selected in the tender process was free to compete to the limit of its financial and technological capabilities. TDC did not have the funding to continue.

The plaintiff claimed general damages in the amount of $300,000 for loss of goodwill and business reputation. There was no evidence to support the conclusion that the plaintiff suffered a loss of goodwill and business reputation that was caused by the defendant. No valuation of these assets had been tendered and having regard to the evidence it was unlikely that there was significant value in these accounts by the time the pilot RFP was made public in September 2006. By August 2006 TDC was unable to raise funding. The uptake of service was significantly less than what was anticipated and there was an interruption of service that month due to non-payment of bills. The evidence supported the conclusion that TDC's business reputation and technical reputation were already seriously damaged before the publication of the pilot RFP. The claim for general damages based upon the loss of goodwill and business reputation was dismissed.

headtext.ital: Reasons for Decision of Court of Appeal

para.paratext: On appeal, Justice Bourgeois dismissed the appellant's appeal of the trial judge's damage assessment. The trial judge's findings leading to the conclusion that the respondent did breach its duty of confidence were not challenged on appeal. The appellant submitted that the trial judge made several errors which led to an inordinately low award of compensatory damages. At the hearing, the appellant presented three inter-related arguments: based on his own factual finding that the confidential information disclosed was “something special”, the trial judge failed to apply the correct valuation analysis; related to the above, the trial judge misunderstood the purpose of the expert evidence presented by the appellant which formed the basis of its claim for compensatory damages and, as such, he improperly discounted it; the trial judge further failed to consider the damages arising from the respondent's second improper disclosure in the provincial RFP. The appellant asserted that these errors led the trial judge to an inordinately low award, and that he ought to have awarded compensatory damages as calculated by its expert as set out in her report. In the alternative, the appellant submitted that the trial judge failed to award damages based upon the “springboard” doctrine.

With respect to the appellant's first argument that the trial judge failed to apply a proper valuation analysis, the appellant grounded its argument in the judgment of Cadbury Schweppes Inc. v. FBI Foods Ltd., [1999] 1 S.C.R. 142. The appellant argued that Cadbury adopted the earlier approach of the English Court of Appeal in Seager v. Copydex Ltd. (No.2), [1969] 2 All E.R. 718, in which Lord Denning set out a method of damage assessment based upon the quality of the confidential information at the heart of the breach. The appellant submitted that the trial judge properly found the information used by the respondent was “something special”. However, having made that finding, it argued that the trial judge was then bound to assess damages on the basis of “the value as between a willing seller and a willing buyer”. The appellant submitted that the trial judge failed to undertake such an assessment, instead assessing damages as if the information were “nothing very special”, resulting in an improper award based upon a consultant fee.

In dismissing these submissions, Justice Bourgeois observed that the trial judge made several factual determinations that were particularly relevant to his assessment of economic loss, none of which were challenged on appeal, stating:
The respondent did not use or disclose “the most valuable part of the appellant's delivery system”;
Neither Seaside, the successful bidder on the Cumberland RFP, nor the other successful bidders on the Provincial RFP, utilized systems based upon the confidential information disclosed;

The appellant's factual assertion that “Absent the Province improperly using the confidential information regarding the Delivery System, TDC would have been the only provider with a technology that was proven to work in the topography of rural Nova Scotia” was rejected as an overstatement;
The appellant was the only company that had attempted to provide a fixed wireless delivery system in rural areas, but it had not shown that its system was financially viable;

The Cumberland RFP required, amongst other criteria, that a successful bidder have a viable business plan, which the appellant did not have. Justice Bourgeois observed that a review of Justice Binnie's reasons in Cadbury makes clear that in citing Seager, he was in no way endorsing a rigid or defined approach to assessing damages for breach of confidence, but in fact, stated the opposite:

24 The result of Lac Minerals is to confirm jurisdiction in the courts in a breach of confidence action to grant a remedy dictated by the facts of the case rather than strict jurisdictional or doctrinal considerations. See J. D. Davies, “Duties of Confidence and Loyalty”, [1990] Lloyd's Mar. & Com. L.Q. 4, at p. 5:

There is much to be said for the majority view [in Lac Minerals Ltd.] that, if a ground of liability is established, then the remedy that follows should be the one that is most appropriate on the facts of the case rather than one derived from history or over-categorization.

Justice Bourgeois observed that the facts of a particular case can give rise to numerous approaches to valuing the damages flowing from a breach of confidence. In Justice Bourgeois' view, in assessing compensatory damages, the trial judge utilized a flexible approach to the facts as he found them. The trial judge combined a willing seller/willing buyer approach with one that also recognized a depreciation in the value of the information disclosed. Justice Bourgeois saw no error in this approach.

The appellant submitted that the trial judge had the necessary evidence to establish the fair market value of the delivery system, but failed to use it as a means of determining damages on the basis of a “willing seller/willing buyer” assessment. The expert opinion was presented for the purpose of establishing the fair market value of the delivery system, which, the appellant asserted, was equivalent to what a willing buyer and willing seller would establish as a fair sale price. The expert opined that value as being between $2,035,000 and $2,495,000. The appellant contended that the trial judge was confused with respect to the purpose of the expert report—it was not to make a claim for lost profits, but rather to reflect the fair market value of the delivery system for the purpose of establishing a sale price between a willing buyer and seller. Based on this misapprehension, the trial judge erroneously discounted the expert opinion based on certain assumptions relied upon by the expert. The trial judge noted a number of assumptions contained in the expert opinion. However, the appellant submitted that none of the assumptions were relevant to the purpose of the expert's valuation: to establish what a willing buyer would pay for the delivery system. All of the assumptions criticized by the trial judge applied to a scenario in which the appellant retained the delivery system and continued to operate it. None applied to a scenario where the system was purchased by any number of potential buyers. As such, the assumptions the trial judge viewed as undermining the valuation would have no impact on the value of the system to a willing buyer. The appellant argued that the trial judge ought not to have rejected the expert opinion and should have awarded the higher end of her valuation.

Justice Bourgeois concluded that the trial judge in no way misapprehended the purpose of the expert opinion or its content. The appellant's claim that the trial judge misunderstood the report as being a loss of profits quantification, as opposed to establishing a market value for the purposes of a willing buyer and willing seller, was refuted by the report itself. Two alternative approaches to quantifying the appellant's economic loss were considered: the lost profit approach and the business valuation approach. The expert concluded that the former was the appropriate means of establishing the appellant's loss. Given the framing of the expert opinion and its statement of claim seeking “loss of past and future profits”, the appellant's assertion that the trial judge suffered from a misapprehension was unwarranted.

Justice Bourgeois did not accept the appellant's suggestion that the factual assumptions identified by the trial judge as undermining the expert opinion were irrelevant to its claim. The expert specifically indicated that should the evidence at trial not support the assumptions she had been asked to apply by the appellant and its legal counsel, her opinion might change. The trial judge found that the evidence at trial did not support several of those key assumptions. As such, the trial judge was entitled to view the expert's valuation with wariness.

The appellant's third source of alleged error was that the trial judge, in undertaking his consideration of compensatory damages, only considered the breach of confidence arising from the misuse of information in the Cumberland RFP. Despite having found that further technical information “consistent with the TDC system” had been released in the provincial RFP, the trial judge improperly confined his valuation to the damages arising from the initial disclosure.

Justice Bourgeois observed that the appellant based the quantification of its economic loss on the KPMG report. The author identified the “valuation date” as being the issuance of the Cumberland RFP. No additional quantification was presented for additional damages arising from the second release. Given the appellant's expert treated the initial release as the moment when its damages crystallized, the trial judge could hardly be faulted for doing the same. In light of how the appellant chose to structure its claim at trial and the evidentiary record, Justice Bourgeois was satisfied the trial judge was not obligated to consider additional damages arising from the provincial RFP.

The appellant's alternative argument was presented in the event that the Court of Appeal found that it was open to the trial judge to reject the “willing seller/willing buyer” valuation. The appellant submitted that having rejected that opinion, the trial judge ought to have employed the “springboard” doctrine. This was explained as “the value of the cost of developing the Delivery System and a consulting fee as the Province saved itself those costs by taking and improperly using the Delivery System”. On appeal, the appellant asserted that the value, utilizing a 2.5-year time frame representing the time to develop the system, would equate to damages of $750,000. It calculated this as being a consultation fee, being the salary over the development period for the three Cockerill brothers, plus the compensatory damages awarded by the trial judge.

The trial judge agreed with the appellant's assertion that the respondent obtained a head start in the drafting and development of the RFPs by using its confidential information. The trial judge also found, however, that the successful bidders did not ultimately deploy systems that used the appellant's confidential information. He further found the breach did not involve the most valuable aspects of the delivery system.

Justice Bourgeois observed that the approach to assessing damages for a breach of confidence is necessarily a flexible one. The appellant presented no authority for its proposition that the trial judge was obligated to use any particular assessment approach. Further, the appellant had not demonstrated that the trial judge erred by failing to award its claim for its entire research and development costs. Justice Bourgeois observed that the trial judge was faced with a complex and unique set of factual circumstances where the appellant established a breach of confidence, but the evidence supporting its claim for damages was lacking Justice Bourgeois concluded that the trial judge was entitled to consider the evidence and apply a flexible approach to assessing damages.

headtext.bold: No Limits Sportswear Inc. v. 0912139 B.C. Ltd.

head.headtext: No Limits Sportswear Inc. v. 0912139 B.C. Ltd., 2015 CarswellBC 2712, 258 A.C.W.S. (3d) 445, 2015 BCSC 1698

para.paratext: The plaintiffs had not proved their only claim to a remedy.

The confidential information related to the plaintiffs' business plans in relation to a brand of men's underwear known as SAXX underwear. The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants misused the confidential information to develop and eventually launch in the following year a competing brand of men's underwear, the brand “MyPakage”.

headtext.bold: Reasons Given by Court for Award:

para.paratext: The plaintiffs pleaded that as a result of the defendants' alleged misconduct, the plaintiffs suffered a loss of opportunity and a reduction of their market share and market position, and they sought compensatory damages in this regard. The plaintiffs submitted that their damages should be calculated based on the theory that all sales and gifts by the defendants of MyPakage underwear, to date and for some years into the future, should be treated as a loss of sales of SAXX product by the plaintiffs. The plaintiffs projected damages of approximately $23 million into 2018.

The trial judge concluded that since the goal of the remedy for breach of confidence is to restore the plaintiff to the position it would have been but for the breach, that in a case where the only remedy claimed is compensation for the plaintiff's losses, failure to prove any losses would mean failure to prove entitlement to a remedy.

The claimed loss of business opportunity was based on the theory that the SAXX product lost market share to the MyPakage product, which got a head start in the market due to the defendants' misuse of confidential information. The plaintiffs failed to call any credible evidence that they suffered a loss of business opportunity, loss of market share, or loss of market position as a result of the launch of the MyPakage business and MyPakage product.

The evidence from Hawrish highlighted the fact that there were a number of potential outcomes that could arise from MyPakage underwear being sold in the market. One outcome could be that MyPakage educated consumers about this new category of specialty men's underwear, expanding the overall customer base for SAXX products as well. Indeed, some consumers introduced to this specialty market by the MyPakage product and advertising could have since become loyal Saxx Apparel consumers if they found the Saxx Apparel product to be superior. This was speculative, but so too was any theory to the contrary.

To prove damages, the plaintiffs relied solely on the evidence of two members of the No Limits corporate team, McCurry and Jewell. Neither witness was independent or objective in the way an independent expert witness would be. McCurry had no evidence to give that would allow the Court to conclude that every sale or gift of the MyPakage product (or any portion thereof) resulted in lost Saxx Apparel sales. He simply did some calculations on the instructions of the plaintiffs' counsel that he should assume 100% of sales or gifts of MyPakage product, beginning in 2011, equated to lost sales of SAXX product, and then apply Saxx Apparel profit margins to those figures. He also assumed without any evidentiary basis that any loss of sales of SAXX product due to sales of the MyPakage product would increase by 20% each year from 2011 through 2018, and projected a total loss of sales of just over $23 million. No independent evidence, such as that by a business valuator, was tendered to justify McCurry's calculations, including: the 20% increase, the time span of the claim, and the fact there were no allowances for contingencies and no present valuing of this enormous claim. There was no evidentiary basis on which one could conclude that McCurry's calculation was a fair assessment of the plaintiffs' damages. The plaintiffs called no evidence as to their market share or market position in relation to other brands of men's underwear in 2009 or subsequently. There was therefore no evidence capable of supporting factual conclusions as to what the plaintiffs could have achieved in sales of the SAXX product, but for alleged sales of MyPakage product, compared to what the plaintiffs did actually achieve in sales of the SAXX product after the alleged misconduct and launch of the MyPakage product.
While the equitable principles upon which a claim for breach of confidence is based are flexible, there still needs to be some evidence to support the remedy claimed.

There was not the proper evidentiary support on which to base a finding that the MyPakage product and MyPakage marketing efforts had a negative impact on the plaintiffs' sales of SAXX or Saxx Apparel's market share. The plaintiffs failed to prove their claim for relief which was based on the allegation that they would have been in a better position, with greater market share, and greater sales, but for the defendants' breach of confidence.

head.headtext: Jane Doe 464533 v. D. (N.), 2016 CarswellOnt 911, 2016 ONSC 541

para.paratext: General damages of $50,000
Aggravated damages of $25,000
Punitive damages of $25,000
Order directing the defendant to immediately destroy any and all intimate images or recordings of the plaintiff, in whatever form they may exist, that he has in his possession, power or control.
Order permanently prohibiting the defendant from publishing, posting, sharing or otherwise disclosing in any fashion any intimate images or recordings of the plaintiff.
Order permanently prohibiting the defendant from communicating with the plaintiff or members of her immediate family, either directly or indirectly.

The plaintiff's ex-boyfriend posted an intimate video of her on a pornography website without her knowledge or consent. In early December 2011, the plaintiff learned that the defendant had posted the video she sent him on an Internet pornography website under the “user submissions” section of the website. As posted by the defendant, the video was titled “college girl pleasures herself for ex boyfriends (sic) delight.” She further learned that the defendant had been showing it to some of the young men with whom they had attended high school. She later learned that the video had been posted online on the same day she had sent it to him, and that its existence had become known among some of her friends. The video was available online for approximately 3 weeks, before it was “removed”.
There was no way to know how many times it was viewed or downloaded or if and how many times it may have been copied onto other media storage devices or recirculated.

The plaintiff's lawyer sent a demand letter to the defendant in February 2012. The defendant admitted having posted the video, but advised that it had been removed and that he did not consider that the plaintiff's claims for compensation had any merit. The defendant failed to serve a statement of defence and had been noted in default.

headtext.bold: Reasons Given by Court for Award:

para.paratext: The consequences for the plaintiff arising from the defendant's conduct had been significant and long-lasting. She saw a counsellor at her school for over a year and a half to deal with the emotional fallout from the posting of the video. She experienced serious depression and emotional upset. On the occasions since the incident when she had encountered the defendant she has become emotionally distraught and unable to cope, sometimes collapsing. The plaintiff remained conscious of the fact that the video was viewed by acquaintances of the defendant, that its existence was known to other members of her former social circle and has caused harm to her reputation. More than four years after the incident, she was emotionally fragile and worried about the possibility that the video may someday resurface and have an adverse impact on her employment, her career, or her future relationships. She continued to be distraught about the incident and afraid that these feelings would haunt her for a long time to come. Despite these challenges, she finished her undergraduate studies and was attending a graduate program that would enable her to become a health care professional when she graduated. She remained worried, however, that the defendant's actions had put her future career in jeopardy should news of these events surface again.

The plaintiff's action was commended under the Simplified Procedure and thus her damage claim was limited to $100,000. Plaintiff's counsel submitted that a much higher award was suitable, but conceded that she was restricted to the $100,000 limit.

In support of the damage award sought, plaintiff's counsel analogized this case to ones involving claims arising from physical sexual battery, with its attendant psychological impact and consequences: although the physical injuries may be modest and ones from which the victim may recover relatively promptly, the emotional and psychological effects of the offensive conduct are frequently severe and long-lasting. Given the novelty of the plaintiff's claim, there is no Canadian case law to guide in determining a suitable monetary award. In light of the nature of the wrong, the significant and ongoing impact of the defendant's conduct on the plaintiff's emotional and psychological health, and its similarity to the impact of a sexual assault, some assistance may be found in that category of cases. The judge recognized that, unlike cases which involved actual battery of the plaintiff, there was no physical touching. That said, the plaintiff's resulting injuries bore striking similarities to those for which the courts have awarded compensation in other cases. The actions of the defendant offended and compromised the plaintiff's dignity and personal autonomy. A non-pecuniary damage award in should similarly “demonstrate, both to the victim and to the wider community, the vindication of these fundamental, although intangible, rights which have been violated by the wrongdoer.”

The judge considered the factors approved by the Supreme Court in Blackwater v. Plint, [2005 CarswellBC 2358 (S.C.C.)]: With respect to the circumstances of the victim at the time of the events, including factors such as age and vulnerability, the plaintiff was 18 years old at the time of the incident, a young adult who was a university student. Judging by the impact of the defendant's actions, she was a vulnerable individual. With respect to the circumstances of the assaults including their number, frequency and how violent, invasive and degrading they were, the wrongful act consisted of uploading to a pornographic website a video recording that displayed intimate images of the plaintiff. The defendant's actions were thus very invasive and degrading. The recording was available for viewing on the Internet for some three weeks. It is impossible to know how many times it was viewed, copied or downloaded, or how many copies still exist elsewhere, out of the defendant's (and the plaintiff's—and the Court's) control. As well, the defendant showed the video to his friends, who were also acquaintances of the plaintiff. Although there was no physical violence, in these circumstances, especially in light of the multiple times the video was viewed by others and, more importantly, the potential for the video still to be in circulation, it was appropriate to regard this as tantamount to multiple assaults on the plaintiff's dignity. With respect to the circumstances of the defendant, including age and whether he or she was in a position of trust, the defendant was also 18 years of age. He and the plaintiff had been in an intimate—and thus trusting—relationship over a lengthy period. It was on this basis, and on the basis of his assurances that he alone would view it, that he persuaded her to provide the video. His conduct was tantamount to a breach of trust. With respect to the consequences for the victim of the wrongful behaviour including ongoing psychological injuries, the consequences were emotionally and psychologically devastating for the plaintiff and are ongoing. Having regard to these factors and the past and ongoing impact of the defendant's actions on the plaintiff, the judge assessed her general damages at $50,000. This case involved much more than an invasion of a right to informational privacy and was in many ways it is analogous to a sexual assault.

This was a case where an award of aggravated damages was warranted. Such damages may be awarded where the damage to the plaintiff was aggravated by the manner in which the culpable act was committed. The posting of the video amounted to a breach of the trust reposed by the plaintiff in the defendant that he would not reveal it to anyone else. This feature of the defendant's behaviour was an affront to their relationship that made the impact of his actions even more hurtful and painful for the plaintiff. The judge awarded $25,000 on this account.

The plaintiff sought orders that would prevent a repetition of the defendant's conduct and further violations of her rights. Such relief was appropriate to ensure that no further incidents of this nature occurred. It was unclear whether the defendant still possessed any copies of the video or other intimate images of the plaintiff.

headtext.bold: Seaway Marine Services Ltd. v. Weiwaikum General Partner Ltd.

head.headtext: Seaway Marine Services Ltd. v. Weiwaikum General Partner Ltd., 2014 CarswellBC 3311, 2014 BCSC 2102

para.paratext: No damages awarded

A monetary remedy for a breach of confidence will not be granted in circumstances where the plaintiff is not able to show some detriment or loss as a result of those breaches. A bald allegation that a breach of confidence caused damage without any facts to show any loss or detriment is not sufficient.

The case concerned the ownership and operation of a marine fuel barge docked at a marina. The fuel barge and associated equipment was owned by Esso for several years. Esso decided to divest itself of all marine fuel dock operations on the British Columbia coast. The plaintiff was notified of Esso's intention to not renew their dealership agreement. Shortly thereafter, the plaintiff expressed an interest to Esso in buying the fuel barge and associated equipment from Esso, and assuming Esso's lease. The Weiwaikum board assumed management of certain marina-related assets, including the Esso/ lease which was soon coming to an end. The Weiwaikum board sent letters requesting various items of information related to the lease to Esso and to the plaintiff concerning the lease and the marine fuel operation. It received representations from the plaintiff in support of the plaintiff's plan to purchase the fuel barge and assume the lease. The plaintiff's reply to Weiwaikum enclosed a “Letter of Intent” indicating that the plaintiff was in the midst of negotiations with Esso to purchase the fuel barge and with Devco to assume Esso's leasehold. Weiwaikum ultimately decided that the Limited Partnership would purchase the fuel barge from Esso.

The plaintiff alleged that the defendants breached confidence in relation to the information the plaintiff communicated, including reports on the condition and value of the fuel barge; the plaintiff's financial statements; and an outline of the plaintiff's operational plan for the marine fuel business. The trial judge observed that equity is “quick to protect confidences” and sets a “relatively low threshold” on the type of information capable of providing the foundation for a breach of confidence claim. The trial judge had no difficulty in concluding that the information as to the barge condition and value, the information in the financial statements, and the aspects of the “operational plan” was confidential information and accepted on that basis by Weiwaikum. The plaintiff's documents were manifestly confidential. The information in them would have been known to very few outside of the plaintiff, was acquired by the expenditure of the plaintiff's money or its effort, and could not be easily acquired or duplicated by others. The defendants received the information from business letters exchanged during the course of commercial negotiations. The reasonable person standing in the shoes of the defendants would have realized on reasonable grounds that the information was being given by the plaintiff in confidence, and the equitable duty of confidence was therefore imposed.

The trial judge's conclusion that the defendants were entitled to use the plaintiff's barge information when considering all of the various options for the fuel dock narrowed the issue to whether the defendants made use of the financial statements or confidential aspects of the “operational plan” for purposes other than assessing the viability of the plaintiff as a tenant. Briefing notes prepared for a meeting with Chief Pollard included a reference to information from figures extracted from the plaintiff's 2005 income statement and reflected use of the financial statements for an unauthorized purpose. The use of the information in the financial statements as part of a briefing note for a meeting to consider whether the Limited Partnership should take over the marine fuel dock was not a permitted use of this confidential information. The question whether the information was actually factored in to the decision to purchase and run the fuel barge was another matter. The trial judge considered it unlikely that there was substantive discussion at this brief meeting on the question of whether the Limited Partnership should take over the fuel dock business, and highly unlikely that any use was made during this meeting of the plaintiff's 2005 financial figures.

headtext.bold: Reasons Given by Court for Award:

para.paratext: The only misuse of confidential information demonstrated was very limited, namely, the inclusion of data from the 2005 financial statements in the Weiwaikum briefing note. There was no evidence that the very limited misuse of the confidential information played any part in the decision taken to acquire the fuel barge and operate the marine fuel business. The plaintiff was in no different position than it would have been in had the misuse not occurred. The plaintiff failed to prove damages on a “common sense view of causation.

The plaintiff was not entitled to compensatory damages for the defendants' misuse of confidential information despite the submission that this result was foreclosed by the necessary imposition on the defendants of a “special disability in the field of competition”. The trial judge understood the plaintiff's argument to be that this “special disability” was imposed regardless of the nature and extent of the misuse of confidential information. The trial judge observed that the difficulty with this argument was that it lost sight of the relationship between the concept of “special disability” and the concept of using information as a “spring-board” to get an “unfair start”.

The trial judge observed that the result should not differ between a case where information is in fact “nothing very special” and a case where information may have value but is treated by the recipient as if it was “nothing very special”. The trial judge concluded that the plaintiff's claim failed because the limited misuse of the confidential information by Weiwaikum made no difference to the plaintiff's position. The breach of confidence was not sufficiently serious that the Court should invoke its equitable discretion to award damages.

head.headtext: Spartek Systems Inc. v. Brown, 2014 CarswellAlta 1496, 2014 ABQB 526, additional reasons (2015), 2015 CarswellAlta 477, 2015 ABQB 190

para.paratext: No damages awarded

The defendant Hartwell was employed by the plaintiff until he was terminated in August 2005. In the summer of 2004, Hartwell spoke to Brown after Brown had announced his departure from Spartek. Brown contacted Hartwell from time to time, requesting his assistance with mechanical drawings for proposed tools. Hartwell prepared these drawings at home, after work hours. He prepared the drawings using Spartek templates as blank forms. It was his evidence that he did not use Spartek drawings or other confidential information. He was not paid. Some of these tools were similar to and would compete with Spartek products. None of the proposed tools were manufactured in larger numbers or distributed to the market. Hartwell admitted that he sent confidential Spartek information on one occasion. Shortly before leaving for Tunisia, Holt lost part of a Spartek tool that was included in the production logging tool. There was no substitute available from Spartek, so Hartwell sent Spartek's drawings to Holt so that Holt could manufacture a replacement.

headtext.bold: Reasons Given by Court for Award:

para.paratext: The trial judge concluded that Hartwell breached his duty of confidence to Spartek, as well as his contractual obligation to keep Spartek information confidential. He admitted that he provided confidential Spartek information to replace a lost tool. However, no damages were assessed as there was no evidence that Spartek suffered any loss as a result. The information that Hartwell provided to Holt assisted Holt in performing a service job in Tunisia. This was neither a business that Spartek carried on nor a geographical location where Spartek's customers carried on business.

The trial judge was not satisfied that there were other breaches by Hartwell of his duty of confidence to Spartek, or that any breaches caused damage to Spartek. The trial judge accepted Hartwell's evidence that he used Spartek blank templates when making drawings, but not their confidential information and concluded that to the extent that the templates themselves were confidential information, their use by Hartwell after work hours as blank canvases for his own drawings did not cause damage to Spartek.

headtext.bold: Service Corp. International (Canada) Ltd. v. Nunes-Pottinger Funeral Service & Crematorium Ltd.

head.headtext: Service Corp. International (Canada) Ltd. v. Nunes-Pottinger Funeral Service & Crematorium Ltd., 2012 CarswellBC 1100, 2012 BCSC 586, 2012 C.L.L.C. 210-062 (B.C.S.C.), additional reasons 2012 CarswellBC 3301, 2012 BCSC 1588

para.paratext: Damages as against the defendants Nunes, Pottinger and Nunes-Pottinger Funeral Service and Crematorium Ltd., jointly and severally, in the total amount of $280,285.00.
Punitive damages of $10,000 as against Nunes.

The long time manager of a funeral home resigned to open a competing business, taking the entire staff with him. As of September 2008, the funeral home had files containing approximately 300 pre-need contracts. The majority of pre-need contracts had been made with one insurer—Assurant Life. Those contracts were also the most easily transferred to another funeral home. Copies of more than 200 of those files were made and taken. The files included the information needed to contact the clients and persuade them to transfer their contracts. In the seven months between the opening of NP and April 30, 2009, a total of 208 pre-need contracts were transferred from Graham to NP. In March 2009, when the plaintiff demanded return of its files, the defendant denied that NP was in possession of any Graham documents. However, the defendants eventually consented to an order, under which they were to return all documents, including copies. Most of the copied files were returned but about 40 had by then been destroyed. The destroyed files were likely the ones for which no transfer had been obtained. Every file that was returned contained a transfer form in favour of NP.

headtext.bold: Reasons Given by Court for Award:

para.paratext: Taking and using confidential information is clearly a breach. Nunes and Pottinger were in breach of a departing employee's duty of good faith and confidentiality not to misuse confidential information obtained from their former employer. Nunes, Pottinger and NP were jointly and severally liable for misuse of confidential information to obtain the transfer of pre-need contracts. The plaintiff must be compensated for the loss of future income those contracts represented, less the portion of that income that would have gone to NP even in the absence of wrongful conduct.

There was obviously no way to determine with any certainty how many pre-need contracts would have been transferred if NP had waited for individual clients to initiate the process. There was no doubt that Nunes' standing in the community would have led some clients to transfer their pre-need contracts. The best guide to what would likely have happened can be found in the actual experience of the two funeral homes in competing for new pre-need contracts in 2009 and 2010. The remaining 208 customers, or 67.5 per cent, obviously were favorably disposed to transferring their files to NP. However, in the absence of economic or other pressing need to consider the matter, they would not necessarily have done anything about it. It was reasonable to assume that only about half of that group would have actually made the effort to find their documents and contact NP about transferring their policies. That would leave NP with 104, or about one third of the total pre-need contracts. It was appropriate to reduce the expert's calculation by half to represent a transfer rate of about one third per cent, resulting in an award of $263,000 for the loss of the transferred pre-need business.

The plaintiff failed to prove a loss of business after October 1, 2008, except for the loss of new pre-need contracts between that date and the end of 2008. The diversion of business by Nunes likely resulted in a loss of nine such contracts. The expert's calculations, based on an assumed loss of 15 contracts, showed a present value of lost future income of $18,028, plus lost “marketing allowance,” which is paid by Assurant on sale of the contracts, of $6,616. Pro-rating that amount for nine contracts produces a loss of approximately $14,800.

head.headtext: GasTOPS Ltd. v. Forsyth, 2012 CarswellOnt 2539, 2012 ONCA 134, 2012 C.L.L.C. 021, 2012 C.L.L.C. 210-021, 288 O.A.C. 201 (Ont. C.A.)

para.paratext: Permanent injunction refused.
Corporate defendant to disgorge profits from military contracts in its first ten years of operation.
Damages awarded against the personal appellants equivalent to the profits earned by MxI from military contracts in its first ten years of operation.
All appellants ordered to pay this amount jointly and severally quantified at $12,306,495.00.

The trial judge found the personal appellants, F, B, C and V liable to the respondent GasTOPS Ltd. for breach of fiduciary duty, breach of confidence and breach of their contract of employment. He found the respondent MxI Technologies Ltd. liable for breach of confidence.
The principal issue on appeal was the trial judge's use of ten years as the timeframe for the assessment of damages and for the disgorgement of MxI's profits.

GasTOPS was engaged in the design, development and application of computer software products that assess machinery conditions for maintenance purposes for operators of gas turbine engines. During 1996, GasTOPS was in the course of developing the next iteration of its technology. As of October 1996, GasTOPS was an industry leader in the area of engine condition-based maintenance, usage and life tracking of engine parts. None of the software programs developed by GasTOPS' competitors were as sophisticated or covered such a wide spectrum of engine maintenance elements as GasTOPS product line. Up until October 1996, the personal appellants were all employees of GasTOPS. These four were considered effectively the designers of the core programs within the family of GasTOPS' technology products. They set up MxI and they were all well aware of the business opportunities GasTOPS was pursuing and its proposals to potential customers. They had full knowledge of the design of GasTOPS' family of products. They were in possession of the 1997 GasTOPS' business plan and its strategic plan to acquire the U.S. Navy as a customer. Because of their responsibilities, the roles they played in the development of the respondent's product lines, and the information they possessed, the trial judge held that they were crucial to the direction and guidance of the company.

As far back as May 1996, B and C had attended a seminar on starting a software company, unbeknownst to GasTOPS. The two subsequently shared the material with F. On October 7, 1996, F and B submitted separate, but identical, letters of resignation from GasTOPS. Three days later, C and V resigned. Within hours of their resignation from GasTOPS, F, B and C were meeting with GasTOPS employees and describing to them their plans to start up their own business, focused on aviation maintenance software. In short order, a number of other GasTOPS employees left to join with the four personal appellants.
MxI was incorporated on October 15, 1996. The original entrepreneurs behind it were the four personal appellants.

The immediate result for GasTOPS was that its customers, such as CAF and Dofasco, were caused to re-evaluate their existing business relationships with it. Prospective customers, such as the U.S. Navy, proceeded to re-evaluate their willingness to contract with GasTOPS.

Subsequent to their resignations, the appellants pursued virtually every existing and potential GasTOPS customer, including the CAF and the U.S. Navy. They used the confidential business information they had obtained while at GasTOPS to form their marketing strategy and develop their technology, the functionality of which was virtually identical to the technology they had designed and developed at GasTOPS. They used the technical information thus acquired at GasTOPS to do this. They simply offered GasTOPS' existing and prospective customers a virtually seamless transition to MxI and its products. MxI's success and GasTOPS' corresponding damage was immediate and significant. It began by MxI successfully usurping the business opportunity GasTOPS had cultivated with the U.S. Navy. Indeed, in its first three years, over 80 per cent of MxI's substantial total income was derived from U.S. Navy contracts.

headtext.bold: Reasons Given by Court for Award:

para.paratext: The trial judge, having rejected the claim for injunctive relief, ordered MxI to disgorge profits of $12,306,495.00. He ordered damages against the four personal appellants in the same amount.

The trial judge found that all the appellants, including MxI, acquired information that was confidential to GasTOPS. This information was both commercial (such as strategic business plans and individual customer needs) and technical (such as the details of software product design and data models). They misused that information to advance their own business to the detriment of GasTOPS in breach of their duty of confidence to GasTOPS.

The trial judge found that ten years was the duration of the losses suffered by GasTOPS due to the breach of fiduciary duty by the four personal appellants, for which they had to pay damages. This reflected the highly specialized nature of GasTOPS' business, the time required to develop and evolve its suite of products, and the useful life of the confidential information taken from it.

headtext.bold: Zoic Studios BC Inc. v. Gannon

head.headtext: Zoic Studios BC Inc. v. Gannon, 2012 CarswellBC 2792, 2012 BCSC 1322, 221 A.C.W.S. (3d) 346, 27 D.E.L.D. 25 (B.C.S.C.), affd 2015 BCCA 334, 2015 CarswellBC 2077

para.paratext: The plaintiff was not entitled to an accounting for the breach of confidence, but to equitable compensation.

The plaintiff was a computer visual effects studio which specialized in feature films, television shows, and commercials, video games, advertising and online content. Zoic BC was a wholly owned subsidiary of Zoic LA, a mid-sized Los Angeles based studio. At the time Zoic BC was first being planned in 2005, Zoic LA chose willing employees to relocate to Vancouver to set up the office. Two “senior employees” were chosen: the defendant and another employee. They were tasked with setting up Zoic BC. Once the Zoic BC office was running, they were co-managers in charge of overseeing the daily workings of the business and keeping up office morale generally. In 2008, the defendant was “elevated” to executive creative director. She also held the role of visual effects supervisor of the Zoic BC office. She reported directly to Zoic LA.

In the fall of 2009, Adams and the defendant began to discuss starting their own visual effects studio and doing freelance work. Around that time they purchased an RED camera which would allow them to shoot some of their “own projects.” They also set up Gmail accounts with their business name, Leviathan. Adams left Zoic BC in late January of 2010. When he left Zoic BC, he did not know whether Leviathan was going to get a contract for season 4 of Eureka. Adams signed a work-for-hire contract on February 17, 2010, for Leviathan Studios to provide some of the visual effects for season 4 of Eureka. At that time, the defendant was still employed by Zoic BC. Leviathan Studios had not yet been incorporated. Leviathan Studios was officially incorporated on February 22, 2010. Both the defendant and Adams were listed as shareholders and directors. On March 1, 2010, the defendant advised Zoic LA she was resigning. On March 11, 2010, Zoic BC learned of the existence of Leviathan Studios.

headtext.bold: Reasons Given by Court for Award:

para.paratext: The defendant breached her duty of fidelity, good faith and loyalty to Zoic BC. Her conduct while she was still employed by Zoic BC went beyond mere planning to establish a competing business; she competed while she was still employed.

The allegations of misuse of confidential information surrounded hard drives containing Eureka digital material, as well as other Zoic BC material. The defendants had the documents in their possession and admitted to using them. The pricing information would be confidential information. The defendant personally used the confidential information contained in the bid template. The plaintiff did suffer a loss by the use of this confidential information by the defendant. The defendant breached confidence. Through this breach, she also breached her duty of fidelity and good faith. Leviathan participated in the breach. The bid templates were used on behalf of Leviathan to bid on season 4 of Eureka.

The actuals template was the document used by Zoic BC to track their costs and profits. This document did contain confidential information that was not accessible outside the plaintiff's business. The defendant used the bid rate for the loan application actuals document. The plaintiff suffered a detriment through the misuse of the information. The defendant was in breach of her duty of confidentiality and her duty of good faith. Leviathan should also be held responsible for the breach. The actuals template was used to apply for a loan on its behalf.

Cumulatively these factors allowed Leviathan and the defendants to springboard ahead. They put Leviathan in a place to transition somewhat more easily into providing visual effects for Eureka than they could otherwise have done. However, it was not “far easier.” The defendants would have been in a position based on their knowledge and skill to determine pricing structures and rates fairly easily. The use of the information did allow Leviathan to transition faster. It did not, however, put them in a place where it was “far easier” to work with Eureka.

The defendants' actions were not an effective or dominant cause of the plaintiff' loss. The plaintiff had a reasonable probability of being awarded the visual effects contract for season 4 of Eureka. The defendant's failure to inform Zoic LA that Mr. Gore and GEP Productions were not returning did cause Zoic BC to lose the possibility of it renewing its contract with Eureka. Had the defendant informed them of such, they would have been able to approach GEP Productions and discuss the issue. Zoic BC had a chance, albeit a very small chance, to renew the contract.

As for the amount that the damages should be reduced by for the possibility the plaintiff would not have been awarded the contract, the loss of opportunity damages should be reduced by 95%. There was only about a 5% chance that Mr. Gore could have been persuaded to return. Eureka would likely have gone where Mr. Gore recommended.

Despite making a finding that the personal defendant and Leviathan misused confidential information, this was not a case in which an accounting was appropriate. The confidential information was “nothing very special.” It was only minimal pricing and financial information. The information, particularly the bid template, was something that it would not have taken anyone with experience very long to develop. The springboard effect was not for any significant length of time. The main use of the actuals document was to apply for a loan from the Business Development Bank of Canada. This did not allow the defendant to springboard in a dramatic fashion. To order an accounting of the profits made by the defendants from their contract with Eureka would simply be too harsh a remedy when the benefit the defendants gained from use of the confidential information is assessed. It would overcompensate the plaintiff as opposed to putting it back in the position it would have been but for the breach of confidence since the defendants did not as a result of the misuse of the confidential information obtain the Eureka contract.

On appeal, the main thrust of the appellant's position was that the Trial Judge focused almost entirely on whether the employee had the legal authority to bind Zoic BC, and/or whether her authority at Zoic BC was unfettered and that the Trial Judge failed to consider whether the employee exercised discretionary power to affect Zoic BC's practical interests. In dismissing the ground of appeal relating to breach of fiduciary duty, Justice Chiasson observed that the trial judge examined very thoroughly the authority of the employee, was alive to the law of fiduciary duty and that she considered the effect of the employee's authority on the interests of Zoic BC. The trial judge made no error of law. Her findings of fact were supported by the evidence.

The Court of Appeal allowed the appeal to the extent only of remitting the matter to the trial judge with the direction that she consider whether an equitable accounting should be ordered arising out of the personal respondents' breach of their duty of fidelity and loyalty by competing with the appellant.

head.headtext: Cruise Connections Canada v. Cancellieri, 2012 CarswellBC 137, 2012 BCSC 53, 2012 C.L.L.C. 210-026, 93 C.C.L.T. (3d) 242, 98 B.L.R. (4th) 32 (B.C.S.C.), additional reasons 2013 CarswellBC 2, 2013 BCSC 1

para.paratext: The plaintiff was awarded damages against the defendants, Cancellieri, Stover, Markus, Szeto, Iverson, Meridian and Vision 2000 in the amount of $590,000.

Damages of $120,000 were assessed for the plaintiff's loss caused by the defendants' misuse of confidential client information to transfer or cancel and rebook cruises through Vision 2000. In addition, damages were assessed in the amount of $470,000 for the loss of revenues the plaintiff would have received between September 2006 and December 2009 but for the defendants' breaches of contract and torts.

The plaintiff Cruise Connections claimed that it suffered damages of $1,751,000 as a result of the defendants' misappropriation and wrongful use of its confidential client information. The individual defendants were cruise booking specialists who provided services to the plaintiff until various times in September 2006 when they terminated their relationships with the plaintiff and formed a partnership through which they contracted with the corporate defendant, Vision Travel 2000 Travel Group Inc. to provide services to that defendant and to the defendant, Meridian Travel Limited including the booking of cruises.

The terms of each of the Contractor Agreements made between the plaintiff and the respective partnerships were identical. The intent of the parties was that the cruise booking specialists would hold in strict confidence all confidential, proprietary or trade secret information pertaining to Cruise Connections and its clients, who were the members of the travelling public with whom the cruise booking specialists dealt on behalf of the plaintiff.

headtext.bold: Reasons Given by Court for Award:

para.paratext: It was not unlawful for the individual defendants to leave Cruise Connections or to compete for business with the plaintiff. None of the defendant cruise booking specialists had signed a restrictive covenant prohibiting them from soliciting former customers. However, the defendant cruise booking specialists were prohibited by subparagraph 4.02(h) of the contractor agreements, and their common law duty of confidence, from using the plaintiff's confidential client information in the WinCruise database for any purpose other than conducting business on behalf of Cruise Connections. The defendants were not bound by a non solicitation clause. However, in breach of both the good faith and confidentiality provisions of the contractor agreements, the defendant cruise booking specialists misappropriated client lists from the plaintiff and then used them for the purpose of conducting business on behalf of Vision 2000.
The corporate defendants were vicariously liable for the office manager's tortious interference with the plaintiff's contractual relations.

An award of damages for losses flowing from the defendants' misappropriation and use of Cruise Connections' confidential information involves an assessment of the plaintiff's loss, rather than a mathematical calculation of those damages.

The plaintiff's claim for compensatory damages had two parts. First, the plaintiff claims damages for bookings the defendants wrongfully transferred, or cancelled and rebooked through Vision 2000. Second, the plaintiff sought compensation for the loss of future bookings resulting from the defendants' misuse of its confidential client information.

The plaintiff had not produced any agreements with the cruise lines or other documents to support its claims for the loss of incentive fees and advertising contributions. The amounts claimed were significant. The plaintiff had not suggested that no records existed. In these circumstances, the plaintiff failed to prove its claims for lost incentive fees and advertising contributions. Accordingly, the plaintiff's claim was reduced by $40,000 to remove the amounts sought for incentive fees and advertising contributions.

Further adjustments were necessary to allow for bookings cancelled or transferred for reasons unconnected with the defendants' misuse of the plaintiff's confidential information, and to deduct cancelled or transferred cruises of customers who were personal contacts of the sales agents. The damages under this head were assessed $120,000.

The plaintiff's damages flowing from the defendants' past and anticipated future use of the plaintiff's client contact information were estimated at $1,568,000. The plaintiff's loss was calculated for September 2006 through 2013, a period of seven years and four months.

The quantification of the plaintiff's damages over so long a period was excessive. Even without the misappropriation of any customer contact information, the cruise specialists, with the assistance of the corporate defendants' advertising resources would have re-established contact with many of their key customers in a short time. The customers' primary loyalty is to the particular agent with whom they have a relationship.

The determination of an attrition rate is specific to the facts in each case. Here, the close personal connection between client and cruise booking specialists, the loyalty of the client to the cruise booking specialist rather than the travel agency, and the ease of mobility of client and cruise booking specialist all militated in favour of an attrition rate greater than 15%. An attrition rate of 25% was realistic.

Because it was unlikely that the plaintiff would have retained 100% of its clients in 2006, the use of 1,670 client bookings as a starting point for the determination of the plaintiff's loss was flawed.

The assumptions by the plaintiff' expert witness that but for the individual defendants' misappropriation of confidential client information, the plaintiff would have retained 100% of its customers, and that the plaintiff's loss extended over seven years and four months were neither sound nor supported by the evidence. Further, the selection of a 15% annual attrition rate failed to adequately reflect the loyalty of customers to particular cruise specialists with whom they deal and the ease of mobility of both customer and cruise specialist. The report did not provide a reliable estimate of the plaintiff's actual loss.

The duration of the plaintiff's compensable loss should reflect the principle that an award of damages is intended to restore the plaintiff to the position it would have enjoyed had the tort not occurred and/or the contract had been performed. The factors specific to that determination included the normal rate of attrition of clients, the mobility of sales agents in the travel industry, the effect of other competition in the market place, the strength and duration of the relationship between sales agents and their clients, the time required for departing sales agents to find a new travel agency and begin to compete fairly, the ability of departed sales agents to solicit and acquire customers, including former customers through lawful advertising and the principle that the public interest in promoting free competition militates against unduly extending the duration of the damages. Weighing all of these factors, the reasonable period for the assessment of damages was from September 2006 through December 2009.

The assessment of damages began by adjusting the estimate to reflect the 60% retention rate, 25% client attrition rate commencing in 2007 and compounding from year to year, and the duration period of three years and four months. Damages must be assessed rather than calculated with precision. The adoption of a 60% retention rate and a 25% attrition rate gives considerable weight to the negative contingencies. The plaintiff was awarded damages for lost bookings from September 2006 through December 2009 in the amount of $470,000.

head.headtext: Zesta Engineering Ltd. v. Cloutier, 2010 CarswellOnt 7953, 2010 ONSC 5810, [2010] O.J. No. 4485, 77 B.L.R. (4th) 7, 86 C.C.E.L. (3d) 1 (Ont. S.C.J.), additional reasons 2013 CarswellOnt 410, 2013 ONSC 385

para.paratext: Zesta was awarded damages of $45,000 against Kelvin

The defendant Kelvin was incorporated in early 2000. It carried on a business similar to and in many ways competitive with that of Zesta. A large measure of Zesta's success was attributable to Cloutier. Cloutier was fired. Kelvin evolved into a much more substantial operation. The new Kelvin premises were outfitted with virtually the same equipment found in the Zesta manufacturing plant, in order to enable Kelvin to go into the business of manufacturing thermocouples.

The basic thrust of Zesta's confidential information claim was that “know-how”, information and documents regarding the design and manufacture of thermocouples that it had developed through trial and error over many years, were valuable information that Kelvin unlawfully used to springboard its new business into competition with Zesta. Within two to three months of setting up business, Kelvin was manufacturing thermocouples that were identical to those produced by Zesta. In doing so, Kelvin utilized a production system that was modeled on the one created at Zesta over the course of many years, utilizing equipment, supplies, suppliers and techniques developed and refined by Zesta through years of effort, experimentation, trial and error.

headtext.bold: Reasons Given by Court for Award:

para.paratext: Insofar as Zesta's production processes, equipment, supplies and suppliers were concerned, the court, subject to one exception, was unable to find that this information was confidential or communicated in confidential circumstances. The court did have concerns relating to product costing. Zesta's costing information was treated as confidential information. By incorporating it into Kelvin's costing spreadsheet, White was misusing Zesta's confidential information for the benefit of Kelvin. In turn, Kelvin used the information supplied by White using the Zesta confidential information for purposes of submitting a thermocouple pricing quote to Husky. In so doing, they breached Zesta's rights.

Zesta did not quantify its damage claim by reference to this specific wrong. The court estimated, however, that it would have taken Kelvin approximately six months to develop this body of knowledge on its own. In other words, instead of being able to cost its thermocouple products accurately at the commencement of its operations in March 2000, on its own Kelvin would have taken until September 2000 to be able to do so. In assessing damages for this wrong, it was difficult to correlate any specific loss or damage to Zesta. The proper award was the value of the benefit gained by Kelvin in wrongfully exploiting this confidential information. Zesta would have been able to make the thermocouple sales that Kelvin did during this period. In its first year of operation Kelvin had $496,135 in sales, and a contribution margin of $271,513. As with Zesta, not all of Kelvin's business was comprised of thermocouple manufacturing and sales, however, so not all of that revenue was connected to the misuse of the production costing information. At Zesta, manufacturing represented approximately 25 to 35% of annual revenues. If one assumed the same ratio at Kelvin, the manufacturing portion of the contribution margin of $271,513 was reduced to between $68,000 and $95,000 approximately. Allowing for six months of improper use of the information would reduce that sum to between $34,000 and $47,500. Erring on the side of the innocent party, Zesta was awarded damages of $45,000 against Kelvin.

head.headtext: Stonetile (Canada) Ltd. v. Castcon Ltd., 2010 CarswellAlta 1073, 2010 ABQB 392, 84 C.P.R. (4th) 350, 29 Alta. L.R. (5th) 239, [2010] 12 W.W.R. 143, 74 B.L.R. (4th) 49, 189 A.C.W.S. (3d) 815 (Alta. Q.B.)

para.paratext: Plaintiff awarded damages of $111,345.00 against both the defendants W and Castcon.

W was employed by Stonetile from 1992 until January, 2001. In 2003, he started a company, Castcon Ltd., to produce and sell a similar product to Stonetile, a cement exterior moulding system for buildings.
Stonetile took sufficient steps to guard its production process as confidential, to meet the onus it carries as the plaintiff to prove that the production process was confidential information.

The information was all conveyed from Stonetile to Robert Will in the context of an employer/employee relationship. The information was given to an employee, and at a later date, the employee was requested to and did sign a confidential understanding.

headtext.bold: Reasons Given by Court for Award:

para.paratext: W's position as production supervisor or his involvement in the management or the executive committee, in the context of Stonetile's actual circumstances, did not mean that W stood in a fiduciary capacity to Stonetile, such that in addition to his employment obligations, he owed fiduciary duties.

The circumstances of W, as an employee getting detailed production information, who signed an understanding of confidentiality document requested by the employer would convey to the ordinary person that the parties were aware the employer was imparting knowledge it felt was confidential. The requirement to sign the understanding clearly communicated that there were aspects of the process, learnt through experience, that Stonetile did not consider that the employee was free to pass onto others.

W and then Castcon, with whom he did not stand at arm's length and who received the information knowing the circumstances of how it was communicated to W did misuse the information. The information and process he had learned through his employment allowed him to fast track his development. After some small but not significant experimentation, Castcon defaulted to essentially the same production methods based on building master moulds, and using plastic forming to create plastic forms to fill with cement to produce an exterior cladding system to attach to buildings. The information provided the classic “springboard” effect. There were some variations in the process and product between Stonetile and Castcon. However, most of the differences are small variations on a very similar theme. Although Castcon has developed somewhat differently from Stonetile, it was offering very similar products as Stonetile, to a similar market in Calgary.

The evidence did not support any suggestion that Castcon went head on with Stonetile with customers who were known to W during his employment there. Castcon was directly competing with Stonetile in Calgary, Alberta, which was Stonetile's primary place for business and sales.

A remedy must be designed to compensate the plaintiff for the misuse of its information, which led Castcon to springboard into a position to be able to start production more quickly than would otherwise have been the case. The other aspect that has to be considered is the fact that the springboard effect may not only reduce the time to reach commercial production of a product, but it also may take significant risks out of going into business. With the knowledge of the process and product, and the knowledge and experience gained from employment, a person may risk capital much more freely than the first person to develop the product, who puts more at risk in the face of uncertainty of whether the product will be successful, while also not knowing if there will be a commercial market. W while holding a full-time job, was able to bring Castcon from theory to first commercial sales in sixteen months. He was able to develop the lucrative Castlerock tile part of Castcon's business in a maximum of five months and to produce slate tiles with included thirteen inch hangers within another three months.

The confidential information that W took from Stonetile and gave to Castcon gave that company a one year head start from where it would have been, had it started from square one, and worked only with the individual bits of information in the public domain, and put them together to attempt to develop the products it now produces.

It is very difficult to determine the value of the one year head start. No expert evidence was called to assist the court. Stonetile's financial information did not help the Court to quantify a direct loss to Stonetile. Obviously the gross profit from Castcon's first year of operation was not the correct amount, as small companies starting out usually run at a loss as they get off the ground. The average annual gross profit for the years 2004 up to and inclusive of 2009 was $111,345. That was likely the most fair estimate of the annual gross profits to be earned. A fair assessment of damages for the one year head start in this case for the misuse of confidential information was the amount of $111,345.

head.headtext: Pat's Off-Road Transport v. Campbell, 2010 CarswellAlta 1354, 2010 ABQB 443, [2010] A.W.L.D. 3704, [2010] A.W.L.D. 3817, [2010] A.W.L.D. 3816, 75 C.C.L.T. (3d) 300, 500 A.R. 377, 191 A.C.W.S. (3d) 236 (Alta. Q.B.)

para.paratext: Order that the defendants are jointly and severally liable to the plaintiff for damages of $80,000.00.

Order that the defendants not disclose to any third party by way of selling, leasing, renting, lending out, assigning any interest in or making available to third parties in any way the Camko Fluid Heating Ltd., heating unit or any material relating to the trade secrets of the plaintiff.

The plaintiff's principal over a 20-year period culminating in 2001, developed, by trial and error, and with the investment of a great deal of time and money, a truck mounted heating unit that was commercially advantageous over its competitors. The plaintiff claimed this technology was being kept secret from the public and its competition, and the technology that was developed for the truck mounted heating unit was a trade secret.

In April 2001 the plaintiff hired the defendant as a truck driver. He was trained to operate, maintain and clean the trucks with the mounted heating units. The defendant's employment was terminated by the plaintiff on July 3, 2003. Two years after he left the plaintiff's employment, the defendant developed and built a truck mounted heating unit that was virtually identical to that of the plaintiff.
The design over which the plaintiff claimed a trade secret consisted of a truck mounted, low maintenance fluid heater with an easy to maintain, removable burner.

headtext.bold: Reasons Given by Court for Award:

para.paratext: At minimum, the defendant used, as part of his recipe for making his own hot oiler unit, some private information from the plaintiff. The building of the unit was not a simple process. Notwithstanding all of his research on the internet, his reverse engineering and his consultation with suppliers and manufacturers, the defendant could not have built his unit without the information and knowledge gained from working with the plaintiff.

The defendant's knowledge of the process was the springboard which led to the construction of his unit. The reasonable man would see an “equitable obligation of confidence”. By taking the confidential information that he gained while employed at the plaintiff, the defendant clearly used that as a “springboard” to build his own unit. The defendant personally and through his company breached his duty of confidence to the plaintiff.
The court was not satisfied that the plaintiff had set out sufficient facts and thereby met the legal test to prove either breach of his fiduciary agreement or breach of his employment agreement.

There will be an order directing that the defendants be restrained from disclosing to any third party any information or documentation containing the trade secrets used to build the hot oiler truck mounted unit.

There was no actual monetary loss suffered by the plaintiff. In fact, the plaintiff's sales have increased considerably. There was no expert evidence led on the defendants' gain. The onus was on the plaintiff to establish on the basis of credible evidence its damages.

While the court could not accept the amount of damages put forward in argument by the plaintiff that did not mean the defendants should escape from any award of damages. Allowing the defendant and his company no penalty by way of damages even though his company made money by misappropriating his former employer's confidential information could not be countenanced. The defendant Camko Fluid Heating Ltd. earned a net income of $39,693.00 for the year end of May 31, 2007. No evidence was led from either side for the year end May 31, 2008, which was the last year the defendant operated the truck before selling the truck and shutting down operations. The court imputed income of the same amount as 2007 for the last year of operation of Camko Fluid Heating Ltd.

headtext.bold: RBC Dominion Securities Inc. v. Merrill Lynch Canada Inc.

head.headtext: RBC Dominion Securities Inc. v. Merrill Lynch Canada Inc., 2008 CarswellBC 2099, 2008 SCC 54, J.E. 2008-1919, 2008 C.L.L.C. 210-042, 68 C.P.R. (4th) 401, 298 D.L.R. (4th) 1, [2008] 3 S.C.R. 79, 169 A.C.W.S. (3d) 790 (S.C.C.)

para.paratext: Having made a global loss of profits award against the branch manager, it would be inappropriate to award additional damages against the investment advisors for loss of profits based on improper use of confidential information.

The trial judge awarded damages in the amount of $1,483,239 against the branch manager for the loss of profits RBC suffered as a result of his failure to perform his duties in good faith, specifically, his orchestration of the departure of virtually all RBC's investment advisors.

In addition, the trial judge awarded a total of $225,000 against the investment advisors for unfair competition. The trial judge held that during the 2.5 week notice period, the departing employees remained subject to their contractual duties and specifically their general duty of fidelity to RBC, which prevented them from competing with RBC during this period. She found that by competing against RBC during this period, the investment advisors, including the branch manager, caused RBC losses that continued after the notice period. Specifically, she found that in the absence of this “unfair” competition, RBC would have retained 25 percent rather than 13.5 percent of its clients. Hence the trial judge made an award against all the investment advisors for 11.5 percent of RBC's profits over a five-year period. This award was in addition to the $40,000 award for failure to give reasonable notice.

The trial judge took the view that the employees continued to be under a general duty not to compete with their former employer during the notice period. This formed the basis of her award for non-competition damages against them.

headtext.bold: Reasons Given by Court for Award:

para.paratext: To the extent the trial judge awarded damages on the basis that the employees continued to be a under a general duty not to compete, this award of damages was wrong in law.

The trial judge made additional findings about the RBC employees' use of confidential client records which suggested she might have awarded damages even in the absence of this erroneous holding. The trial judge made findings of fact regarding efforts of the employees to remove confidential information before leaving RBC. The trial judge made an additional finding that Merrill Lynch used these records to solicit RBC clients between the employees' departure and the return of the records shortly thereafter. In overturning the award, the Court of Appeal emphasized that the documents were very quickly returned, which may suggest the court viewed the trial judge as implicitly having concluded that no specific loss flowed from the conversion of the records due to the short duration they were held. The trial judge took into account the use of confidential information in making the global loss of profits award against the branch manager and accepted RBC's concession that no damages arose “uniquely” from the conversion of the records.

There was some discussion of the nature of the legal duties of managerial and non-managerial employees; the suggestion was that the former might have quasi-fiduciary duties, while the latter would not. The duties found here for all the defendant employees were the implied duties to perform one's employment functions in good faith and to give reasonable notice of termination. The compensatory damages awarded were grounded in these implied duties. It was therefore unnecessary to go beyond these duties.

headtext.bold: Flag Works Inc. v. Sign Craft Digital (1978) Inc.

head.headtext: Flag Works Inc. v. Sign Craft Digital (1978) Inc., 2007 CarswellAlta 1829, 2007 ABQB 434, 427 A.R. 206, 44 B.L.R. (4th) 190, 160 A.C.W.S. (3d) 481 (Alta. Q.B.), additional reasons 2007 CarswellAlta 1313, 2007 ABQB 579

para.paratext: The following damages were awarded:

Two employees left Flag Works, a flag and banner company where they had worked for over two and eight years respectively. They left at separate times and for their own reasons. They joined another company, Sign Craft that was in a related field of graphic design. This company started to compete in the flag and banner business under the name of Flag Craft. Before Flag Craft began operations in 2002 there had been virtually no competition in Calgary in relation to flags and banners and Flag Works had essentially occupied the field.
