Finlay and Trott each separately took and used a Flag Works' customer list while employed at Sign Craft. Holt retyped that customer list into the Excel format used by Sign Craft. That customer list was used, in combination with some other information, as the basis for a fax out to some 700 potential clients announcing that Sign Craft was starting a flag and banner business late in March 2002. Holt also took certain other materials with her.
Finlay admitted that she took a Flag Works' customer list with her to Sign Craft without permission. The list was generated from the company's FileMaker computer system.

headtext.bold: Reasons Given by Court for Award:

para.paratext: The evidence established clear breaches of an employee's common law obligations in relation to confidential property. This customer list was and remained the confidential property of Flag Works. The defendants' argument that the customer list did not create an advantage, or give them any benefit, was of little value and was used minimally would be addressed in the assessment of damages. Holt took the Flag Works' customer list and re-typed it in Excel format. This was a misuse of confidential information of her former employer and was a breach of Holt's common-law duties.

There were numerous problems with the claim of loss profit as advanced by the plaintiff. First, Flag Works suffered no absolute loss. Its claims were based on its expectations for future growth. The flag business is highly cyclical, with individuals not needing new flags every year. Even though there is an established track record for this company, it could not safely be assumed that prior years are necessarily accurate predictors of the future. The historic rate of growth may not reflect what the company could have hoped to realistically achieve in subsequent years. In this case, the revenues in the flag and banner divisions were greatly enhanced after September 11, 2001 by the significant and unprecedented sale of stock flags. As a result, it would have been most unlikely that the growth rate experienced between 2000 and 2001 could have continued at the same pace into 2002 and beyond.
It was difficult to reconcile the evidence that it took 10 to 12 months for the company to regain its position and a claim of lost profits for two years.

Even had there been no misuse of confidential information it was more likely than not that Flag Works would have suffered loss from the departure of these employees. The company lost accounts because it was simply too busy and could not produce the quality product it had previously. Whether seen as an absence of causation or inadequate mitigation, the result is comparable and the defendants could not attribute two years of lost profits to the defendants' breaches.

There can be no recovery for lost profits caused simply because a new flag and banner company entered the Calgary market. Competition per se is not a compensable harm. Even key employees are allowed to compete, especially in the absence of a non-competition agreement. Damages are only recoverable when caused by a breach of a recognized duty.

The plaintiff could not recover for the lost profits claimed because a majority of the loss claimed was attributable to the fact of competition alone. It was difficult to assess what loss, if any, was generated by the use of the Flag Works' customer list. However, where injury has been suffered in a complex commercial setting, a flexible and imaginative approach to the assessment of damages is appropriate. The key in determining damages in an action for misuse of confidential information is distinguishing between losses attributable to the employee's misconduct, and those that are the result of other intervening causes. The Flag Works's customer list provided valuable information as it was a grouping of potential purchasers for flags and banners who had already purchased such products; it provided timesaving contact information; and may have included notes concerning the needs and preferences of various customers.

The use of the Flag Works customer list by Finlay, the promotional materials and the fax out caused a certain level of loss to Flag Works. There were, however, numerous factors that undermined that common sense assumption and reduced the amount of loss attributable to the misuse of confidential information.

First, loss arising from competition alone cannot be claimed under this approach either. Second, losses caused by the departure of these employees alone cannot be claimed. Third, Finlay was successful at sales because she developed strong personal relationships; her customers “loved her” and as a result she had a large and loyal customer base. It is likely that some of these customers would have chosen to continue to do business with her because of their good working relationship even if she had not taken the customer list. Fourth, there could not be recovery for the sales that would have been lost because Ms. Flock was away or because Mr. Morgan was doing two full time jobs and had limited experience in production. Fifth, the list was of minimal assistance in securing clients, led to few actual sales and was not the cause of substantial loss.

Only modest recovery was warranted. Damages of $15,000 for the misuse of the confidential information were awarded to be split between Finlay and Holt. This amount was based loosely on the lost sales for one year, the percentage of traditional profits, and was discounted. Apportionment was equal because while Finlay took and made minimal use of the list, Holt used it for the fax out, which had a wide distribution.

head.headtext: Jones v. Klassen, 2006 CarswellAlta 31, 2006 ABQB 41, 14 B.L.R. (4th) 212, 55 Alta. L.R. (4th) 354, 2006 C.L.L.C. 210-021, 390 A.R. 66 (Alta. Q. B.)

para.paratext: Compensatory damages of $13,464.00
Punitive damages of $5,000.00

The defendant was employed as an investment representative from January 1999 until October 15, 2002.The defendant decided to leave Edward Jones and move to Cartier Partners. Cartier Partners was also a “storefront” brokerage firm, similar to Edward Jones, and was therefore potentially a direct competitor. When the defendant made his decision to change firms he printed a copy of the client list, as well as thousands of pages of contact sheet information relating to those clients, from which he made handwritten notes on the client list of important details concerning each account. He took both the client list and the contact information with him when he left. In addition, he took a list of potential clients. During the six months following the defendant's departure and letter to his clients, a total of 98 Edward Jones client investment accounts, totalling $3,393,101.10 in assets, transferred out of Edward Jones to the defendant at his new firm of Cartier Partners.

headtext.bold: Reasons Given by Court for Award:

para.paratext: The defendant had a contractual duty pursuant to the Employment Agreement, to surrender the client list and contact sheet information when he resigned from Edward Jones. He also had a contractual duty, pursuant to the Employment Agreement, not to solicit Edward Jones customers for a period of six months following termination of the Agreement.

The defendant was the “face” of Edward Jones. Within the framework of what Edward Jones offered all its clients, he had the discretion to make recommendations for purchases, sales, and in essence, all the day-to-day decisions relating to Edward Jones' clients in his territory. The defendant was in a fiduciary relationship with Edward Jones.

The defendant was not free to compete unfairly with his former employer, to use confidential information against his former employer. The defendant owed Edward Jones a duty at common law not to compete unfairly, and not to make use of confidential information against his former employer. By taking and using the information he did, the defendant breached those duties. He also breached his fiduciary duty to Edward Jones.

98 Edward Jones client investment accounts, totalling $3,393,101.10 in assets, transferred out of Edward Jones to the defendant at Cartier Partners, within the six months after his departure representing a transfer of 37 percent of the total asset base held by Edward Jones in that St. Albert office. It was reasonable to assume that some percentage of those monies may very well have been lost to other investment advisors, in any event. While speculative, the court accepted on that basis a 10 percent market attrition loss. There also would have been a 10 percent family and friends attrition rate, in any event, as a result of his move.

Edward Jones was able to retain the majority of the clients and, indeed, increase its client base in the St. Albert branch by the end of the six months after the initial six-month non-solicitation period. Accordingly, damages were only awarded for the initial six-month time frame.

The compensatory damages of $13,464 to Edward Jones would be significant for the defendant to bear. However, by not merely taking the client documentation, but by photocopying and retaining it while purporting to return the documentation through counsel, was behaviour that must be condemned by this Court. Accordingly, $5,000 in punitive damages was awarded.

head.headtext: Axiom Services Ltd. v. Weigert, 2005 CarswellBC 357, 2005 BCSC 145, 2 B.L.R. (4th) 185 (B.C.S.C.), additional reasons 2005 CarswellBC 1076, 2005 BCSC 665

para.paratext: Damages as a result of W's breach of duty were assessed at $10,000.

In October 2001 W and P, who were hairstylists at Axiom Hair Design, left that salon and began to work at Catz Hair Lair. W's shares in Axiom Services Ltd. had been purchased for $320,000. A share purchase agreement dated October 28, 1999 was entered into. The real value of the business lay in its ability to produce revenue, and this was dependent on its ability to maintain its clientele. The purchasers recognized that keeping the core group of stylists was essential to maintaining clientele, and they felt that they would be able to hold onto most of the staff after they bought the salon. They were particularly concerned about the possibility that W would open another shop, and they obtained, as part of the deal, a “Non Competition Agreement” from W. The parties expected W to stay on at the salon as a part-time hairstylist without management responsibilities. Within months of selling the salon, W found herself unhappy working there as a mere stylist. W planned her exit from Axiom carefully, and in advance. She made arrangements with P to work at her salon before P even completed the purchase. W began contacting her clients, using the list she had had printed out from the Axiom database. Only a handful of W's clients remained loyal to Axiom. The economic effects on Axiom were significant. W was well aware that the database was confidential, and that stylists were not entitled to access it. She then used the client list to contact her clients, and to ensure that they continued with her rather than with Axiom.

headtext.bold: Reasons Given by Court for Award:

para.paratext: The court did not agree that W assumed the obligations of a fiduciary following the sale of Axiom. She was a mere employee in the aftermath of the sale. She played no part in the management of the company, and exercised no supervisory role over employees.
P was one of the top three stylists at Axiom, in terms of revenue, but she was neither a director, manager, nor even a “key employee” such as to attract special fiduciary duties.
The claim against W was allowed on the basis that she wrongfully appropriated database information that was the property of the plaintiffs

The evidence did not provide any method of accurately quantifying the damages caused to the plaintiffs as a result of W's wrongful appropriation of client lists. Most of the plaintiffs' decrease in business following the departure of the two stylists was attributable to P's departure. As P did not breach any duty to the plaintiffs, it followed that they were not entitled to any recovery for the bulk of their financial setback. The loss attributable to W's departure was better estimated by looking at her subsequent income than by looking at Axiom's decrease in revenues or profits. For the years 2000 to 2003, W's income was approximately $23,000 per year. There was some evidence to suggest that, as a rule of thumb, 30% of a stylist's customers remain with a salon when a stylist leaves. The proportion would have been smaller, due to the personal loyalty and longstanding nature of W's customers. As well, due to her relatively small client base, she would have been able to contact a large proportion of her clients even if she had not appropriated client lists.

head.headtext: Calian Technology Ltd. v. Fredrickson, 2004 CarswellOnt 3076, 47 B.L.R. (3d) 250 (Ont. S.C.J.)

para.paratext: Award of damages equal to the lost profit for the four years of the contract, in the amount of $172,760.
Calian Technology Ltd. (Calian) offered technology-related services to clients, including the federal government, principally in the areas of temporary staffing and outsourcing services.

Frederickson and Poluchowski were employees of Calian on a contract, known as the SARSAT project, in which the services of these two individuals were provided to the Department of National Defence. The contract was scheduled to end in mid-2000. On July 26, 2000 Public Works and Government Services Canada issued a Request For Proposal to provide the services of two individuals to the SARSAT project for a further two year period, with two option years. Basically, the RFP involved the continuation of the kind of services which were provided by Calian through Frederickson and Poluchowski on the current SARSAT project. In response to the RFP, Calian submitted a proposal and offered the services of Frederickson and Poluchowski who, as employees of Calian, were the incumbent individuals working on the site on the previous contract.

Unknown to Calian, Martin also submitted a bid in response to the same RFP and, with the consent of Frederickson and Poluchowski, also offered the services of these two individuals. Martin was the successful bidder and secured the contract. Frederickson and Poluchowski resigned from Calian and continued working on the new contract as employees of Martin.

headtext.bold: Reasons Given by Court for Award:

para.paratext: The résumé of Frederickson, as prepared by Calian, which contained the extensive cross-references with respect to evaluation criteria and Statement of Work which specifically refer to the RFP were prepared by Calian and that document, as a whole, including the cross-references, was the property of and confidential to Calian. Frederickson and Poluchowski breached their obligations of confidentiality owed to Calian when they delivered those documents to Martin.

The documents as delivered to Martin went far beyond what could reasonably have been expected to be the résumé of each of these individuals. Martin received the documents and used the information in these documents, which it must have known to be confidential to Calian, in its own bid. Had it not had that information available to it, together with the assistance of Frederickson and Poluchowski, Martin could not have assembled the technical proposal for the bid by September 13, 2000. Martin knowingly participated in the breaches of confidentiality by Frederickson and Poluchowski and this enabled it to assemble the technical proposal of the bid, which was then technically compliant with the RFP. Had such information not been available to Martin, it would not have been able to successfully bid on this contract and the contract would have been awarded to Calian.

Calian was entitled to an award of damages equal to the value to Calian of the lost contracts. Its gross margin, as calculated on its bid, amounted to 23.61 percent. Based on its estimated revenue of $182,963 for each year and a total salary cost, including benefits, for these two individuals for each year of $139,773 Calian sought to recover its lost profit of $43,190 for each year, for a total of four years, being the sum of $172,760.

Where the general overhead costs would have been incurred in any event, a deduction from a claim of damages for general overhead expenses would indeed penalize the injured party twice. There should be no deduction for general overhead expenses. Given that the contract in fact lasted for four years, it is appropriate that the profits which were lost to Calian over that period be included in an award of damages.

headtext.bold: Billows v. Canarc Forest Products Ltd.

head.headtext: Billows v. Canarc Forest Products Ltd., 2003 CarswellBC 2154, 2003 BCSC 1352, 27 C.C.E.L. (3d) 188, 2004 C.L.L.C. 210-015 (B.C.S.C.), additional reasons 2005 CarswellBC 1005, 2005 BCSC 623

para.paratext: Damages of $30,553 ($30,000 and the $553 for the extra work by Jensen) awarded to employer

Billows worked for Canarc as a lumber trader and office manager of Canarc's Surrey office from September 16, 1997, to December 13, 1999. He was paid by commissions on his lumber sales. When he left Canarc, Billows and a partner, through their holding companies, each became fifty per cent owners of Millenium, also a lumber wholesaler.

On leaving Canarc, Mr. Billows immediately began, or had already begun, his preparations for establishing his own company. Many of Millenium's customers were formerly customers of Canarc. Billows did not restrict himself to publicly accessible information about his future customers when he solicited them. He used information he acquired at Canarc and recorded in his black book to solicit and acquire former customers of Canarc. The list of Millenium's customers which Billows produced at Canarc's request contained 25 names of customers from a total of about 40 with whom Billows had dealt while at Canarc.

headtext.bold: Reasons Given by Court for Award:

para.paratext: Billows could not have made the projections in his business plan without confidential information he had recorded in the black book while at Canarc. His projections about huge business revenue from Tolco and Seemac came from knowing the volume of lumber those companies bought over a given period. He used information obtained from Canarc and its goodwill with these customers to persuade the bank to grant Millenium a line of credit.

Not only did he use the names of customers and their contact people, but also the volume of lumber purchased and the needs and preferences of customers. This gave Billows an unfair advantage over Canarc. His activity went much further than mere use of the skills he had acquired at Canarc; he made unfair use of information acquired during his employment with Canarc.

Canarc was entitled to be compensated for the further loss of business it suffered from Billows' breach of his duty of fidelity. Millenium had taken Canarc's former angle-cut business. Not only did the Canarc customers solicited by Billows take their angle-cut business to Millenium, they also took their non angle-cut work.

The damages from Billows' breaches of his employment contract, and duty of fidelity after he left Canarc were difficult to quantify. The damages from the breach of Billows' post-employment duty of fidelity and confidentiality have a temporal limit. Even had Billows competed fairly with Canarc, as he was entitled to do, he may well have succeeded anyway in obtaining part of Canarc's business. Four months was a reasonable period for which to award damages to Canarc.

The appropriate method of calculating Canarc's damages was to base it on the difference between Canarc's profit in 1999 and its profit in 2000. The evidence disclosed that the total decline in business for Canarc from 1999 to 2000 was represented by a gross margin of $1,691,275.63. This figure was the difference between the gross margin in 1999 of $2,452,987.60 and that in 2000 of $851,711.97. A fair estimate of net profit on the gross margin after deduction of other expenses such as commissions and overhead was 2%. On a reduction in gross margin of $1,691,275.63, the loss of net profit in 2000 from 1999 was $33,825.51. The period for which to calculate Canarc's damages is only four months. Canarc would have incurred most of its loss in the first four months of 2000. It was during this period that Canarc suffered the harm to its reputation, the loss of major customers to Billows, the time-consuming liquidation of Billows' inventory, and the obtaining of acceptable end-user statements. This was the period of intense damage control. After about four months, Canarc would have assumed new business and begun to recover its lost ground. A reasonable award was $30,000.

The alternative of basing the damages on Millenium's net profit for the first four months of 2000 was troubling; it did not account for the reasonable possibility that even had Billows not left Canarc in a disadvantageous position by breaching his employment contract, and even had he not breached his duty of fidelity, some of Canarc's clients would have followed him to Millenium in any event. There was also the real possibility they would have given Billows both the angle-cut and non angle-cut business for the convenience of using only one trader whom they already knew.

headtext.bold: Anderson Preece & Associates Inc. v. Dominium Appraisal Group Inc.

head.headtext: Anderson Preece & Associates Inc. v. Dominium Appraisal Group Inc., 2001 CarswellAlta 1873, 2001 ABQB 1073, [2001] A.J. No. 1608, 309 A.R. 124 (Alta. Q.B.)

para.paratext: The Plaintiffs were entitled to receive as equitable compensation for the unlawful conduct of the Defendants Osske, Desmoreau, Bramley and Dominium an award of damages in the amount of $150,000.

The Plaintiffs were entitled to recover damages from the Defendant Thiem in the several amount of $15,000 for the wrongful removal and conversion of APA's property for the benefit of her future employer

APA operated a full spectrum appraisal business. Prior to their departure, the individual Defendants had surreptitiously copied extensively from the files and computer records of APA for the purpose of facilitating the operation of the business of Dominium.

None of the Defendant appraisers had had any appraisal experience prior to their engagement by APA. In the fall of 1997, the individual Defendants undertook a systematic operation to copy and remove from the premises of APA master files, appraisal comparables, and forms and precedents which APA had established, including copies of the software programs for systems and storage of data in use by APA for the operation of its appraisal business. This copying and removal was done by each of the Defendants while employed with APA, both during and after working hours. Most of the hard copy duplication was performed on the photocopier of APA using APA paper as well as paper brought in for that purpose by the Defendants. Computer data was copied by Thiem onto 25 disks provided by Osske for that purpose. They continually utilized the materials removed from APA in the business of Dominium until receipt of a notice of the Anton Pillar Order which was served upon them November 27, 1998. Dominium relied on the APA precedents and systems in the creation of its appraisal reports. Dominium completed 973 appraisals in 1998, which included 20 farms and 9 four plexes and generated $230,662 in revenues. In 1999, 1380 appraisals were completed including 15 farms and 8 four plexes generating gross revenues of $298,225. In 2000, Dominium did 1018 appraisals including 19 farms and 8 four plexes realizing gross revenues of $212,506.94.

headtext.bold: Reasons Given by Court for Award:

para.paratext: Each of the individual Defendants was in breach of a fiduciary duty they owed to their employer APA. Upon the recruitment of Thiem, they gained complete access to all the computer records and programs of APA. With that access, they gained very considerable power to affect the business of their employer. The Defendants could and did unilaterally exercise that power to affect the legal interests of APA by copying and removing business records and systems from APA to assist the operations of Dominium. The actions of each of the individual Defendants constituted a misuse of the confidential information belonging to APA. That information was secretly assembled by the Defendants acting in concert for the specific purpose of facilitating the establishment of Dominium, as a competitor to APA. Dominium applied the APA system “holus bolus” to the conduct of its business from the time that company opened for business to and even after service of the Anton Pillar Order.

Any attempt to award damages to APA for actual losses incurred as a result of the misconduct of the Defendants would be an entirely inappropriate response to their breach of duty. Dominium and the individual Defendant appraisers had been unjustly enriched by their use of the property of APA in competition with that company. The only appropriate remedy in the circumstances was to require those Defendants to disgorge completely the benefit of that unjust enrichment. By misappropriating APA's property, Dominium was clearly in an advantaged position over any other competitor entering the appraisal business in that market. In addition, some portions of the APA property would simply have been unavailable to Dominium. Dominium's ability to perform appraisals in the formats expected by their clients on a prompt basis was fundamentally dependent on the availability of the library of comparables and other information forming part of the APA property. Dominium and its shareholder owners were undoubtedly enriched by the immediate access to the systems and programs of APA and utilization of their library of information. That enrichment was unjust because it resulted from their unlawful taking and conversion of the property of their employer. The Plaintiff was entitled to equitable relief requiring the appraiser Defendants and Dominium to disgorge the benefit flowing from their wrongful acts.

The primary factor to consider was the outright dependence of Dominium upon the APA materials for the establishment of its business. The Defendants could not have created a broad range of comparables for residential properties in all the neighbourhoods of Red Deer and the outlying areas or the library of information contained in the 331 farm files, for anything approaching immediate use by Dominium. Dominium simply would not have been in a position to deliver a quick return of appraisal work without access to extensive and relevant comparables which form a key component particularly to residential appraisals. The strong initial success of the business of Dominium would have been severely compromised had the wrongful conversion of APA confidential information not occurred. Accordingly, the benefit of the confidential property of APA to the Dominium business had been very substantial. The totality of the APA systems and libraries was indeed of the “very special” variety of confidential information because without access to it, Dominium could not have been an effective competitor to APA. The utilization by Dominium of all the confidential information of APA was fundamentally responsible for the initial and continued success of Dominium's appraisal business. It was the almost immediate creation of a prompt reliable competitor to APA which allowed Dominium to take advantage of the appraisal boom beginning in mid 1998 and accelerating in 1999. Dominium's ability to hit the ground running through the appropriation of APA property was critical to the success enjoyed by the Defendants.

Approximately 75% of the income generated by Dominium in the first four months of its operation should be considered a benefit to be regurgitated. Approximately 50% of the revenues generated by Dominium for the next six month period should also be considered to be a benefit to be regurgitated. The ability of Dominium to perform more than half of the appraisals they did actually undertake would have been severely constrained by the lack of the library of comparables and other data and the necessary time which would have had to be expended in the research efforts for appraisals undertaken. Finally, an additional 25% of the income generated by Dominium of the next six months of its operation should also be considered to be a benefit to be regurgitated. While the Dominium data bank would have been developing to a much greater extent in this time frame through the actual experiences of Dominium in appraisal and the program of research through MLS, some restrictions in the company's ability to perform appraisal work at the volume actually undertaken would necessarily continue. By calculating the number of appraisals ordered in each month as a percentage of the total number of appraisals completed in the relevant year, the Court could reach an approximate determination of the percentage of gross income generated in each of the periods identified by the Court. That percentage was applied to the gross revenue for the relevant year to identify the approximate gross revenue for each period. By then applying the appropriate percentage of earnings to be regurgitated, in each of the respective periods, the approximate total of the earnings to be regurgitated, being the total of this benefit unjustly received by Dominium could be determined. In addition Dominium and the appraiser Defendants benefited by the savings of the cost of generation of most of the computer systems and reference libraries during that period. That cost was at least $10,000 which must be included in the global figure of damages awarded. An award of $150,000 was the fair and equitable compensation required to redress the wrongful acts of Dominium and the appraiser Defendants.

headtext.bold: McCormick Delisle & Thompson Inc. v. Ballantyne

head.headtext: McCormick Delisle & Thompson Inc. v. Ballantyne, 2001 CarswellOnt 1603, 12 B.L.R. (3d) 257, 9 C.C.E.L. (3d) 50, 145 O.A.C. 379, 2001 C.L.L.C. 210-034 (Ont. C.A.), leave to appeal to S.C.C. refused 2001 CarswellOnt 3613

para.paratext: Trial judgment varied to substitute for the damage award the sum of $260,000.

The plaintiff appealed from the decision awarding damages in favour of the appellant in the amount of $30,324 against all of the respondents jointly and severally for breach of fiduciary duty and/or breach of employee duty not to exploit confidential information obtained during the course of employment on the issue of damages alone.

The appellant was a management consulting firm. It provided services primarily to clients in the manufacturing industry in order to assist them in changing the method by which they manufacture their products. Because of the nature of the service the appellant provided, its relationships with prospective clients often required a twelve to nineteen month “maturing period” before a customer was secured and actual invoicing was done. Once a customer had been secured, 90% of the work was performed in the field by specialized service providers who were responsible for bringing about changes to the manufacturing process.

During the late spring and early summer of 1996, the three individual respondents were negotiating with the appellant in an attempt to buy into the company as equity partners. Negotiations eventually broke down and on September 9, 1996, the three individual respondents collectively agreed that they would go into business together, in a field similar to that occupied by the appellant. By December 23, 1996, all of the individual respondents had left the appellant's employ. The very next day, they incorporated the respondent Process Impact Inc. and delivered two proposals to two very substantial customers of the plaintiff.

headtext.bold: Reasons Given by Court for Award:

para.paratext: The trial judge found that each of the individual respondents had a fiduciary duty to the appellant and a concurrent duty, within or without the fiduciary relationship, not to exploit confidential information obtained in the course of their employment to the detriment of the appellant. The trial judge further found that the individual respondents had breached their duties. Finally, the judge found that the company formed by the individual respondents for the sole purpose of exploiting confidential information was equally liable to the appellant.

The trial judge concluded that the damages for which the respondents were responsible should be calculated on the basis of a twelve-month period from January 1, 1997 up to and including December 31, 1997, which he referred to as being at the “far end of the usual range.” The start date was chosen on the basis that no money was actually siphoned off from the appellant until the end of December 1996, and there was no hard evidence of blatant solicitation prior to December. In order to calculate the actual net loss of the appellant during the relevant period, the trial judge began by setting the gross loss of income to December 31, 1997 at $249,585. The trial judge chose to take the appellant's usual profit margin and apply it to the numbers generated in the first step of the analysis. The most attractive profit margin from the appellant's perspective was determined by the trial judge to be the 16.2% achieved in 1996. The trial judge arrived at a loss, before contingencies, of $40,432.00. Recognizing that “it may be somewhat, the trial judge assigned 25% and reduced the figure to $30,324.00.

The approach of the trial judge to the issue of damages was flawed. This was a case of three employees who, in egregious breach of their duties to their employer, secretly solicited contracts from the most attractive of their employer's clientele while they were still in its employ. Whether a twelve-month grace period was appropriate or whether some other figure was called for was a moot issue. Based on the respondents' use of confidential information obtained during the course of their employment, as well as their solicitation of some of the appellant's clientele before their departure, no length of post-departure grace period would have protected the appellant from the consequences of the misconduct of these employees. In fact, the loss of clientele suffered by the appellant as a result of the respondents' breach of duties almost put the appellant out of business.

It was significant that the four specific contracts in issue were not terminated prematurely and only came to an end after the completion of the respective projects by the appellant's former personnel. In the case of GSW, this took three years, for Sowa it was two years, for Quadro one year, and for Hauser one year. Accordingly, the trial judge erred in restricting the period of lost sales to twelve months. Having found that this conduct of the respondent employees was in breach of their respective fiduciary duties and/or their common law duties to their employer, the trial judge should have treated the four contracts in issue as having been misappropriated by the respondents and should have awarded the value of the lost contracts to the appellant as damages.

Based on contracts with GSW, Hauser, Sowa and Quadro, the respondents earned gross revenues of $530,960.00 in the two years following their departure, while the appellant's gross sales dropped by $590,000.00 during the first thirteen months post-departure. In addition, the appellant, which had recorded positive net earnings of $152,000.00 before tax in 1997, suffered a net loss before taxes of $136,000.00 in 1998, a swing of almost $300,000.00. These figures revealed the patent error of the trial judge's finding that the quantum of the appellant's loss was a mere $30,324.

There was no reason why the appellant should not be compensated for its loss of the four clients' contracts taken by the respondents upon leaving the appellant's employment. The respondents appropriated the contracts of two major customers (GSW and Hauser) and solicited two smaller contracts from customers who were in receipt of proposals by the appellant (Sowa and Quadro). In doing so, they also appropriated the effort and expenses laid out by the appellant during months of what appellant's counsel described as “wooing the client”, for which the appellant received nothing. Those costs were absorbed in the appellant's overall administrative costs that, on the evidence, continued without significant change during the period covered by the contracts in issue. In the normal course, these administrative costs would have been recovered by the billings for the work done on the job. Accordingly, what the appellant lost was the revenues that were to be generated from these contracts. Its only savings were the expenses of the personnel on the job and any commissions that would have been payable for securing the contracts. To suggest that the appellant should deduct from its claim for damages a factor for general overhead expenses would be to accept that the appellant should be penalized twice.

The court also disagreed with the 25% contingency deduction applied by the trial judge. When the damages claim is treated as a misappropriation of four specific customers who had been persuaded to, and did in fact, reorganize their businesses, there should be no such arbitrary across the board deduction.

headtext.bold: Success Realty & Insurance Ltd. v. Metrotown Insurance Services (Vancouver) Ltd.

head.headtext: Success Realty & Insurance Ltd. v. Metrotown Insurance Services (Vancouver) Ltd., 2001 CarswellBC 1065, 2001 BCPC 101 (B.C.P.C.)

para.paratext: The claimant was entitled to a payment order for $7,123 against Lau and Metrotown Vancouver jointly and severally.

Success operated an insurance agency. Lau was employed by Success as an insurance sales person for a period of about four years to August 1996. There was no written employment agreement between the parties. Success had a master customer list of all clients serviced by its sales agents. Each sales agent had his or her own client list but was not privy to the master list containing confidential customer information. In August 1996 Lau resigned from his position. Lau was not a manager of Success or a key employee at the time of his resignation. After Lau's departure, a number of Success' customers were starting to transfer their business to another agency. Success received written notices from Metrotown Insurance which showed a consistent pattern of files on which Lau had been a representative now being written up by Metrotown Insurance. Success' customer list regarding Lau's portfolio had disappeared from the office.

headtext.bold: Reasons Given by Court for Award:

para.paratext: Lau was not a senior or key employee. He owed no fiduciary duties to his former employer upon the termination of his employment. He did, however, owe a duty of good faith and fair dealing both during and after the end of his employment relationship with the Claimant, Success.

Metrotown Vancouver, through its agent and director, William So, acquired confidential information that was the property of Success. William So used that information to unfairly solicit Success customers. Lau was the only plausible link between the confidential Success documents found in Metrotown Vancouver's possession and their ultimate use by William So in his solicitations of Success customers. The bundle of documents in Metrotown Vancouver's possession comprising of Success policies or their client's applications for insurance came into Metrotown Vancouver's possession through Lau and were the likely source from which client solicitation occurred. Lau acted as a referral source to Metrotown Vancouver either directly or indirectly. He provided confidential information to them. In doing so, he breached his duty of good faith owed to his former employer, Success.

Metrotown Vancouver, though its manager and director, William So, did knowingly and wrongfully obtain and use confidential Success documents to solicit business, which caused Success economic harm. William So, as director and Manager of Metrotown Vancouver, knowingly and wrongfully used confidential Success documents to target Success customers with a view to inducing them to place their renewal policies with Metrotown Vancouver.

Any calculation of damages must consider some attrition due to personal loyalty of some customers to Lau, some redundancy or inaccuracy in the client lists, and the net loss to Success after factoring in the cost of doing business in writing up the policies and partial sharing of commissions.

The court accepted a factor of 2.0 for the general lines, for $9,300 in round figures. A multiplier of 1.0 should be used for the autoplan business for a total of $3,364. The total was $12,664. The Gross figure of $12,664 was an appropriate starting point for assessing damages. From this figure, there was to be a 25% deduction due to natural attrition or customer loyalty to Lau, leaving $9,498. The remaining gross amount should be further reduced to reflect some cost of business or shared commissions, which was assessed at 25%. This resulted in a final award of $7,123.

headtext.bold: Cadbury Schweppes Inc. v. FBI Foods Ltd.

head.headtext: Cadbury Schweppes Inc. v. FBI Foods Ltd., 1999 CarswellBC 77, 167 D.L.R. (4th) 577, 83 C.P.R. (3d) 289, 59 B.C.L.R. (3d) 1, [1999] 5 W.W.R. 751, [1999] 1 S.C.R. 142, [2000] F.S.R. 491, 1999 CarswellBC 78, [1999] S.C.J. No. 6 (S.C.C.)

para.paratext: The Referee was directed to calculate the amount of compensation required to restore to the respondents what the respondents had lost as a result of the appellants' breach of confidence.
The period of calculation was to be restricted to the 12-month period commencing April 15, 1983.

The appellants and their predecessors manufactured Clamato juice under licence from the respondents. The respondents terminated the licence effective April 15, 1983. The courts below concluded that thereafter the appellants misused confidential information related to the Clamato recipe obtained during the licence period to continue to manufacture a rival tomato-based drink. Liability for breach of confidence was no longer contested.

In 1982, the respondent Cadbury Schweppes acquired the shares of Duffy-Mott and, in a switch of business strategy, decided that Duffy-Mott would take back the production and marketing of Clamato in Canada. It notified Caesar Canning on April 15, 1982 that the Licence Agreement (and consequently the sub-agreement with FBI Foods) would terminate in 12 months.

The Licence Agreement left Caesar Canning, and therefore FBI Foods, free to compete with the respondent in the juice market after termination. The Licence Agreement provided only that Caesar Canning would not, for a period of five years, manufacture or distribute any product “which includes among its ingredients clam juice and tomato juice”. Caesar Canning immediately began work to develop a competing product, utilizing the formula and process information about Clamato. Caesar Canning could have developed a product as much like Clamato as Caesar Cocktail without using the Clamato recipe by hiring the appropriate skills. It could have done so within the 12-month notice period at modest cost. Caesar Cocktail went on the market immediately after the licensing agreement terminated on April 15, 1983. Unbeknownst to the appellants, the respondents had surreptitiously discovered the exact formula of Caesar Cocktail at the end of March 1983 by slipping a technical expert onto the team for the final financial audit of Caesar Canning under the Licence Agreement. Despite this knowledge, the respondents did not take any action to enjoin the manufacture and sale of Caesar Cocktail, or otherwise protest. The respondents mistakenly believed that the absence of clam broth in the reformulated recipe would be fatal to their claim. Caesar Canning ran into serious financial problems, ceased production on October 23, 1985, and shortly thereafter made an assignment in bankruptcy.

headtext.bold: Reasons Given by Court for Award:

para.paratext: The respondents obtained from the British Columbia Court of Appeal a permanent injunction against continued use of the confidential information, or products derived therefrom, plus an award of compensation equivalent to the profits the respondents would have earned had they in fact sold an additional volume of Clamato equivalent to the sales of Caesar Cocktail during the 12-month period following termination of the licence.

This was a case of third party liability. The appellants did not receive the confidence from the respondents, but from the now defunct Caesar Canning with the knowledge that its use was to be confined to the purpose for which the information was provided, namely the manufacture of Clamato under licence.

The licensing arrangement expressly contemplated open competition upon termination, subject for a period of five years to avoidance of what came to be recognized as a useless limitation, namely mixing clam broth with tomato juice. While the law will supplement the contractual relationship by importing a duty not to misuse confidential information, there was nothing special in this case to elevate the breached duty to one of a fiduciary character.

Nothing is said expressly in the Licence Agreement or Tolling Agreement about confidentiality. There was no privity of contract between the appellants and the respondents. The only party with whom Duffy-Mott had a contract was Caesar Canning, now bankrupt.

The respondents did not bargain for the unfair competition of having their own know-how, imparted in confidence, used against them. The contract cannot reasonably be read as negating the duty of confidence imposed by law.

The Clamato formula and related processes, insofar as they had been disclosed to the appellants, constituted a unique combination of elements, notwithstanding that some or all of the constituent elements were themselves widely known within the juice industry. This was a case of unauthorized use as opposed to unauthorized disclosure. The information passed to Caesar Canning was found to satisfy the requirements of being inaccessible to the uninitiated, and to constitute an identifiable and distinct source of information which Caesar Canning wrongfully used for its own commercial advantage.

The respondents' “lost opportunity” was that the appellants, using these confidential production techniques, entered the marketplace with Caesar Cocktail a year earlier than would otherwise have been the case. The respondents were not entitled to be free of competition from the appellants. Apart from the clam juice limitation, they were only entitled to be free of the appellants' competition which used the respondents' confidential information. A consultant skilled in the art and deploying a variety of techniques could have come up with a plausible clam-free copycat product within 12 months to bring the respondents' commercial “opportunity” to a close.

The trial judge acknowledged that the breached confidences had acted as a “springboard” to enable the appellants to bring Caesar Cocktail to market 12 months earlier than would otherwise have been the case.

The unique features of the respondents' manufacturing process, and its alleged lack of replicability, do not necessarily establish a causal relationship to a financial loss. The respondents were not in the business of selling information, and the “market value” of the confidential information is not the appropriate measure of compensation. That having been said, the respondents were in the business of exploiting commercial opportunities, and their ability to make a profit from Clamato was limited by the acknowledged entitlement of the appellants to market a similar product without clam juice. The assessment of compensation has therefore to address the value of the lost market opportunity and, in particular, the lost advantage of being able to market Clamato free of the appellants' competition for 12 months, and not be diverted to a valuation of the confidential information itself.

The Court was free to draw inferences from the evidence as to what would likely have happened “but for” the breach. The key to the assessment of equitable compensation was the expected duration of the respondents' “lost opportunity”, i.e., the economic advantage they would have enjoyed after the cancellation of the licence “but for” the breach.

The Court of Appeal was correct to reject the trial judge's “consulting fee” approach. The award would not restore the respondents to the position they would have been in but for the breach. The respondents did not lose a consulting fee. They were not in that business.

However, the British Columbia Court of Appeal erred in being prepared to assume that if Caesar Cocktail had been kept off the market because of its unconscionable origins, the respondents would have filled the void with sales of Clamato juice. The respondents' damages, on this assumption, would be their lost profit on the assumed sales of Clamato juice. This approach makes a number of unjustified assumptions. There was no precise evidence that the sales of Clamato juice were affected by the marketing of Caesar Cocktail, and if so to what extent. The reference directed by the Court of Appeal should continue, but on somewhat modified terms. Firstly, the mandate is to assess the loss attributable to the breach of confidence, if any, sustained by the respondents during the 12-month period following the termination. Secondly, the compensable period is the 12 months following termination. The Court of Appeal was correct to start the compensable period on April 15, 1983. The trial judge found that the competition would have ceased to be unfair once the appellants could reasonably have been expected to come up with a tomato juice product independently of the confidential information. The trial judge fixed that period at 12 months. Thirdly, the Referee may think it proper to have regard to the “other market factors” mentioned in the American Restatement. It must be remembered that, at the time of the termination, Caesar Canning and FBI Foods had built up a business infrastructure to which the respondents denied themselves access by their notice of termination, and which the appellants were perfectly entitled to utilize to advance their own economic interests thereafter. If in fact the sales of Clamato dropped in the 12 months following termination, as appears to be the case, it may be that at least some of the drop was caused by the self-inflicted deprivation of this business infrastructure, and was not causally related to the existence of Caesar Cocktail. Fourthly, the assessment of the respondents' loss of profit may include consideration of the royalties otherwise payable under the Licence Agreement for the 12-month compensable period. Fifthly, the Referee will have to keep in mind that the objective is a broadly equitable result. Mathematical exactitude is neither required nor obtainable

headtext.bold: Ben-Israel v. Vitacare Medical Products Inc.

head.headtext: Ben-Israel v. Vitacare Medical Products Inc., 1999 CarswellOnt 1885, 122 O.A.C. 57, 87 C.P.R. (3d) 518 (Ont. C.A.); varying 1997 CarswellOnt 4418, 78 C.P.R. (3d) 94, [1997] O.J. No. 4540 (Ont. C.J. [Gen. Div.])

para.paratext: Damages of $112,500
The appeal was allowed and the judgment below awarding damages in the amount of $263,810 was varied by reducing the damages award against Vitacare by the following amounts:
This was an action to recover damages for breach of contract, breach of confidence and breach of fiduciary duty, in the context of an arms-length, commercial customer/manufacturer relationship.
The information in question was the design of the pillow and the insert, as well as the customer list, quantities and pricing of the plaintiff's pillow.

The only use to which the defendants were entitled to put the plaintiff's information was the manufacture of the pillow for the plaintiff. In this role, the defendants were under a “special disability” with regard to the use of that information, in order to prevent them from doing exactly what they did—get an unfair start in the market, and use the information to the detriment of the plaintiff who supplied the information.

The defendants received confidential information, imparted in circumstances of confidence, and used it as a springboard to produce and sell their own product. They used the plaintiff's pillow and the information and layout of his insert, both of which had taken time, effort, research and money to develop. They also knew who his customers were, and that he had opened up the mass-merchandiser market for therapeutic pillows. They had a good idea of the quantity the plaintiff was selling, to whom, and at what price, because of orders placed with them. This information was used to the detriment of the plaintiff, as Vitacare's pillow was sold to the plaintiff's customers, and efforts were made to sell to more of the plaintiff's customers, at prices known to Vitacare to be lower than the plaintiff's, thus reducing his share of the market, reducing his profits and jeopardizing his business. It bears repetition that the defendants' pillow, without reasonable explanation, was virtually identical in colour scheme, printed material, design and packaging.

The plaintiff elected to claim for damages alone, as opposed to an injunction against the defendants, or an accounting of their profits. Regardless of whether the breach is one of contract, duty of confidence or fiduciary duty, the appropriate and available remedy was damages. The plaintiff should be restored to the position he would have been in had the breach not occurred.

A breach of contract and a breach of the duty of confidence did occur, regarding the defendant's competition with the plaintiff's therapeutic foam pillow, and their use of the plaintiff's confidential information. Damages were awarded in the amount of $263,810

headtext.bold: Reasons Given by Court for Award:

para.paratext: The court had serious doubts that this information, or at least a substantial part of it, was confidential. However, in view of the conclusion that Vitacare was liable for breach of the non-competition agreement and the conclusions with respect to the issues of damages, there was no practical consequence to the trial judge's finding that Vitacare also breached a duty of confidence. As a result, it was not necessary to address this ground of appeal.

In compensating the respondent for the breach of the non-competition agreement and for the breach of the duty of confidence, the trial judge awarded damages based on the respondent's loss of profit for the years 1990, 1991 and 1992 in the amount of $56,250 per year. The trial judge's calculation of the loss of profit was based on figures for sales, revenues and costs provided by the respondent. Many of these figures were unsupported by documentary evidence and there was difficulty in reconciling certain of the projected and actual sales figures. That said, an assessment of damages will often, by necessity, involve some speculation and estimate. In calculating the respondent's loss of profit the trial judge made two reversible errors. First, he should not have included an award for the loss of profit for 1990. He awarded damages on the basis of lost sales of 7,500 pillows annually. This figure was based on projected annual sales of 10,000 pillows and actual sales of approximately 2,500. However, in 1990, the respondent sold over 11,000 pillows which were more than he had ever sold before. Simply put, there was no evidence of lost sales in 1990. The 1990 loss of profit was not proved. The damage award was reduced by the amount of $56,250, being the loss of profit awarded for 1990.

The second error with the award for the loss of profit relates to an adjustment made by the trial judge for the impact of increased competition on the respondent's sales. The trial judge misunderstood the respondent's evidence to be that the loss of profit from lost pillow sales was $63,750 per year. In fact, the respondent's evidence was that the loss of profit from lost sales was $56,250 per year. The court therefore reduced the award for the loss of profit from the loss of sales for the years 1991 and 1992 by $7,500 for each year.

In regard to the finding that Vitacare breached a duty of confidence, the trial judge awarded $75,000 as a fee to compensate the respondent for his time and effort in developing his pillow. The trial judge stated that a figure between $50,000 and $100,000 would be a reasonable consulting fee had Vitacare hired someone to develop the pillow. He then awarded $75,000. There was no evidence to support this award. The respondent did not provide an accounting of his time and expenses, nor did he claim a specific figure or put forward an estimate upon which the court could base this award. The respondent did not call any evidence as to what a consultant's fee would have been. The trial judge erred in awarding damages in the absence of evidence to support this claim.

Moreover, the award of damages for the respondent's loss of profit was intended to put the respondent in the same position that he would have been in had Vitacare not breached the duty of confidence. Expenses incurred in developing the pillow would have been incurred whether or not there had been a breach. Those expenses were necessary to enable the respondent to earn the profits that he actually realized and to earn the profits for which he is being compensated by the award of damages. An additional award to compensate for development expenses would constitute a windfall or double recovery. In addition, there is no evidence to suggest that the respondent's design had any value to Vitacare other than in connection with the sales of its pillow that form the basis of the award for the loss of profit. For the same reason, the trial judge also erred in awarding the respondent damages in the amount of $5,060 to compensate him for the design of the pillow insert.

headtext.bold: Sweet Factory Inc. v. Hudson's Bay Co.

head.headtext: Sweet Factory Inc. v. Hudson's Bay Co., 1998 CarswellOnt 5273, 85 C.P.R. (3d) 417 (Ont. C.J. [Gen. Div.]) [Reasons for decision on liability]; Sweet Factory Inc. v. Hudson's Bay Co., 1999 CarswellOnt 347, 86 C.P.R. (3d) 417 (Ont. C.J. [Gen. Div.]), supp. reasons 1999 CarswellOnt 2026 [Reasons for decision on damages]

para.paratext: Damages assessed at $511,783
Punitive damages in the sum of $200,000
The Sweet Factory concept involved candy displayed in modern design acrylic tubes, and the use of colour gradation, the candy being purchased by weight for a set price.
A confidentiality agreement was executed by both parties. Documentation or information was provided to the representatives of the Hudson's Bay.

The areas of information supplied to the Bay were, having regard to the terms of the confidentiality agreement, confidential or proprietary. Further, considering all the negotiations and discussions with Hudson's Bay, the uniqueness of the S.F. concept and the terms of the confidentiality agreement, the plaintiff demonstrated that the items of information were supplied to the Hudson's Bay in circumstances in which an obligation of confidence arose. The overall concept of the store, and the operation of merchandising bulk candy in the fashion in which it was done in both stores, the Candy Lab store was very similar to that of the Sweet Factory concept, and the total package was based on the use and misuse of confidential information supplied to Hudson's Bay, and its unauthorized use violated the confidential agreement and breached Ontario law. The main reason why HBC able to and in fact did put into operation the number of Candy Lab Stores in 1989 that it did was the available information it had from the plaintiff.

headtext.bold: Reasons Given by Court for Award:

para.paratext: There was a duty on the Bay to act in good faith and that duty was breached by the Bay in attempting to obtain all of the useful information and documents with respect to the Sweet Factory concept. Considering the background of the dealings between the parties, the various discussions and negotiations which had taken place, terminating in the business agreement which took place in December, that a fiduciary relationship arose, and there was therefore a fiduciary duty on the Hudson's Bay to disclose to Sweet Factory that they intended to do the candy concepts themselves, and to take the sites which had been discussed and agreed upon. In the opening up and operation of the several Candy Lab stores in 1989 the H.B.C. breached its fiduciary duty to the plaintiff by making unauthorized use and/or misuse of confidential information supplied to it during discussions and negotiations which took place in 1988 and 1989, and plaintiff was thereby entitled to damages from the defendant.
The stores and kiosks were closed in 1990. A decision was made in the early 1990s to close down the Candy Lab operation.

Considering that there was the element of necessary profitability after the first year as to whether or not there would be ten new stores opened in the second year, the approach as expressed in Alternative B was a more appropriate and reasonable basis to assess the damages of the plaintiff and he plaintiff's damages were assessed at $511,783.

headtext.bold: Apotex Fermentation Inc. v. Novopharm Ltd.

head.headtext: Apotex Fermentation Inc. v. Novopharm Ltd., 1998 CarswellMan 318, 162 D.L.R. (4th) 111, 80 C.P.R. (3d) 449, 129 Man. R. (2d) 161, 180 W.A.C. 161, [1998] 10 W.W.R. 455, 42 C.C.L.T. (2d) 133 (Man. C.A.)

para.paratext: Compensatory damages of $3,718,369.
The cross-appeal by Apotex with respect to the duration of the permanent injunction was allowed, and it was extended by an additional 19 months to July 31, 1999.

The trial judge found that Dahiya brought over to the appellant Novopharm technology that he had developed for the respondent Apotex for making Lovastatin, a “miracle” anti-cholesterol drug with an international market potential in the billions of dollars. Dahiya misappropriated Apotex's comprehensive process, thereby committing a breach of confidence and breach of fiduciary duty, and Novopharm was liable for Dahiya's conduct. Compensatory damages were awarded against Novopharm and Dahiya in the amount of $3.718 million being the cost to Apotex of its Lovastatin project up to the time Dahiya joined Novopharm in October 1991.

In 1988, Apotex became interested in Lovastatin amongst other drugs. Worldwide sales of Lovastatin were expected to amount to billions of dollars annually, with Canadian sales estimated at $100 million annually. As a result of its interest in Lovastatin, Apotex entered into a research agreement with ABI Biotechnology Inc. In June of 1988, Dahiya commenced employment with ABI as a scientist. When Dahiya left AFI he took with him documents belonging to AFI and relating to the technology which had been developed. ABI's strain selection and improvement work on A. terreus was a significant undertaking. There was no evidence that Dahiya subsequently developed a process independent of what he had learned at ABI.

The trial judge concluded that the fermentation conditions used at ABI were basic but remained a trade secret; the extraction process used at ABI was a trade secret; Novopharm was vicariously liable for the acts of Dahiya; Apotex was entitled to compensatory damages in the sum of $3,718,369 representing the total cost of ABI's Lovastatin project up to the time Dahiya left ABI; and the interlocutory injunction against Dahiya and Novopharm prohibiting Novopharm from performing any research or other activities relating to the production of Lovastatin (and certain other drugs) was made permanent until December 31, 1997.
The trial judge found Novopharm liable for breach of confidence and breach of trust of its employee Dahiya since he was acting within the scope of his employment.

headtext.bold: Reasons Given by Court for Award:

para.paratext: The facts demonstrated clearly and unequivocally actual knowledge on the part of Novopharm and its senior officials of Dahiya's misconduct.

The trial judge adopted the loss of investment/cost approach to damages. The trial judge rejected Novopharm's argument that Apotex's unprotected technology had no value. The evidence overwhelmingly supported his finding.

Canadian jurisprudence identifying research and development costs as an appropriate measure of damages in misappropriation of trade secrets cases is sparse. However, in ICAM Technologies Corp. v. EBCO Industries Ltd. (1991), 36 C.P.R. (3d) 504 (B.C. S.C.), Maczko J. concluded that the development costs incurred by the plaintiff in acquiring its confidential information was an appropriate factor to consider in calculating damages for the defendant's breach of confidence.

The commercial setting of Apotex's loss of technology, the likely future consequences of the misappropriation, and the nature and extent of the use Novopharm put the trade secrets to after the misappropriation support the application of the cost approach to the assessment of Apotex's damages. The trial judge was correct in applying the cost approach, and in using Apotex's actual costs in calculating the costs saved by Novopharm as a complete measure of damages.

headtext.bold: Planon Systems Inc. v. Norman Wade Co.

head.headtext: Planon Systems Inc. v. Norman Wade Co., 1998 CarswellOnt 3437, [1998] O.J. No. 3547 (Ont. C.J. [General Division])

para.paratext: In view of the lack of information on Wade's actual sales prices, damages were determined in the total amount of $1,148,000 plus $172,800 in punitive damages, but this award was subject to any further submissions which the parties might make within 30 days as to whether, on the basis of the evidence received at trial and the relevant law, an assessment procedure should be ordered to determine the amount of the damages per se, including any formula or terms that were proposed.
This was a proceeding under the Companies' Creditors Arrangement Act to determine the validity and amount of the claims made by Planon against Wade in the reorganization of Wade under the CCAA.

In the early 1980's, Planon supplied filing cabinets to Wade for resale by it. In April 1985, Wade advised Planon that because of product deficiencies Wade would terminate their arrangement unless the deficiencies were overcome. Wade indicated to Planon it should retain a Montreal industrial designer, M to redesign the unit consisting of the filing mechanism and its cabinet. Wade advised that the product was not satisfactory and the agreement was cancelled as was an outstanding purchase order. Following the termination letter, Wade ordered product from Planon for resale and also arranged with M to design a unit for it which was designed to be competitive with the Planon product. Subsequently, Wade cancelled orders it had placed with Planon and refused to pay for invoiced units on grounds of deficiencies. Wade introduced into the market its own filing cabinet unit designed by M. Planon's business declined and a few years later Planon went out of business.

headtext.bold: Reasons Given by Court for Award:

para.paratext: Planon communicated information to Wade that, having regard to the business circumstances of the communication, had to be regarded as confidential and as intended to be kept confidential. Planon's communications with Wade that involved confidential information were made for the purpose of restoring its supply agreement with Wade. Planon gave to Wade the key confidential information that Planon had retained M to design its new system and that M had designed the system which was demonstrated to Wade's representatives on May 21, 1985.

Planon was entitled to damages from Wade in respect of the design claim. Wade was liable to Planon for breach of its duty of confidentiality. Wade was also liable for inducing breach by M of his duty of confidentiality. The liability of Wade was liability in tort. In consequence Wade was liable for the loss caused by its tortuous conduct to the extent that that loss was foreseeable. It was foreseeable that as a result of selling units of its own manufacture produced with the use of the designs made by M (as opposed to units which could have been made and supplied by Planon), Wade would cause a reduction in the sales that Planon would otherwise have been able to make. The loss of Wade's business was an important contributing factor, probably the most important contributing factor, to the eventual collapse of Planon's business.

The breach of the duty of confidentiality enabled Wade to itself produce and sell units of the type that it would otherwise have had to acquire from Planon. This inevitably directly affected Planon's sales adversely, and must be regarded as a principal cause of the collapse of the Planon business. The loss to the Plaintiff must be considered to be in the same order of magnitude as the profits to Wade.

Planon provided financial information about Wade's business to March 1996. Planon's calculations show a profit over the period to Wade of $1,640,000 assuming that Wade was able to sell units at full list price. The profit that could be attributed to sales of units at a 20% discount would be 70% (i.e. 1.4 divided by 2) of the full profit amount. This 70% factor could then be applied to the profit amount of $1,640,000 to yield a net amount of $1,148,000 as the reasonably presumable profit of Wade attributable to the sales of the units and therefore as reasonably representing the profit lost to Planon on such sales.

headtext.bold: Walter Stewart Realty Ltd. v. Traber

head.headtext: Walter Stewart Realty Ltd. v. Traber, 1995 CarswellAlta 236, 31 Alta. L.R. (3d) 162, [1995] 9 W.W.R. 593, 174 A.R. 45, 102 W.A.C. 45 (Alta. C.A.), additional reasons 1995 CarswellAlta 441

para.paratext: 30 per cent of the profit of the subdivision before tax
After finding that the respondent, Traber had breached the confidence of the appellant, the trial judge awarded the appellant 15 per cent of the profits of the subdivision before tax.

S was put in touch with the respondent Traber as a potential financier of the project. He extracted a promise from Traber to keep secret and confidential the information he was about to disclose. The details of the joint venture were disputed at trial, although the general concept of a joint venture and the discussion of 30 per cent were accepted.

By the time of the actual transfer of the subject lands, Traber and S had encountered difficulties in the Stafford joint venture. The subject property was transferred at Traber's instructions, and without the knowledge of S, into the name of his family holding company, the respondent Quintra Development Ltd., rather than the newly incorporated company Bel-Aire, which the appellant alleged was the intended recipient of the land. This occurred in June 1989, and since that date Traber had total control of the project and S received no compensation.

headtext.bold: Reasons Given by Court for Award:

para.paratext: The trial judge found the following: a) There was no joint venture agreement ever finalized; b) The respondents did not owe a fiduciary duty to the appellant, but did owe a duty of confidentiality and breached that duty; c) Damages were to be assessed on the basis that the appellant was entitled to be restored to the position he would have been in had there been no wrong, which he held to be best accomplished by an award of a percentage of the profits. He determined the appropriate percentage to be 15 per cent.

The findings of the trial judge were fully supported by the facts, with the exception of his assessment of damages at 15 per cent share of the profits. Accepting his approach to the method of calculating damages, he erred in not awarding the full 30 per cent of the profits as damages.

There was no error in the approach taken by the trial judge in awarding a percentage of profits. The real issue was whether the figure of 15 per cent was appropriate. Unfortunately, the trial judge did not share his reasons for selecting the 15 per cent figure, and there was rational connection of the reduction of the percentage to any reduced obligation under any joint venture.

The trial judge accepted that had the parties been able to agree on the outstanding items of the joint venture, 30 per cent was the percentage these two arm's length parties had negotiated as a fair split of profits. That percentage was to be the bonus for S's part in bringing and completing the land deal. It was, in essence, the finder's fee for the transaction. The trial judge failed to appreciate that the other obligations contemplated were to be compensated, albeit the exact terms of the compensation had not been agreed. The evidence was overwhelming that the general terms of negotiation were that S would be paid for the obligations associated with the development and the sale of lots. The trial judge's decision to reduce by one-half the amount of the profit figure these parties had agreed to as a reasonable compensation on the basis that that figure contemplated full participation in the joint venture was unreasonable. There was no evidence to support the conclusion that a full participation would have placed a burden on the appellant that would not have been more than compensated. Rather, the evidence would indicate that had a joint venture been in force the appellant would have had the opportunity to earn sales commissions, to earn compensation for development, and to earn a bigger percentage of the profit.

The only reasonable inference was that the 30 per cent was the figure agreed to by the parties as compensation for finding the deal. The best measure of value of the deal was the figure negotiated by the parties. The fact that the balance of the items were not agreed to did not change the validity of the percentage figure negotiated. It could only be viewed as the figure which these parties were willing to place on the value of the introduction to the deal.

headtext.bold: Franklin Supply Co. v. Midco Supply Co.

head.headtext: Franklin Supply Co. v. Midco Supply Co., 1995 CarswellAlta 308, 33 Alta. L.R. (3d) 362, 172 A.R. 264 (Alta. Q.B.)

para.paratext: General damages of $258,025

For over 20 years prior to 1987 the plaintiff and Midcontinent Supply Co. carried on business as competitors in the oil field supply business in western Canada. All of the individual defendants were in 1987 employees of Midcontinent and had been for varying lengths of time. By agreement dated October 5, 1987 the plaintiff purchased certain of the assets of Midcontinent in Canada and assisted in the disposition of the balance. Shortly before the plaintiff had made offers of employment to all of the Canadian employees of Midcontinent. On closing of the agreement some 35 employees, including all of the individual defendants, joined the defendant Midco Supply Ltd., a previously inactive company, as shareholders and employees, and Midco immediately went into competition with the plaintiff. Shortly after the closing, the plaintiff discovered a large number of documents which ought to have been in the Midcontinent stores where Midco was then operating, were not. The plaintiff then, on October 20, by way of an Anton Pillar order, seized in excess of 500 documents and files from the six locations.

By late 1986 the senior employees of Midcontinent in Canada were aware that their parent company in the U.S. was in serious financial trouble. By early 1987 Al Brandon, the general manager for Canada, and the defendant Daniel Endersby, the operations manager, were discussing their alternatives and Endersby on his own caused the corporate defendant to be incorporated. Endersby had decided by then he would not be joining Franklin and so in early September began to get ready to go and filed an application with the Toronto-Dominion bank for credit, using in part some historical financial records of Midcontinent, broken down by store. These documents comprised individual documents, files, boxes, manuals, and computer printouts, containing, inter alia, financial, customer, producers, supplier and credit information. There were some originals, some file copies, some photocopies. There appears to have been no consistency to what was taken by different employees, some took very little or nothing, others took boxes full. The activities of the Midcontinent employees in September, and the taking of the documents occurred despite the terms of “employee invention trade secret” agreements.

headtext.bold: Reasons Given by Court for Award:

para.paratext: Whether by way of trade secrets agreement signed by the employees or a general duty on the part of the defendants not to misuse confidential information, there had been some misuse of confidential information for which the defendants were liable. However, insofar as such misuse may related to information regarding the customers of Midcontinent, such liability was considerably restricted by the nature of the customer base in the industry in question.

The plaintiff also argued liability could be found on the basis of International Corona Resources Ltd. v. LAC Minerals Ltd., [1989] 2 S.C.R. 574, and subsequent following authorities, but that line of authority seems invariably to involve information passing in a non-employment situation, and it was not particularly helpful to the situation here.

A large number of the documents were of no use to either Franklin or Midco because they related to things like distributorships that had been terminated or represented historical obsolete information. A great many others were of very limited use, such as compilations of information that for the most part was available in the phone book or from industry publications. That was not to say that much of the material was not of a confidential nature, especially recent financial reports and detailed information compiled with regard to customers and suppliers. However, even that sort of material must be considered in light of the nature of the business that Franklin and Midcontinent were in. It was extremely competitive, the customer base in different locations was well known to all who worked in those locations, and over time competitors gained a good insight as to what each other's pricing and discounts were.

White, a C.A., C.B.V. and C.F.A., was qualified as an expert in business evaluations and economic losses. His conclusion was that the best way to measure the losses was to arrive at a determination of what percentage of Midfield's business would have gone to Franklin were it not for the wrongful acts of the defendants. He assumed, among other things, that the actions of the defendants were wrongful as claimed, that Franklin was unable to use the documents seized because of the Anton Pillar order, and that the Scott/Fieger analysis as to the importance of the documents was correct. White concluded that 85%–88% of sales were due to personal relationships and 12%–15% to the lack of availability of documents and the activities of Endersby and others. Applying those percentages to the sales figures for Midfield for the years ending in 1988 and 1989 and adding an ongoing loss at 10% of the 1990 annualized loss with a multiple of 4.5, he arrived at total figures for damages of $1.8M–$2.3M, including pre-judgment interest, up to March 31, 1995.
