The defendants called no evidence to challenge White's methodology or calculations.

The best way to assess Franklin's loss was as a portion of the business the defendants actually got. The question of what portion of the defendants' business is appropriate is more difficult. There was no particular logic to Mr. White's conclusion that it should be 12%–15% over two years and 10% for another four and a half, it was simply his conclusion. Three of his assumptions, namely, that the actions of the defendants were wrongful as claimed, that the plaintiffs were unable to use the documents, and the documents carried the importance as claimed in the Scott/Fieger analysis, were not in accord with the trial judge's findings. It follows that either Mr. White's percentages or time frames, or both, must be significantly reduced. The plaintiff suffered more than nominal damages.

An appropriate basis of calculation would be 8% of the defendants' profits for the first two years of their operation. That would recognize the fact that the defendants, by the way they started their operation, clearly “got the jump” on the plaintiffs, but also takes into account the assumptions of Mr. White that were not supported by the evidence. The profits lost for the first two years of the defendants' operation were shown in Mr. White's report to be $387,038 using 12% as the lost sales percentage. Adjusting the 12% to 8% would give $258,025.

headtext.bold: ICAM Technologies Corp. v. EBCO Industries Ltd.

head.headtext: ICAM Technologies Corp. v. EBCO Industries Ltd., 1993 CarswellBC 322, 85 B.C.L.R. (2d) 318, [1994] 3 W.W.R. 419, 36 B.C.A.C. 298, 58 W.A.C. 298, 52 C.P.R. (3d) 61, 11 B.L.R. (2d) 205 (B.C.C.A.); affirming 1991 CarswellBC 1195, 36 C.P.R. (3d) 504, 6 B.L.R. (2d) 98, [1991] B.C.W.L.D. 1911 (B.C.S.C.)

para.paratext: Damages of $300,000.

The appellant EBCO appealed from a judgment wherein EBCO was found liable for damages for breach of the duty of confidence. The trial judge awarded ICAM $300,000 in damages. EBCO appealed both the finding of liability and the quantum of the award. ICAM cross-appealed seeking to have the award of damages increased to $500,000.

The plaintiffs sought damages from the defendant for breach of confidence. The plaintiffs were two companies (ICAM) that alleged they researched, assembled and presented a concept to create a unique high technology machining facility for modern aeroplane parts. The owner and manager of these companies, Nassr, presented the concept to Eppich, the President of the defendant EBCO and EBCO used Nassr's concept without his consent and without paying compensation.

The dispute revolved around a concept or an idea described as Project Chipmunk. Nassr conceived an idea for the manufacture and marketing of sophisticated aeroplane parts. The parts were primarily designed for new aeroplanes such as the Boeing 747, 757, 767 - 7 - 8 and the new F 18 fighter jet which was about to be manufactured in the United States and sold to Canada. Nassr recognized this new market opportunity and did detailed market research to determine the exact types of parts that would be required and how they would be manufactured. He determined that there was a shortage of machinery capable of manufacturing these parts efficiently and concluded that the machinery with this capability was computer controlled, three spindle, five axis, gantry machines. These machines were very expensive (approximately $2,000,000 each) and had an 18-month to 2-year delivery time.

Project Chipmunk had two main elements: one was the development of a machining centre with the machinery described above and the other was to have a central computing centre which would allow smaller manufacturing companies to have access to a central computer that would control the machinery. The computers and programming were expensive and required considerable expertise. This central system would allow a number of smaller manufacturers into a very expensive business. This second part of the proposal would also provide training in how to use the machines.

The plaintiff and defendant both worked towards a proposal to be presented to the Federal Government. The proposal would be a joint venture and was described as the EBCO-ICAM Project. On January 17th Eppich made an offer to Nassr which was a rough outline of a business proposition. He wrote this out by hand and at this time he was suggesting $500,000 worth of shares for Project Chipmunk which included ICAM, funded by a minimum of $6.1 million of DIPP money. The plaintiff would roll his two companies with their $100,000 profits into the EBCO-ICAM project and this was valued at $500,000 worth of shares. The third item offered to Nassr was an additional $500,000 worth of shares in EBCO-ICAM in recognition of future performance over the next five years based on a minimum cash generation as shown in EBCO's proposals. Eppich and Nassr both concluded that a deal could not be reached and negotiations were ended.
EBCO presented to DIPP its revised application for funding. This application was almost identical to the project developed by the plaintiff and the defendant during December 1980 and January 1981.

It was Nassr who brought the project to EBCO. EBCO had not put together the knowledge of the machines, the market potential and the DIPP grants. They had only general information about each. The information was of significant value to EBCO because they were prepared to pay 1.5 million dollars in shares to the plaintiff, of which $500,000 worth of shares was for the financing portion.

headtext.bold: Reasons Given by Court for Award:

para.paratext: In this type of action the court has great flexibility to fashion a remedy to suit the circumstances. The court has many options which include an injunction, royalties and an accounting for profits or damages.

In assessing damages the court must attempt as far as possible to monetarily restore the plaintiff to the position he would have been in had it not been for the defendant's wrongful conduct. Depending on the position of a particular plaintiff, the damages may be calculated in a number of ways. For example, the appropriate measure may be any one of or a combination of the following considerations: (a) the confider's loss of profit; (b) the value of a consultant's fee; (c) the depreciation and value of information in consequence of a breach of confidence; (d) the development costs incurred in acquiring the information; (e) capitalisation of an appropriate royalty; (f) the market value on information as between a willing buyer and a willing seller. The trial judge concluded that (b), (d) and (f) are the most appropriate factors to consider on the facts. The trial judge excluded (a) because the confider lost no profits and was not in the business of producing anything on which profits could be lost; (c) because there was no evidence of depreciation of value as a consequence of breach of confidence, and (e) because the circumstances in this case did not lend themselves to a royalty. The plaintiff had communicated an idea for getting into a certain type of business rather than the production of a particular product on which royalties could be conveniently calculated. It was anticipated that the defendant would create a new company with new facilities and would manufacture a variety of products. In 1981 when the parties were bargaining over the value of the information it would have been unrealistic to attempt to evaluate a royalty when they were venturing into such unknown territory.

It is difficult, if not impossible, to assess a true market value for the information provided by. Nassr to EBCO because the project was unique. There is some hint of the value in the negotiations between the parties because Eppich offered the plaintiff $500,000 worth of shares in the private company to be formed. When giving evidence Eppich said he did not consider paying cash because the company needed all the cash it could get. Apart from Eppich's evidence it is logical that shares, in a private company to be formed, with all its risks, are not as valuable as cash. Indeed, if the plaintiff had received shares he would be a long time in realizing any income because the company has not yet made a profit and it will not likely produce a profit to the shareholders for some time to come.

Nassr put a great deal of time into the project. Without documentation or specific figures, the trial judge estimated the value of his work at $200,000. Nassr's company should be compensated for the unique idea he brought to EBCO. Fair compensation for the idea was $100,000.

There was ample evidence before the trial judge to support the findings he made, and, with one minor exception, the principles of law that he applied in concluding that, after negotiations had broken down between the parties to enter into a joint venture agreement, EBCO acted in breach of the duty of confidence that it owed to ICAM with respect to confidential information that ICAM supplied to EBCO during the course of those negotiations.

The trial judge seems to have concluded that the “value of a consultant's fee”, the “market value of information, as between a willing buyer and willing seller”, and “development costs incurred in acquiring the information” were all factors to be considered in measuring the plaintiffs' damages on the facts as established before him. Although any one of those three measures may have been used, it would be an error to use more than one. The plaintiff was entitled to be restored to his pre-loss position, and no more.

In valuing that loss, the person wronged is entitled to have damages assessed on the basis most favourable to himself. In this particular case, the market value of the information, as between a willing buyer and willing seller, will produce the most favourable result for the plaintiffs ICAM. The willing buyer and willing seller method was precisely what the trial judge was attempting to articulate in the balance of his reasons for judgment.

What the trial judge did was look first at EBCO's position. In the negotiating stage Eppich committed his thoughts in handwriting which ultimately formed the basis for EBCO's final proposal to ICAM and Nassr for the proposed joint venture. There were three components making up the consideration of 1.5 million dollars worth of shares in the joint venture company to be formed. The first was $500,000 worth of shares for Project Chipmunk. Secondly, there was $500,000 of shares for ICAM to roll its computer consulting business into the joint venture and, thirdly, $500,000 worth of shares for Nassr's personal continued participation in the project for an additional five years.

As the trial judge remarked, he found a hint of the true market value of the information provided because Nassr had provided $500,000 worth of shares for it. In this portion of his analysis of the willing buyer assessment, the trial judge correctly observed that shares in a private company are not as valuable as cash. He did not articulate what he considered a reasonable discount for cash would be.

Then the trial judge turned his attention to the only other evidence there was pertaining to what a willing seller would accept. Firstly, he considered whether Nassr might have accepted a consultant's fee under the circumstances. It does not appear that the trial judge made any assessment on such a basis and such a measure of the plaintiffs' damages would not have been appropriate. Secondly, the trial judge considered a claim advanced by Nassr for $300,000 worth of management staff-time and travel expenses incurred by Nassr and his companies in creating Project Chipmunk, which primarily represented all the time expended by Nassr on the project, commencing in the years 1978, 1979 and through the full year 1980. The trial judge considered this estimate prepared by Nassr was somewhat exaggerated and reduced this facet of the claim to $200,000. Third, and lastly, the trial judge considered whether ICAM should be compensated for the unique idea “at the time he might have sold it …” to EBCO and concluded that $100,000 was the appropriate amount. In assessing what a willing seller would have accepted under the conditions ICAM and Nassr found themselves in January of 1981, both the time and energy expended in creating the concept Project Chipmunk, and an additional sum for the value of a unique idea were both appropriate factors to be weighed. Although the trial judge did not make a clear finding that $500,000 worth of shares offered by EBCO when discounted for cash would be $300,000, such a conclusion can, and should, be inferred.

head.headtext: Macri v. Miskiewicz, 1993 CarswellBC 211, 82 B.C.L.R. (2d) 126, [1993] 8 W.W.R. 46, 50 C.P.R. (3d) 76, 31 B.C.A.C. 42, 50 W.A.C. 42 (B.C.C.A.)

para.paratext: Damages to be assessed by trial judge.

This was an appeal by the defendants from a judgment declaring that the defendants, Richard Marcus and Rose Marcus, were jointly and severally liable to the plaintiff for their unlawful use of the technical/artistic information which had been imparted by the plaintiff to the defendant Richard Marcus and which information was utilized by the defendants during the period from January 1, 1980 until February 14, 1984, the date of incorporation of Marcus Art Ltd.; that the defendants, Richard Marcus, Rose Marcus and Marcus Art Ltd. jointly and severally are liable to the plaintiff for their unlawful use of the technical/artistic information which had been imparted by the plaintiff to the defendant, Richard Marcus, which information was used by the defendants from February 14, 1984 until but not including March 5, 1986, the date of incorporation of Mammoth Enterprises Inc.; and that the defendants, Richard Marcus, Rose Marcus and Mammoth Enterprises Inc., are jointly and severally liable to the plaintiff for their unlawful use of the technical/artistic information which had been imparted by the plaintiff to the defendant, Richard Marcus, during the period March 5, 1986 to November 15, 1991; and ordering that the plaintiff shall be at liberty to set for trial the quantum respectively payable by the defendants to the plaintiff, or to seek an accounting by the defendants to the plaintiff for their respective profits, following disclosure by the defendants to the plaintiff of relevant financial information by the defendants pursuant to the plaintiff's demand for discovery of documents.

headtext.bold: Reasons Given by Court for Award:

para.paratext: It could not be denied that the plaintiff, through his diligence and dedication to his work in ivory, crafted a new and innovative method of combining ivory with other materials, and by the use of cinoacrylic glue created free-standing ivory jewellery and other art objects. While each or many of the 17 steps which he developed to produce the end product may indeed have been simple and in the common domain, it was the combining of these steps into one process which achieved the ultimate stunning result.

The appellants did not continue after 1984 to be bound by an obligation of confidentiality. The process was by then known and used by others who were competitors of the parties and under no such obligation. The process had ceased to have the necessary quality of confidence. As the obligation of the appellants to the respondent ended in 1984, those paragraphs which fix a liability from the end of 1984 until 1991 could not stand. The question of damages remained to be dealt with by the court below. They should be assessed by the trial judge.

headtext.bold: Tree Savers International Ltd. v. Savoy

head.headtext: Tree Savers International Ltd. v. Savoy, [1991] 6 W.W.R. 84, 37 C.C.E.L. 116, 37 C.P.R. (3d) 455, 1991 CarswellAlta 125, 1991 ABQB 3952 (Alta. Q.B.), reversed in part (1992), 87 D.L.R. (4th) 202, 39 C.C.E.L. 253, 40 C.P.R. (3d) 173, 1992 CarswellAlta 220, [1992] A.J. No. 61, 1992 ABCA 34 (Alta. C.A.)

para.paratext: Damages of $1,920,000

In that between 95 per cent and 99 per cent of the assets acquired by Trojan in business had been acquired as a result of the breach by Savoy and Deringer against TSI, it was appropriate to appoint a receiver immediately to collect and hold all income and assets of Trojan, under terms and conditions to be approved by the court, until the damages, together with costs and interest, shall have been paid in full and that until the receiver is in place, the temporary injunction shall continue.

TSI had about 20 employees, of which Savoy, Deringer, and Albert Roesch and Bruce Cherewyk, the principals of TSI, were four. Savoy was sales manager of TSI and was the only employee at Calgary. About 90 per cent of TSI's business was directed through the offices of oil well owners and operators at Calgary. Due to the high turnover rate in personnel in the industry, by the day of Savoy's departure, the up-to-date customer list bore little or no resemblance to the one he brought to TSI. By April 21, 1989, the customer list had become TSI's customer list. Savoy was, to a great extent, autonomous in his position. No one else in the firm had his up-to-date customer lists or had but a small portion of his knowledge of the customer contact persons or customers' needs and wants or the upcoming job opportunities.

Savoy was a key employee who owed a fiduciary duty to TSI. Deringer's role was not sufficiently that of a key employee owing a fiduciary duty. However, Deringer, having joined with Savoy, is subject to the fiduciary duty of Savoy.

During the pre-termination period, both Savoy and Deringer breached their obligation of rendering faithful and loyal service to TSI by gathering together special information of TSI for their intended post-employment business and by making plans and carrying out plans for their competing business. Savoy and Deringer, after terminating, unfairly used TSI's confidential information as to the contact persons for the customers, the customers' needs and wants, the customers' preferences and TSI's discount policies. As well, they both used TSI's special information relating to TSI's gauge plug procedures, how to determine the proper size of a sealing nipple and the design of the sealing nipple as well as the dimensions, methods of use and materials used in TSI's isolation tools and special pin and bonnet. Savoy and Deringer were and are two of the three directors, officers and shareholders of Trojan and therefore, the wrongful activities of Savoy and Deringer should be imputed to Trojan from the time of its incorporation, which was immediately after the date of termination of Savoy and Deringer.

headtext.bold: Reasons Given by Court for Award:

headtext.ital: Assessment of damages by trial judge:

para.paratext: The elements of damage claimed against Savoy, Deringer and Trojan related to: (1) breach of fiduciary duty by Savoy and Deringer, which is imputed to Trojan, with respect to solicitation of clients of TSI and the use of information that is special or peculiar to TSI with respect to their apparatus and procedures; (2) breach of confidence by taking and using confidential information from TSI, including technology, client lists, pricing structures and information about client preferences and their needs and wants; (3) breach of duty of good faith and fidelity to TSI during their period of employment.

It was basically impossible to evaluate what the damages should be for each of the three elements. Damages should be awarded in two categories: (1) loss of profits to the date of trial; (2) the capitalized value of the future loss of profits, or the loss of business, goodwill and reputation; this may be calculated by subtracting the value of the business as a going concern at the time of trial from its value immediately before the damages were suffered. Loss of profits: Loss of profits he calculated from April 22, 1989, to December 31, 1990, at $658,000; and from January 1, 1991, to April 30, 1991, at $171,000, for a total of $829,000. There should be a reduction of 25 per cent to exclude Frachead's loss of profits and a further 25 per cent for the contingencies that if Savoy and Deringer had left and had not competed, there would likely have been that further loss, in any event. So that aggregate of 50 per cent reduction means a reduction of $414,500. That means a net loss of profits of $414,500. (2) Decrease in value of TSI's—To reflect those uncertainties and considerations, the amount shown by Henning for the decrease in value of TSI's business as at December 31, 1990, $1,728,000, should be discounted by 50 per cent: $864,000 for that item; (3) The cost to hire and train new employees to replace Savoy and Deringer based on 9 months instead of the 18 months for the replacements to be trained, one half of $146,200 is $73,100. Those three elements total $1,351,600.
TSI shall have judgment against Savoy, Deringer and Trojan in the amount of $1,351,600.

headtext.ital: Assessment of damages by Court of Appeal:

para.paratext: The first part of damage awards considered was the award for replacing and training employees. The trial judgment awarded only half the amount given by the respondent plaintiff's expert, i.e., only $73,100. The trial judge seems to have done so on the basis of 9 months notice, not 18. 9 months was too short.

The trial judge cut each of these heads of damage in half, to allow for future contingencies. That was too severe. A multiplier of only four times annual earnings already builds in an enormous amount of risk. The further 50 per cent cut was serious underestimation. In other words, risks were counted twice.

It did not appear that adding the suggested future “cut-off point” for lost profits would much reduce that head of damages. In the first place, it would have taken a good deal of time and money for a competitor to break into this market legitimately without any theft of trade secrets or breach of fiduciary duty by anyone. In the second place, the valuators and the trial judge only used a multiplier of four times earnings. A steep discount rate means that anything a few years away has very little effect on the final number. The practical solution was to adjust the excessive 50 per cent discount of the lost-profit and business-value figures. The trial judge's pessimism as to the future could not be stretched to more than a 30 per cent discount. Accordingly the discount should be only 30 per cent on those two items.

head.headtext: Gottcon Contractors Ltd. v. Manzo, 1992 CarswellOnt 862, 49 C.L.R. 233, 40 C.P.R. (3d) 498, 92 C.L.L.C. 14,031(Ont. C.J. [Gen. Div.]); affirmed 1996 CarswellOnt 1797 (Ont. C.A.)

para.paratext: Damages of $125,000

The plaintiffs were limited companies owned by the Gottardo family. They sued the defendant corporation and its three principals for damages for breach of fiduciary duty and for wrongful use of confidential information. The plaintiff Gottardo was a masonry contractor. The plaintiff Gottcon was a general building contractor engaged in the construction of commercial buildings.

Emilio Manzo was employed by Gottardo as a masonry estimator. By 1986 he was Gottardo's chief masonry estimator and was used by Gottcon from time to time as an estimator for general contracting work. In April 1986 the Stonor Group, a client of Gottcon, requested a quotation for the construction in Markham of a new commercial building known as the Applecreek Project. The defendant Manzo did all of the necessary preliminary work and prepared a draft quotation. He prepared the masonry bid on behalf of Gottardo. He then prepared a spreadsheet complete with all the necessary information except for the allowance for overhead and profit. This work Manzo then took to Aldo Gottardo for approval. Aldo Gottardo reviewed the work, generally approved the draft and established the allowance for overhead and the allowance for profit. This quotation was put into letter form, signed by Emilio Manzo and submitted to the Stonor Group. The total price quoted was $2,609,000. The Stonor Group decided not to proceed immediately with the project and nothing was done at that time.

In about the middle of February 1987, Emilio Manzo advised Aldo Gottardo that he was leaving Gottardo effective February 27, 1987 and that he intended to establish his own business. During the first week of March 1987, the defendant Maystar Contracting Ltd. was incorporated by the three defendants. The corporate defendant was awarded the Stonor contract.

headtext.bold: Reasons Given by Court for Award:

para.paratext: The court was not persuaded that Manzo was in breach of a fiduciary duty. However, Manzo made use of confidential information obtained from his employment with the plaintiffs in preparing Maystar's successful bid. The intimate knowledge he possessed of Gottcon's tender including their subcontractor's quotes gave him and Maystar a clear advantage over his former employer. He used this knowledge to bid and obtain the contract.

The contract resulted in a substantial profit to Maystar. Maystar made a net profit in excess of $250,000. However, judgment for an amount equivalent to Maystar's profit was not the correct way to assess the plaintiff's damages. The award should be discounted to allow an amount for the defendant's overhead and a further consideration should be given for the contingency that the Stonor Group would not give the contract to the plaintiffs without a substantial price advantage.

The respondents recovered judgment against the appellants Manzo and Maystar Contracting Ltd. in the sum of $125,000 for improper use of confidential information. The trial judge considered evidence relating to the estimated profit, the contingency of not being awarded the contract and the obligation to mitigate. The assessment was a difficult one to make and there was no error in his conclusion. An award of $125,000 would accurately reflect the injury suffered by the plaintiffs by reason of the wrongful use of confidential information by the defendants Manzo and Maystar.

head.headtext: Pharand Ski Corp. v. Alberta, 1991 CarswellAlta 85, 80 Alta. L.R. (2d) 216, 116 A.R. 326, 37 C.P.R. (3d) 288, 7 C.C.L.T. (2d) 225, 5 B.L.R. (2d) 53, 27 A.C.W.S. (3d) 324 (Alta. Q.B.)

para.paratext: Damages of $1,300,000

The plaintiff claimed several remedies, including damages against the defendant, the province of Alberta, on an action for breach of an obligation or a duty of confidence. The plaintiff alleged the defendant misused confidential information provided to it by the plaintiff in confidence, the misuse of which was of advantage to the defendant and of detriment to the plaintiff. Specifically, the plaintiff alleged that the defendant misappropriated its site selection of Mt. Allan and its concept of and basic design for the area as a viable, commercial, recreational ski area with the added capability of hosting all of the alpine events for the 1988 Winter Olympic Games. In fact, the Mt. Allan site was developed by the defendant, and all of the events of the 1988 Winter Olympic Games with the exception of ski jumping were held there.

headtext.bold: Reasons Given by Court for Award:

para.paratext: The information provided by the Pharands to the government in response to the first proposals call was information that had about it the necessary quality of confidentiality. The potential of Mt. Allan, for the purposes ultimately realized, went undiscovered until the Pharands saw it and brought it to the attention of the world. Although the site of Mt. Allan had been mentioned in various government studies instituted to discover in Kananaskis Country a viable recreational ski area which also had the capability of hosting the Olympic alpine events, no one in government saw its potential as a unique site until the Pharands, by their concept plan, put it into focus. The site selection and the concept plan developed by the Pharands had not only the quality of confidence, its discovery and disclosure were the very essence of the confidence. It was the discovery that had eluded the government and its experts. The Pharands took care throughout to guard their discovery and to reaffirm their position even after the matter became public knowledge. And the information was of real value to the plaintiff. Had the site remained a secret the result would have been the plaintiff as the only bidder for the only site capable of meeting both government objectives under the proposals call system. A great deal of effort and investment of capital were expended by the Pharand group to originate the idea and then prove it up as required by the second proposals call. These factors, coupled with the ingenuity, insight and innovativeness of the idea, prove the quality of confidence.

An obligation of confidence was, in the first instance, expressly accepted by the defendant in response to the plaintiff's request. Second, the obligation arose from the special relationship under the first proposals call. Also, this was information of a commercial value given on a businesslike basis with an avowed common object in mind for the purposes of an anticipated joint venture with the government as co-developer.

The first clear breach by the defendant was when the Calgary Olympic Development Association was told of Mt. Allan as a possible site for the Olympic alpine events. That was done without any knowledge or consent from the plaintiff that their site and concept, given in confidence, were being so disclosed.

Not only had the site of Mt. Allan been revealed but the whole concept of the development plan given in confidence to Mr. Ogilvy formed the basis of the Ogilvy/Mathews June 1982 report, was publicly disclosed. All this confidential information imparted by the plaintiff to the defendant was now being used by the defendant for a purpose inconsistent with the purpose for which it was given, the opportunity to be selected as a developer to work with the defendant as a co-developer of the specific site. This contravened the express purpose of the first proposals call. It also breached the condition of confidence obtained by the plaintiff before taking part in the first proposals call, and it breached the equitable relation of confidence and trust between the plaintiff and defendant imposed by equity.
There was a misuse of the information provided by the plaintiff to the defendant which has been to the detriment of the plaintiff.

Only the remedy of damages was applicable. The difficulty in assessing damages in this case was that the defendant was not only the owner of the property but also the planning approval authority. The total development process from site acquisition, planning, financing, implementing and operating—all phases were under the control of the defendant.

Evidence of the value of the planning done by the plaintiff is also found in the draft agreement it had with Skiing Louise Ltd. It provided not only for equity and operational participation but also provided that if the plaintiff was successful in its bid as selected developer it would be reimbursed up to $300,000 for development expenses. The plaintiff also submitted detailed accounts of expenses accumulated in preparing its submissions under the total proposals call process totalling approximately $150,000 without charging for the time and services of Susan and Claude Pharand.

What the plaintiff lost, by the breach of confidence, was the exclusive opportunity to bid and become the only proponent of a site which answered the objectives of the defendant. If the confidence had been respected, the defendant would either have concluded a co-development agreement with the plaintiff or, failing that, recompensed the plaintiff for finding the site and proving it up.

Considering the plaintiff's lost opportunity and the value of the information imparted by it, the court set damages as fair compensation based on an expert witness valuation at $1,000,000. No award was made for any increase in the value of the site based upon what may have been added in value depending upon the government's participation in infrastructure costs. That was considered much too speculative on the evidence and in all likelihood double damages. However, an additional award of $300,000 as damages was made for recovery of the direct expenses of the plaintiff in accordance with industry practice. This amount was based upon the amount fixed by the plaintiff in its marketplace negotiations with Skiing Louise Ltd. for the return of these expenses had it been the selected developer.

headtext.bold: Ken Graham Consumer Products Ltd. v. Sunbeam Corp. (Canada)

head.headtext: Ken Graham Consumer Products Ltd. v. Sunbeam Corp. (Canada), 1989 CarswellOnt 720, 25 C.P.R. (3d) 52 (Ont. S.C.) [decision on liability]; Ken Graham Consumer Products Ltd. v. Sunbeam Corp. (Canada), 1989 CarswellOnt 802, 27 C.P.R. (3d) 437 (Ont. S.C.) [Decision on damages]

para.paratext: Damages to be assessed on reference or on continuation of trial.
The defendant was declared to be liable to the plaintiff for inducing breach of contract and for misusing confidential information.

The subject matter of the action was the production of coffee makers. The plaintiff was involved in supplying the defendant with coffee makers manufactured in Hong Kong. The claim arose because the defendant purchased coffee makers direct from the Hong Kong manufacturer without the participation of the plaintiff.

Kenneth Graham was employed in Canada for approximately 12 years by a major electrical manufacturer. In May, 1976, he left that employment and caused the plaintiff to be incorporated. His purpose was to create his own brands of small appliances. In March, 1977, Ken Graham travelled to Asia with the design and the mock up to find a manufacturer. E & E agreed to manufacture a coffee maker for Ken Graham in accordance with the design. It also agreed to manufacture the moulds and tooling which would be sold to Ken Graham. In November, 1977, the agreement was evidenced by a purchase order for the tools and moulds, and by a purchase order for 40,000 coffee makers. It was further evidenced in February, 1978 by a written document.

In March, 1980, the defendant Sunbeam agreed with E & E and Ken Graham to purchase coffee makers. In the March, 1980 Agreement, Sunbeam was described as purchaser, E & E as vendor and Ken Graham as agent. Sunbeam made efforts to acquire ownership of the tooling from Ken Graham and also explored the possibility of either a new product or a significant improvement to the CM-2 product. Sunbeam was constantly seeking improvements in both quality and cost. At some time before the end of 1980, Ken Stricker asked Ken Graham to make a proposal for the sale of his tooling. There were ongoing discussions but no agreement could be reached.

In May 1981, there was a Sunbeam meeting at which it was decided that the enterprise would “source a coffee maker like the CM-2” for its worldwide operations. Sunbeam and E & E were proceeding with the new E & E coffee maker which Sunbeam designated the ECM-4. In January, 1984, Sunbeam placed an order for the ECM-4 from E & E. At some point, Ken Graham became aware that E & E was producing a new coffee maker and that Sunbeam was considering purchasing it. The design of the ECM-4 was, to some extent, copied from the CM-2 and the ECM-4 was initially made in part from moulds and tooling previously used to manufacture the CM-2. Some of the tooling for the ECM-4 must have been copied from the tooling for the CM-2. It would be fair to say that the ECM-4was a “line extension” of the CM-2.

headtext.bold: Reasons Given by Court for Award:

para.paratext: The valuation of the tooling and the information were a preferable means of assessing the compensation to Ken Graham than the more difficult, expensive and less satisfactory method of ordering an accounting. The misuse of confidential information in the circumstances of this particular case did not warrant Ken Graham receiving any net profits that might be found to be in excess of what he would have received from Sunbeam for, in effect, permission to use that information.

Some of the information given by Ken Graham to E & E was regarded by Ken Graham as confidential. The coffee makers could be easily copied by reverse engineering. The part of the information that was confidential was limited to design. E & E already had the know-how with respect to the electricity and plumbing. Sunbeam and E & E recognized that some of the design information received from Ken Graham was confidential. Ken Graham, Sunbeam and E & E were jointly engaged in development of a product that required a free flow of information amongst them but, based on custom, there was implied in their relationship an obligation of confidence. E & E made use of design information it had received from Ken Graham in manufacturing the ECM-4. At that time, all the information was in the public domain in the sense that anybody was free to copy all or part of the product. Nevertheless, the use of the information facilitated, to an extent, the manufacture of the ECM-4. Possession of the information would result in significant savings of time and money. Sunbeam knew that E & E had used some of the design information obtained from Ken Graham in manufacturing the ECM-4. Sunbeam indirectly made use of that information when it ordered the ECM-4 from E & E. Sunbeam also made use of design information from Ken Graham when it obtained access to the Ken Graham CSA file. The CSA is primarily concerned with function and not with design. There was, however, some confidential information in the file. The material, including the confidential information, was used in processing the new file which eventually led to the approval of the ECM-4. The extent to which information given by Ken Graham to E & E and to Sunbeam was confidential may not have been great and the use of such confidential information by them may have resulted only in an insignificant loss to Ken Graham.

In manufacturing the ECM-4, E & E used information that had been given to it in confidence. Sunbeam knew that Ken Graham had given confidential information to E & E. It did not know the precise terms of the E & E obligation. Ken Graham revealed the information to Sunbeam for the purpose of a joint venture. The information was communicated in circumstances under which an obligation of confidence existed. Sunbeam used the confidential information supplied by Ken Graham without his consent in two ways: first, by ordering the ECM-4 from E & E; and second, in obtaining CSA approval for that product. Sunbeam knew that the ECM-4 ordered by it would in part be manufactured by the use of confidential information obtained from Ken Graham. In this way, Sunbeam indirectly made use of confidential information to the detriment of Ken Graham.

The liability of Sunbeam is not affected by the fact that the information was in the public domain or that the coffee maker could be copied. Those circumstances may be significant in determining the remedy but a party under an obligation of confidence may not do what others may be able to do.
Sunbeam conceded that Ken Graham was entitled to $1.00 for every ECM-4 that E & E sold to Sunbeam.

Where there has been misuse of confidential information, the court has the power to order an accounting of profits. As the remedy is equitable, the granting of it is in the discretion of the court. There are other available remedies in such a situation. The appropriate remedy depends on the circumstances. In some cases, a combination of remedies has been ordered. An injunction is a common remedy but was inapplicable in this particular case. Sunbeam had ceased purchasing the ECM-4 and in fact is no longer carrying on business in Canada. In at least one case, damages were awarded based on the market value of the information used. In another case, a quantum meruit claim was recognized. In yet another case, the property acquired through use of the information was found to be held on a constructive trust.

There were several problems with ordering an accounting. An accounting is a time-consuming, expensive and often unsatisfactory process. At the end of the inquiry, the result may be disappointing for a plaintiff because he is only entitled to recover net profits. If a plaintiff insists on an inquiry in which the results are highly doubtful, he may be at risk for costs. Ken Graham was not a manufacturer. Misuse of confidential information by a manufacturing competitor may well affect the sales of an injured manufacturer. In such a case, an accounting for profits to compensate for lost sales may be quite appropriate. However, when the plaintiff is not a manufacturer, an accounting may be inappropriate and the springboard argument has less relevance. Because of the nature of the product and the relationship of the parties, there is the further difficulty that not all of the information that went into the manufacture of the ECM-4 was confidential. It would appear probable that in assessing the profits of Sunbeam that some adjustment would have to be made for that circumstance.

The proper course for Sunbeam to have followed would have been to obtain the consent of Ken Graham to the manufacture of the ECM-4. Ken Graham could be adequately compensated if he were to be awarded the market value as between a willing seller and a willing buyer of the tooling and information. He should receive the amount that Sunbeam would have paid him for his tooling and his design at the time it decided to order the ECM-4. Ken Graham was agreeable to such an arrangement if proper terms could have been worked out.

In addition, Ken Graham should be entitled as special damages to his cost of bringing the tooling to Canada. Finally, he should be entitled to interest from an appropriate date on the amounts awarded to him.

headtext.bold: Quantum Management Services Ltd. v. Hann

head.headtext: Quantum Management Services Ltd. v. Hann, 1989 CarswellOnt 124, 43 B.L.R. 93, 69 O.R. (2d) 26, 25 C.P.R. (3d) 218 (Ont. H.C.J.); affirmed 1992 CarswellOnt 1707, 11 O.R. (3d) 639, 45 C.P.R. (3d) 498 (Ont. C.A.)

para.paratext: Damages of $35,937

The plaintiff corporation sued the one corporate and two personal defendants for damages suffered by the plaintiff as a result of the solicitation of competitive business by the two personal defendants. The personal defendants commenced working for the rival corporate defendant upon leaving the plaintiff's employ.

The defendants Hann and Taaffe breached their duty not to solicit their former employer's clients in that they exploited confidential information that they had committed to memory relating to those clients. The memorization of the characteristics of their exclusive clients was tantamount to the physical asportation of a client list.

headtext.bold: Reasons Given by Court for Award:

para.paratext: The deliberate solicitation by Hann and Taaffe of former customers of Quantum, with whom they had exclusive placement rights when they quit Quantum's employ, constituted an unfair exploitation of confidential information to which they had been made privy in their capacities as placement directors of Quantum.

Of the methods of calculating damages for breach of fiduciary obligation, the plaintiff elected a calculation based on its own lost profits, suitably adjusted, rather than a disgorgement of profits realized by the defendants.

The trial judge found that (1) in their capacity as placement directors of the temporary division of Quantum, Hann and Taaffe knew the names of their exclusive Quantum clients, the contacts at these clients' businesses, the clients' needs, their preferences and the rates that they were willing to pay; (2) Hann and Taaffe accounted for 78% of the billings in Quantum's temporary division during the three months preceding their departure; (3) after their departure, Hann and Taaffe deliberately solicited clients through the contacts they had established during their tenure at Quantum; (4) during the first three months of its existence, 98% of the billings of Pinstripe Personnel Inc., the company which was incorporated following their departure from Quantum and which became their new employer, came from job orders placed with former Quantum clients; (5) the large majority of Pinstripe clients from July 31, 1985 until December 31, 1986 were former Quantum clients solicited by Hann and Taaffe; and (6) Pinstripe recruited a low percentage of new clients despite heavy advertising in the media.

The net profit for Quantum expressed as a percentage of temporary sales should be 9 per cent for July 1, 1985 through December 31, 1985, and 6 per cent for January 1, 1986 through March 31, 1986. Various administrative costs were fixed during this period when Quantum's temporary placements diminished by reason of the absence of Hann and Taaffe and their recruitment of their former Quantum clients for Pinstripe. The July to September, 1985 figure of $121,904 multiplied by 9 per cent equals $10,971. Similarly, 9 per cent of the October to December 1985 figure of $223,484 is $20,114. The January to March 1986 figure of $332,505 at 6 per cent is $19,950. The total figure for notional profits over the 9-month period is therefore $51,035. This figure must then be reduced for vagaries and risk. Given the fact that most clients apparently use more than one agency, along with the fact that Pinstripe expressly sought “back-up” business when approaching Quantum clients, not all sales by Pinstripe to Quantum clients necessarily represented losses to Quantum. Another factor to consider was “the proximity of the loss in relation to time of departure diminishing the extent of loss with the progression of time.” Reducing the July to September figure by 10 per cent was $9,874. Reducing the October to December figure by 20 per cent was $16,091 and subtracting 30 per cent from the January to March figure left $13,965 for a total of $39,930. A 10 per cent reduction to allow for other vagaries and risks is appropriate, resulting in a final figure of $35,937.

head.headtext: Genesta Manufacturing Ltd. v. Babey, 1984 CarswellOnt 114, 29 B.L.R. 36, 48 O.R. (2d) 94, 6 C.C.E.L. 291, 2 C.P.R. (3d) 32 (Ont. H.C.J.)

para.paratext: Plaintiff was entitled to damages against all defendants for the improper solicitation of its customers.
Such damages were to be assessed by the Local Master.

This was an action for damages and for injunctive relief by the plaintiff, a manufacturer of plastic products, against a former employee, and his co-defendants who are now associated with him in the manufacture of plastic products.

The market was limited. There were only 10 major manufacturers in the United States and the plaintiff claimed to have 90 to 95 per cent of the Canadian market. In September 1978, the defendant B was hired by the plaintiff as plant manager. By December 1979, the plaintiff had 34 employees, all of whom, other than the few office personnel, reported to B. He was number two man in the company. In April 1981, B was named manufacturing manager, without change in salary. However, production personnel now reported to P. The title of manufacturing manager was virtually meaningless. By June 1982, B was named “Purchasing Agent” but could make no purchase for the plant without the approval of P. In the spring of 1982, he began the organization of his own business. Some time before the end of January 1982 he took a copy of the plaintiff's customer list. He had little or no need of this as he had no duties in connection with sales and, in fact, there were only 10 major customers of the plaintiff, all well known in the industry.

headtext.bold: Reasons Given by Court for Award:

para.paratext: The court concluded that B was not a “senior employee”. In addition, while the defendants did what they could to misappropriate this business opportunity, they did not succeed, nor did any other manufacturer realize the opportunity. The plaintiff had not established that it was more likely than not that the plaintiff would have concluded an agreement with North American Philips but for the intervention of B and his colleagues, or that such agreement would have been profitable.

Where, by the misuse of trade secrets, the plaintiff has had a “springboard”, abridging the period of development which would have been required in the absence of such misuse of trade secrets, it is appropriate to grant an injunction to prevent the defendant from producing within the period of time saved by the springboard. The defendant B was dismissed on August 13, 1982, and the first profiles were produced in April 1983, some eight months later. The “springboard” time for a person with B's experience would not be more than five months. In view of the fact that the defendants did not start preparation for profile production for over four months and that no profile was produced until eight months after termination, this was not a case where an injunction should be granted.

The “know-how” involved in producing lighting profiles by extrusion is not a trade secret. Knowledge of the costing and pricing of profiles and of general office procedure are not trade secrets. B was entitled to take with him any additional skills or experience he may have acquired as an employee. There had been no theft of trade secrets by B.

The defendant B was not entitled to make a copy of the plaintiff's customer list for his own use, nor to solicit its customers on behalf of his new company except as part of a general solicitation of the market. It was probable that he or his colleagues used the customer list for the new business. This was pointless because, with only ten prominent lighting manufacturers as customers, there was no need to take any list. However, B did take a copy and the defendants did solicit eight of the ten manufacturers and made sales to five of them. The direct solicitation of these customers, as compared with a general solicitation of the entire marketplace, is in breach of the duty owed by an ex-employee to his former employer. Where this breach causes loss to the employer, the employer is entitled to damages. The plaintiff put forward a claim based on two types of loss. The first was for profit on sales by the defendants to customers of the plaintiff. The second was for profit lost when the plaintiff reduced its prices to meet the new competition.

The period selected by the plaintiff of July 1983 to April 1984 was not appropriate. It involved two assumptions. The first was that all sales made by Viva would have been made by the plaintiff but for the defendants' improper conduct and the second was that it is the function of the Court to enforce, by awarding damages, the monopoly of the plaintiff, at least to April 13, 1984. The proper approach was to assess the plaintiff's loss which results from the improper solicitation of customers and would not have occurred but for such solicitation. This must be for a limited period. The plaintiff was not entitled to restrict the defendant forever from making sales to its customers. If B and his associates had started up business and limited their marketing to general advertisements and advertisements in trade publications it was probable that the entry of Viva into the marketplace would have been known by the ten potential customers within a very short period of time. It was likely that most would be interested to see whether the new supplier could furnish satisfactory products at the same, or lower, prices. In all probability Viva would have started receiving inquiries and orders soon after it made known the fact that it was in the market and by one year after B's departure from the plaintiff and four months of starting production, Viva, without any improper solicitation, would have established its position with those of the customers of the plaintiff who chose to deal with it. The appropriate period during which damages should be assessed was between August 13, 1982, and August 12, 1983.

Damages consisted of the loss of profit experienced by the plaintiff during this period over and above the loss of profit which would probably have occurred even if there had been no direct approach to the plaintiff's customers. There would have been a substantial loss to the plaintiff even if there had been no direct approach to customers by Viva. The plaintiff's damages should consist of 50 per cent of the profit the plaintiff would have made on the sales which were actually made by Viva to customers of the plaintiff in the one-year period ending August 12, 1983, and 50 per cent of the loss of profit resulting from the reduction in price by the plaintiff to meet the new competition during this period.

If agreement could not be reached, the court would direct a reference to the Local Master to determine the plaintiff's damages. In assessing such damages the “formula” prepared by the plaintiff's accountant should be accepted and the discount of $14,274.50 which was allowed to Crouse-Hinds Canada Limited in lieu of reduced invoice prices should be included as part of the loss sustained by the plaintiff through sales at reduced prices.

headtext.bold: White Oaks Welding Supplies v. Tapp

head.headtext: White Oaks Welding Supplies v. Tapp, 1983 CarswellOnt 915, 42 O.R. (2d) 445, 73 C.P.R. (2d) 98, 149 D.L.R. (3d) 159 (Ont. S.C.)

para.paratext: Judgment for the plaintiff for $28,296

The plaintiff carried on a welding supply business, the chief part of which was the supply of a variety of gases in cylinders to concerns using these in the welding process. In March of 1977, the defendant was the sales manager, having responsibility for two salesmen and two servicemen. In addition, he had authority over certain office personnel as well. The defendant approved all new product lines before the company made a final decision to accept them.

The business of welding supply, and particularly the gas distribution end, is highly competitive. Competitors within the industry attack each other's accounts and it is not unknown for customers to be won and lost, and won again in the course of the battle.

On October 12, 1978, the defendant resigned his position with the plaintiff company. The defendant at no time made an agreement not to compete. The defendant, however, was one of only three executives of this business, one of whom was the owner. The defendant was, in fact, almost entirely responsible for sales and had a day-to-day managerial responsibility for that side of the company's business.

The defendant, with his encyclopaedic knowledge of the plaintiff's customers, his unrestricted access to all customer lists and information concerning such customers, and his personal contact with and responsibility for a large proportion of the plaintiff's customers, was a senior employee with a fiduciary relationship to his employer.

Removable cards from a telephone directory made up by the defendant and used by him for purposes of the plaintiff's business while he was in its employ were so removed and did assist him in soliciting customers for the new concern. In addition, the defendant took with him a miscellaneous collection of notes written and used by him in the course of conducting the plaintiff's business, and such notes were used by the new concern in the preparation of a mailing list for the purpose of soliciting customers.
The defendant's corporation has since failed and the defendant is not actively engaged in a competing business.

headtext.bold: Reasons Given by Court for Award:

para.paratext: As the fault of the defendant was in the breach of a fiduciary relationship, the profits realized by the defendant might be impressed with a resulting trust of which the plaintiff would be the beneficiary. However, the court concluded that the approach should be one of ascertaining the plaintiff's loss of profit, suitably adjusted, having regard to the nature and risks of the business involved. The defendant and his newly formed corporation made very little profit during the time they operated and to hold them merely to an accounting for their profits would be to place a premium on inefficiency.

The amount awarded should be based on the demonstrated loss of the plaintiff, adjusted in several major respects. First, competition in the welding supply business is very severe and clients' accounts, in whole or in part, are constantly being captured and recaptured by the various competitors. Secondly, the non-competition agreement which the defendant was at one time asked to sign, but which was in fact never executed, had in it a limit of one year from the time of resignation as the period during which the defendant would not compete. This furnished a fair limit to the period during which losses should be charged to the defendant. Finally, the practice of the “contribution to overhead” by Canadian Liquid Air Limited, the plaintiff's principal supplier, had the effect of reducing the plaintiff's losses. The “contribution to overhead” made by the supplier was an effective means of price support and it was available to the plaintiff, admittedly after negotiation on an account-by-account basis, to compensate it for loss of revenue occasioned by the plaintiff's reduction of its own prices to certain of its customers which better enabled it to meet the competition offered by the defendant. The court took 35% of the gross sales to October, 1979, $10,808, representing lost gross profit to the plaintiff, as well as gross profit for the defendant.

The court applied the figure of 15.25% to each of the plaintiff's headings, namely, “Lost Revenue Due to Reduced Selling Prices …”, “Lost Demurrage Revenues” and “Lost Revenue Due to Inability to Pass on Selling Price Increases.” These yielded to the nearest dollar totals of $12,102, $2,682 and $8,380 respectively, for a total, added to 35% of the defendant's gross sales, of $10,808, amounting to $33,972.
The court deducted from the total given above 15.25% of that subsidy or, to the nearest dollar, $5,676, giving a net loss to the plaintiff of $28,296.

head.headtext: Schauenburg Industries Ltd. v. Borowski, 1979 CarswellOnt 166, 25 O.R. (2d) 737, 8 B.L.R. 164, 50 C.P.R. (2d) 69, 101 D.L.R. (3d) 701, [1979] O.J. No. 4349 (Ont. H.C.)

para.paratext: Reference to the Master or a Local Master to assess the damages sustained by SIL; and direction that such damages shall be the loss of profits suffered by SIL resulting from sales made by the defendants, during the said two-year period of time, which would probably have been made by SIL but for the wrongful conduct of the defendants.
Punitive damages were assessed at $25,000, divided $20,000 to SIL and $5,000 to the owner of the copyright in the drawings.

While still employed by the plaintiff SIL from the spring of 1977 through August 1977, B set up a trading entity known as Advent. Through Advent he solicited the customers of the plaintiffs and used their employees in attempts to sell rigid mining ducting. In June 1977, B tendered his resignation to SIL, which resignation was to be effective in September 1977.
No particular efforts were taken by SIL to ensure security or maximum security in connection with the use of the two machines in its manufacturing processes.

In the fall of 1977, B gave the original SRG plans to an Ontario company in order that it might manufacture for him a long-seam machine and a heat-sealing machine. The machines were produced for Band, through Flex vent, he used the machines to manufacture flexible ducting which was sold in competition with SIL. Flex vent's product was virtually identical to that sold by SIL. In December 1977, on demand, B returned the original drawings to SIL.

headtext.bold: Reasons Given by Court for Award:

para.paratext: B worked for SIL from 1969 to 1977. He was general manager and virtually autonomous, subject to only one or two visits each year from personnel of the parent company. He was truly senior management and his relationship to SIL was that of a fiduciary.
B wrongfully used this confidential information. B was in breach of his fiduciary duty and the plaintiff SIL was entitled to damages or an injunction or both.

It would require time to develop the two machines, using the plaintiffs' process, to be available to go into production. Without the use of the drawings or input of confidential information from B, he could have contracted for the construction of the necessary machines upon a proper termination of employment, and that he could have commenced the manufacture of these ventilating ducts within two years from the date of termination of employment.

It would be giving the plaintiffs protection beyond that required to enjoin the defendants permanently. Damages are an adequate remedy based on loss of profits for the two years, together with punitive damages in the circumstances. Courts have granted injunctions and/or damages, not on a “permanent” basis but rather covering a period which is referred to as the “springboard” or “long start” period. The springboard principle applied. An interlocutory judgment might have been a proper remedy before trial had it been sought by the plaintiff. However, the two-year period would expire in a short time. The plaintiffs shall recover the damages sustained between September 30th, 1977, and September 30th, 1979, such damages to be assessed on a reference.

The defendant B displayed flagrant behavior and a callous disregard for the rights of his employer in breaching his fiduciary and contractual duties and in infringing copyright. The plaintiff SIL sustained a loss of profits of $150,000 in the first year following B's resignation.
The plaintiff SIL was entitled to damages against the defendants for breach of fiduciary duty, use of confidential information and breach of contractual duty of secrecy.

head.headtext: Reliable Toy Co. v. Collins, 1950 CarswellOnt 96, 13 C.P.R. 53, 11 Fox Pat. C. 5, [1950] O.R. 360, [1950] 4 D.L.R. 499 (Ont. H.C.J.)

para.paratext: Damages of $2,500.

The plaintiffs were also entitled to an injunction restraining the defendant from further disclosure of the trade secrets with respect to the mask, but because of the rapid developments in the plastics fields it should be of limited duration.
This was a restraint of trade action in which the plaintiffs sought to restrain the defendant from disclosing certain of their trade secrets and for damages in respect of such disclosures.
The toy company employed the defendant as a chemist in its chemical laboratory from October 1, 1945, to September 20, 1948, when he was discharged. In the laboratory Collins was chief chemist.
The main disclosures were alleged to have been made to the plaintiffs' chief competitors, Dulev.

Up to the time of Collins' discharge there was not on the market in Canada a suitable lacquer for decorating styrene toys and in having such a lacquer the plaintiffs had an advantage over their competitors.

headtext.bold: Reasons Given by Court for Award:

para.paratext: The matters in respect of which the defendant made improper disclosure were secret and confidential information and the secrecy agreement extended to cover them, altogether apart from the obligations imposed upon a servant arising out of the confidential relationship with his master.

The result of the action was that the plaintiffs' claims failed in all respects save that related to the mask for decorating styrene toys. The plaintiffs suffered increased competition from its competitor, Dulev Plastics.

headtext.bold: XY, LLC v. Canadian Topsires Selection Inc.

head.headtext: XY, LLC v. Canadian Topsires Selection Inc., 2016 CarswellBC 1648, 2016 BCSC 1095

para.paratext: Punitive damages against Zhu, IND, CTS, FBI, IEI, IDI and Ai De were awarded in the amount of $300,000 on a joint and several basis.
In recognition of the lesser role played by Tang and Zhang, punitive damages against each of them in the amount of $100,000 was awarded.

The trial judge in the original action rejected the claim for punitive damages, finding that although the fraudulent conduct of Zhu, Tang and Zhou was “reprehensible”, such conduct did not fall into the category of “malicious” or “highly reprehensible”.

In the current action, the major issue was the determination of damages with respect to: firstly, Tang, Zhang and Ai De, if liability was established; and, secondly, the other defendants against whom liability had already been established. XY sought compensatory damages arising in the period after that considered by the Court in the Original Action after the end of 2008, on the basis of conspiracy and breach of confidence. In the original action, the Court had granted judgment in favour of XY against JingJing, Zhu, and two of his employees, Tang and Zhou in the amount of $8.5 million on the basis of breach of contract, breach of confidence, conspiracy and deceit. The Court had also granted a permanent and mandatory injunction designed to protect XY's intellectual property and technology rights.

The Original Action concerned a licencing arrangement between XY and JingJing, one of Zhu's companies. XY granted a licence to JingJing in February 2004 which required JingJing to pay certain royalties to XY for its use of its technology relating to sexed semen and sexed embryos. In accordance with arrangements between the parties, JingJing originally acquired two SX cytometers for use in its semen-sorting business. XY terminated the Licence in November 2008 after disputes with JingJing arose. The trial judge in the original action found that XY's technology included certain confidential matters including a number of specified components of the SX cytometer, including its configuration; XY's protocols, and all other information and techniques imparted from XY during training, or otherwise, to any of the defendants in the Original Action or their employees relating to the use and operation of SX cytometers; and, XY's confidential patent information. Having found a breach of confidence by the widespread misuse of XY's technology and protocols, the trial judge in the original action issued a prohibitory injunction against the defendants, including Zhu and others, to prevent future use of the Confidential Information, either directly or indirectly. The trial judge also issued a mandatory injunction by which Zhu, Tang and others were to deliver all Confidential Information in their possession, power or control to XY.

The foundation of XY's present claims rested on its now-proven allegations that the defendants in the Original Action were in possession of information confidential to XY, and that they breached their duty in respect of that confidence. In particular, XY relied on the trial judge's findings concerning what he defined as XY's “Confidential Information” in the Trial Order. In the present action, XY alleged that Zhu and Tang continued to breach that duty of confidence to XY after the events that were addressed in the Original Action, and even during the trial itself and beyond. In addition, XY alleged that many other persons, being the other defendants in this action, assisted Zhu and Tang in breaching this duty, and they also benefitted or were unjustly enriched from their actions, although in differing degrees.

In the Original Action, the trial judge found that there had been “widespread misuse” of XY's Confidential Information. XY, and hence the Court, were not fully aware of the misuse that was occurring at the time of the Original Action. Indeed, to some degree, Zhu used the course of the Original Action to aid in the execution of his plan, assisted by the non-disclosure of his true activities. During the course of the Original Action, Zhu and the other defendants continued to assert that JingJing had been put out of business. XY did not know that the IND Group continued to use the three cytometers in their possession to sort semen during the course of the Original Action despite the termination of the Licence. Zhu considered the termination of the Licence, in November 2008, to be entirely irrelevant. It was business as usual for Zhu's semen-sorting operations after November 2008.

The evidence overwhelming supported the following findings of fact: a) Zhu, along with his key employees in the IND Group, used XY's Confidential Information to continue JingJing's operations past the date of termination of the Licence in late 2008 to create sexed semen. They did so until Zhu and the IND Group's key employees concocted a plan in 2010 that would place JingJing into bankruptcy with a view to disguising their ongoing operations and use of XY's Confidential Information; b) concurrent with placing JingJing into bankruptcy, the IND Group companies (IND, IEI, IDI, CTS and FBI), its employees and Zhu expressly planned to use XY's Confidential Information for their own purposes in the future. They succeeded in doing so by January 2012, which saw a resurrection of their operations in the Lower Mainland (through CTS), and either a continuation or commencement of their operations in China. These activities arose, in part, from their use of both “real” SX parts withheld from XY and the Trustee, and also the copying of manufactured SX parts (the BSO and tips) based on further misuse of XY's Confidential Information; and c) the plan was implemented by Zhu and his key IND Group employees, while knowing full well as to the confidential nature of XY's technology, and to exacerbate matters, while doing so in the face of litigation (i.e. the Original Action) commenced by XY to protect its interests in its technology.

headtext.bold: Reasons Given by Court for Award:

para.paratext: The fact that Zhu and the IND Group employees, both in Canada and China, took such pains to keep their plans secret, indicated that all these individuals were well-aware that their actions were breaches of confidence. In execution of this plan, Zhu and his employees made extensive efforts to hide their efforts. This included: a) lying to the Trustee and XY in various respects and, in particular, misleading XY and the Court about who was the true purchaser of the cytometers; b) making misrepresentations as to the Missing Parts and withholding the Missing Parts for their future (mis)use; c) using false names, in terms of sourcing materials and parts for the retrofitting process of the cytometers, all in aid of hiding the IND Group's efforts from XY; and d) attempting to remove the serial numbers from the SX parts and making counterfeit labels for the newly-copied parts and machines.

In addition to copying the SX cytometer parts, the defendants used the newly-retrofitted SX cytometers to make substantial quantities of sexed semen and sexed embryos, all in breach of confidence relating to XY's Confidential Information. All of the defendants received XY's Confidential Information knowing that it had been provided by XY to JingJing in confidence. Their surreptitious actions and misrepresentations taken in relation to the Court, the Trustee, and XY to avoid detection of their true activities were indicative of this knowledge. Equity will pursue the information into the hands of a third party who receives it knowing, or later learns, it was communicated in breach of confidence and impose its remedies. Zhu, both personally and through his various companies, being IND, IDI, IEI, FBI, CTS and Ai De, all participated in this breach of confidence.

Zhu, both personally and through his various companies by which he operated, received the Confidential Information and expressly and improperly misused it for his own purposes through the corporate actions of IND, IDI, IEI, FBI, CTS and Ai De. While the evidence was not sufficient to specify clearly the exact roles of some of the companies, Zhu was acting in his capacity as owner of these corporations in directing their improper activities through the means of the various IND Group employees. All of these corporations took some action in aid of Zhu's goals, and while in possession of knowledge that it was acting for the purpose of improperly using XY's Confidential Information. In addition, Zhu and Zhang were participating as “directors” or directing minds of various IND Group companies, and their actions amounted to a deliberate knowing pursuit or conduct to commit acts which could not be said to be in the best interests of the companies through whom they acted. As such, they were personally liable for those acts. FBI and CTS, were involved (and in CTS' case, created) for the express purpose of acting to improperly use and exploit XY's Confidential Information. There was no evidence that IND, IDI, IEI and Ai De were expressly created for the purpose of using XY's Confidential Information, but corporate actions taken by them were used to further the improper activities relating to XY's technology, as directed by their owner, Zhu. Accordingly, Zhu and the IND Group companies, being IND, IDI, IEI, FBI, CTS and Ai De, and Zhang, as a director of CTS, are all liable to XY for breach of confidence. The evidence, as to Tang's involvement in the plan to misuse XY's technology, was manifestly clear. Accordingly, Tang was liable to XY for breach of confidence. As with Tang, the involvement of Ai De and Zhang in the intentional misuse of XY's Confidential Information had been clearly proven. Zhang and Ai De both played a direct role in receiving and misusing XY's Confidential Information. Zhu, IND, IDI, IEI, FBI, CTS, Tang, Ai De and Zhang were all jointly liable for breach of confidence by reason of their conduct.

The trial judge in the current action agreed that the proper focus was not on the plaintiff's loss but on the defendants' misconduct. In general, the conduct justifying such an award must merit condemnation by the Court. The general objectives are punishment, deterrence and denunciation, and any award should be rationally related to these objectives. XY submitted that the focus should be on the steps undertaken by Zhu and his employees to achieve the conspiracy and breach of confidence, including being deceitful towards the Trustee, XY and the Court, the violation of bankruptcy laws and the abuse of the court process throughout this action. The trial judge concluded that the case invited an expression of condemnation by the Court. Unlike the facts before the trial judge in the original action, where the deceit was largely within the context of a contractual relationship between XY and JingJing, Zhu's scheme went far beyond that scenario. That scheme, in part, involved false representations and false evidence before the Court, consistent with the earlier deceit that was part of the Original Action. The scheme also involved a clear plan to avoid document disclosure of relevant documents in the present action to disguise the true nature and extent of Zhu's operations. Of course, the deceit also involved XY. Zhu's actions went beyond trying to “pull a fast one” on XY. XY describes this as a fraud of epic proportions, which cries out for punitive damages commensurate with the complexity, breadth, and long-standing efforts of Zhu to cheat XY and steal its Confidential Information. There was considerable merit in XY's characterization of the matter. Years before this action was even started, Zhu conceived of a strategy to steal XY's intellectual property for his own gain. The course of his deception in achieving this goal never wavered. Zhu's tactics were more than deserving of punishment and denunciation. In addition, an award would also serve the objective of deterrence. Zhu often employs various people, including his family, friends and employees to do his dirty work. An award will send a clear message to those who have helped Zhu in his improper actions and those who might do so in the future, that assisting Zhu poses severe risks to them. While the compensatory damages and special costs awarded were substantial, they did not adequately address the highly-reprehensible conduct of Zhu and the other defendants. In addition, it was more than apparent that XY had been severely hampered by the actions of Zhu in hiding his true activities. XY expended significant time, money, and effort in advancing the litigation that, to some extent, would not be recovered even by an award of special costs. The misconduct involved a high degree of blameworthiness. It was planned and deliberate. The defendants were driven by a profit motive and were keenly aware that their conduct was wrong. The misconduct took place over a long period of time, being from at least 2009 to the present. It was likely that the misconduct continued to this day. This was an “exceptionally rare commercial case” where punitive damages were appropriate. This was a very unique situation and the facts to be considered were extraordinary.

headtext.bold: TDC Broadband Inc. v. Nova Scotia (Attorney General)

head.headtext: TDC Broadband Inc. v. Nova Scotia (Attorney General), 2016 CarswellNS 669, 2016 NSSC 206, affirmed 2018 CarswellNS 145, 2018 NSCA 22 (N.S. C.A.)

para.paratext: No punitive damages awarded

The question posed was whether Flam's “Rural Broadband Project” received, in confidence, unique technical and/or business information of the plaintiff and used it for the purposes of that project without the plaintiff's permission.

During the campaign leading up to the election of June 13, 2006, the then Premier of Nova Scotia, promised Nova Scotians that all would have access to affordable high speed internet access by 2009. Following their election, the government tasked Flam with delivering on this promise. Flam had no technical background in the provision of broadband internet, no system to deliver the service, no specific geographical area in which to test a delivery system and a tight deadline to meet.

During the years 2004 to 2006 the persons who would become the principals of the plaintiff company invested significant time and capital into developing and deploying a successful internet delivery system that would apparently have satisfied all of the technical criteria of Flam's project.

To be eligible for government financial assistance for a project, the Cockerills needed to incorporate, and in March of 2005 they did so creating the plaintiff company. In the ensuing months TDC focused on using towers as part of its delivery system. As a result, it constructed two towers and by February 2006 began to service customers in the Caledonia community. The delivery system fulfilled the requirements for the provision of high speed wireless internet service in particularly difficult terrain, over a comparatively large geographic area and at a cost that was affordable and expected to be sufficient to sustain the company as it expanded its market. At the time, there were no other internet service providers offering the same combination of availability, speed and reliability in this type of topography.

Notwithstanding their technical success, TDC did not develop a sufficient income stream to support the operations and its own resources were being exhausted. Bills from suppliers were not being paid in a timely manner and the service was at risk of being suspended. Despite these problems, the Cockerills continued to seek out capital and to market the product around the province. They had considerable interest from Regional Development Agencies (RDAs) and believed that because of their work with local Nova Scotia government officials in Queens they were well placed to obtain significant support from the Province which, if it came, would provide the financial stability to support the wide spread distribution of the delivery service.
