However, when the Province decided in March 2006 to seek out proposals to provide broadband internet service to unserviced or underserviced areas of the province they did it in such a manner that it effectively ensured that TDC could not compete with the large service providers, even though TDC had a proven delivery model and their competition did not, or were unprepared to deploy one. The deck was stacked against TDC by the government's roll out plan and the financial requirements of the RFPs. It was a “Catch 22”: in effect, the government would not give TDC the money necessary for their progress because TDC did not have the ability to pay their existing bills and was not attracting new investor money. Having the only technology that was proven to work was not sufficient to overcome their lack of capital, or business acumen.

There were two significant aspects of the plaintiff's confidential information used by the defendant to construct the RFP. The first was the Business Proposal. The second was 5 different aspects of the TDC information in the pilot RFP. The defendant did not include TDC information in the pilot RFP that detailed the most valuable part of the delivery system, which was the overall assembly of the many off the shelf constituent hardware parts together with Dennis Cockerill's configurations that made them work together. Also, the evidence did not support a conclusion that Seaside had the ability to or did deploy the TDC delivery system in the Cumberland pilot. Nor did the evidence demonstrate that other bidders subsequently deployed a system based upon the pilot RFP information.

headtext.bold: Reasons Given by Court for Award:

headtext.ital: Reasons for Decision of the Trial judge

para.paratext: It was mystifying as to why Flam would not have made efforts to engage with TDC at the outset, even if it was only to determine whether they could be useful as consultants. Instead she and Mr. MacDonald went through the back door for this information. There were at least three reasons for their conduct: (i) their negative predisposition toward TDC; (ii) that when Flam's superiors asked for reports about TDC and the Caledonia project she saw it as questioning her decision not to engage with TDC. Flam sought out TDC's information to justify why she was not giving consideration to the Caledonia project; and (iii) realizing that she could obtain TDC's information by other means allowed her to benefit from their experiences without having to engage them. Notwithstanding these conclusions the trial judge concluded that the defendant's misconduct did not meet the very high threshold for the imposition of punitive damages. Flam and MacDonald did not appear to have acquired any personal benefit from their conduct, nor to have been motivated by a hope of personal benefit. The misuse of information was not the cause of TDC's bankruptcy. The company's dire financial problems, including the shutdown of its service in August 2006, pre-existed the publication of the pilot RFP. While TDC information was clearly confidential it was not patented or copyrighted so the misconduct did not offend these types of proprietary protections. The conduct while blameworthy did not reveal the most valuable aspects of the TDC delivery system. TDC lacked most of the requirements necessary to the bid. It suffered from the fact that its delivery system had been shut down in Caledonia and so its technology was scored as not being verifiable. The defendant had no responsibility for these liabilities of the defendant. Finally, there was no indication in the evidence of Flam or MacDonald of any malice toward the plaintiff. Rather, they made a decision that TDC was not a credible business entity capable of meeting the objectives of the Rural Broadband Project. This was a reasonable decision. Any ISP chosen had to have the capability of meeting the financial and technical challenges of the project. When challenged by TDC and by Flam's superiors over their lack of support for TDC they reacted defensively, but that did not undermine their intended good faith to fulfill the government's promise.

headtext.ital: Reasons for Decision of Court of Appeal

para.paratext: Justice Bourgeois dismissed the appellant's submission that the trial judge erred in not ordering punitive damages. The trial judge's findings leading to the conclusion that the respondent did breach its duty of confidence were not challenged on appeal.

The appellant submitted that the trial judge's failure to award punitive damages was anchored in two sources of error. First, the trial judge failed to rely upon the factors giving rise to an award for punitive damages as articulated by the Supreme Court of Canada in Whiten v. Pilot Insurance Co., 2002 SCC 18. Second, the trial judge weighed factors irrelevant to a proper consideration of punitive damages.

Justice Bourgeois found no fault in the trial judge's statement of legal principles. They mirrored closely those articulated in Whiten. In deciding whether to award punitive damages, there was no error in principle on the trial judge's part. The asserted “irrelevant” factors he considered all went to whether the conduct was “malicious”, “outrageous” and “egregious”. They were also directly in response to the appellant's post-trial submissions in which it argued the “high-handed, dishonest and deliberately harmful” conduct of Flam triggered the need for punitive damages. The trial judge could hardly be faulted for failing to consider factors for assessing the quantum of an award of punitive damages in circumstances where no such award was found to be warranted. Awards for punitive damages, or the failure to so award, attract a deferential standard of review.

head.headtext: Jane Doe 464533 v. D. (N.), 2016 CarswellOnt 911, 2016 ONSC 541

para.paratext: Punitive damages of $25,000

The plaintiff's ex-boyfriend posted an intimate video of her on a pornography website without her knowledge or consent. In early December 2011, the plaintiff learned that the defendant had posted the video she sent him on an Internet pornography website under the “user submissions” section of the website. As posted by the defendant, the video was titled “college girl pleasures herself for ex boyfriends (sic) delight.” She further learned that the defendant had been showing it to some of the young men with whom they had attended high school. She later learned that the video had been posted online on the same day she had sent it to him, and that its existence had become known among some of her friends. The video was available online for approximately 3 weeks, before it was “removed”. There was no way to know how many times it was viewed or downloaded or if and how many times it may have been copied onto other media storage devices or recirculated. The plaintiff's lawyer sent a demand letter to the defendant in February 2012. The defendant admitted having posted the video, but advised that it had been removed and that he did not consider that the plaintiff's claims for compensation had any merit. The defendant failed to serve a statement of defence and had been noted in default.

headtext.bold: Reasons Given by Court for Award:

para.paratext: The consequences for the plaintiff arising from the defendant's conduct had been significant and long-lasting. She saw a counsellor at her school for over a year and a half to deal with the emotional fallout from the posting of the video. She experienced serious depression and emotional upset. On the occasions since the incident when she had encountered the defendant she had become emotionally distraught and unable to cope, sometimes collapsing. The plaintiff remained conscious of the fact that the video was viewed by acquaintances of the defendant, that its existence was known to other members of her former social circle and had caused harm to her reputation. More than four years after the incident, she was emotionally fragile and worried about the possibility that the video might someday resurface and have an adverse impact on her employment, her career, or her future relationships. She continued to be distraught about the incident and afraid that those feelings would haunt her for a long time to come. Despite these challenges, she finished her undergraduate studies and was attending a graduate program that would enable her to become a health care professional when she graduated. She remained worried, however, that the defendant's actions had put her future career in jeopardy should news of these events surface again.

An award of punitive damages may be appropriate where the defendant has acted in a high-handed or arrogant fashion or has recklessly disregarded the plaintiff's rights or the potential impact of the defendant's intentional conduct. Those were apt descriptions of the defendant's conduct. He gave no consideration to the inevitable impact of his actions on the plaintiff. He had not apologized; indeed, according to the plaintiff, despite being aware of the harm he has caused, when they have encountered one another since the event, he has had an insolent look on his face, and had shown no remorse.

In relation to quantum, proportionality was an important consideration in making an award of punitive damages. Other factors include the blameworthiness of the defendant's conduct (high); the degree of vulnerability of the plaintiff (significant); the harm directed specifically at the plaintiff (again, significant). Importantly, the defendant acted with malice. Another consideration was the need for deterrence. While the case may be novel, it should serve as a precedent to dissuade others from engaging in similar harmful conduct. A final consideration was the other penalties imposed on the defendant for the same misconduct. Here, the defendant faced no criminal sanctions: his acts took place before Parliament criminalized such conduct. The absence of a specific criminal sanction was no bar to an award of punitive damages in a civil case.

headtext.bold: Service Corp. International (Canada) Ltd. v. Nunes-Pottinger Funeral Service & Crematorium Ltd.

head.headtext: Service Corp. International (Canada) Ltd. v. Nunes-Pottinger Funeral Service & Crematorium Ltd., 2012 CarswellBC 1100, 2012 BCSC 586, 215 A.C.W.S. (3d) 119, 2012 C.L.L.C. 210-062 (B.C.S.C.), additional reasons 2012 CarswellBC 3301, 2012 BCSC 1588

para.paratext: Damages as against the defendants Nunes, Pottinger and Nunes-Pottinger Funeral Service and Crematorium Ltd., jointly and severally, in the total amount of $280,285.00.
Punitive damages of $10,000 as against Nunes.

The Graham Funeral Home was the only funeral home in Oliver, B.C. until its long time manager Nunes resigned to open a competing business, taking the entire staff with him. As of September 2008, Graham had files containing approximately 300 pre-need contracts. The majority of pre-need contracts held by Graham had been made with one insurer—Assurant Life. Those contracts were also the most easily transferred to another funeral home.
Copies of more than 200 of those files were made and taken to NP. The files included information needed to contact the clients and persuade them to transfer their contracts.

In the seven months between the opening of NP and April 30, 2009, a total of 208 pre-need contracts were transferred from Graham to NP. The majority of those transfers in fact took place within the first three months. In March 2009, when the plaintiff demanded return of its files, Nunes denied that NP was in possession of any Graham documents. However, the defendants eventually consented to an order, under which they were to return all documents, including copies, along with other Graham property. Most of the copied files were returned but about 40 had by then been destroyed. The destroyed files were likely the ones for which no transfer had been obtained. Every file that was returned contained a transfer form in favour of NP.

headtext.bold: Reasons Given by Court for Award:

para.paratext: Punitive damages are available against employees who have wilfully and deliberately abused confidential information. Financial statements of NP were put into evidence and indicate that its net after tax profit in 2010 was $89,202, down from $132,817 in 2009. The compensatory damages awarded were therefore equivalent to roughly two years or more of NP's income. The likely impact of such an award on a small local business was sufficient to meet the objectives of retribution, deterrence and denunciation. An award of punitive damages of $10,000 against Nunes was appropriate.

head.headtext: Jones v. Klassen, 2006 CarswellAlta 31, 2006 ABQB 41, 14 B.L.R. (4th) 212, 55 Alta. L.R. (4th) 354, 2006 C.L.L.C. 210-021, 390 A.R. 66 (Alta. Q. B.)

para.paratext: Compensatory damages of $13,464.00
Punitive damages of $5,000.00

When the defendant made his decision to change firms he printed a copy of the client list, as well as thousands of pages of contact sheet information relating to those clients, from which he made handwritten notes on the client list of important details concerning each account. He took both the client list and the contact information with him when he left. In addition, he took a list of potential clients. During the six months following the defendant's departure and letter to his clients, a total of 98 Edward Jones client investment accounts, totalling $3,393,101.10 in assets, transferred out of Edward Jones to the defendant at his new firm of Cartier Partners.

headtext.bold: Reasons Given by Court for Award:

para.paratext: The defendant was not free to compete unfairly with his former employer, to use confidential information against his former employer. The defendant owed Edward Jones a duty at common law not to compete unfairly, and not to make use of confidential information against his former employer. By taking and using the information he did, the defendant breached those duties. He also breached his fiduciary duty to Edward Jones.

The compensatory damages of $13,464.00 to Edward Jones would be significant for the defendant to bear. However, by not merely taking the client documentation, but by photocopying and retaining it while purporting to return the documentation through counsel, was behaviour that must be condemned by this Court. Accordingly, $5,000.00 in punitive damages was awarded.

headtext.bold: Planon Systems Inc. v. Norman Wade Co.

head.headtext: Planon Systems Inc. v. Norman Wade Co., 1998 CarswellOnt 3437, [1998] O.J. No. 3547 (Ont. C.J. [General Division])

para.paratext: In view of the lack of information on Wade's actual sales prices, damages were determined in the total amount of $1,148,000 plus $172,800 in punitive damages, but this award was subject to any further submissions which the parties might make within 30 days as to whether, on the basis of the evidence received at trial and the relevant law, an assessment procedure should be ordered to determine the amount of the damages per se, including any formula or terms that are proposed.
This was a proceeding under the Companies' Creditors Arrangement Act to determine the validity and amount of the claims made by Planon against Wade in the reorganization of Wade under the CCAA.
Planon's claims against Wade related to their arrangements and dealings up to and during 1985 and early 1986 in respect of filing cabinets produced by Planon and purchased by Wade for resale.

In the early 1980's, Planon supplied filing cabinets to Wade for resale by it. In April 1985, Wade advised Planon that because of product deficiencies Wade would terminate their arrangement unless the deficiencies were overcome. Wade indicated to Planon it should retain a Montreal industrial designer, M to redesign the unit consisting of the filing mechanism and its cabinet. Planon did so and an M prototype was demonstrated to Wade's representatives in May 1985 and was approved by them. In early September, Planon delivered to Wade a preproduction model. On September 12, 1985, Wade advised that the product was not satisfactory and the agreement was cancelled as was an outstanding purchase order. During the fall of 1985 following the termination letter, Wade ordered product from Planon for resale. During the same period, Wade arranged with M to design a unit for it which was designed to be competitive with the Planon product. Subsequently, in January 1986, Wade cancelled orders it had placed with Planon and refused to pay for invoiced units on grounds of deficiencies. Later in 1986, Wade introduced into the market its own filing cabinet unit designed by M. Planon's business declined and a few years later Planon went out of business.

headtext.bold: Reasons Given by Court for Award:

para.paratext: It is desirable to deter breaches of confidence and to strengthen the social fabric underlying confidential business dealings and therefore, where there has been a deliberate breach of confidentiality; there should be an award of punitive damages.
The award should be material but related to the damages per se. An award of punitive damage equal to 15% of the damages per se would be satisfactory in principle.

headtext.bold: Sweet Factory Inc. v. Hudson's Bay Co.

head.headtext: Sweet Factory Inc. v. Hudson's Bay Co., 1998 CarswellOnt 5273, 85 C.P.R. (3d) 417 (Ont. C.J. [Gen. Div.]) [Reasons for decision on liability]; Sweet Factory Inc. v. Hudson's Bay Co., 1999 CarswellOnt 347, 86 C.P.R. (3d) 417 (Ont. C.J. [Gen. Div.]), supp. reasons 1999 CarswellOnt 2026 [Reasons for decision on damages]

para.paratext: Damages assessed at $511,783
Punitive damages in the sum of $200,000
The Sweet Factory concept involved candy displayed in modern design acrylic tubes, and the use of colour gradation, the candy being purchased by weight for a set price.
A confidentiality agreement was executed by both parties. Documentation or information was provided to the representatives of the Hudson's Bay.

The areas of information supplied to the Bay were, having regard to the terms of the confidentiality agreement, confidential or proprietary. Further, considering all the negotiations and discussions with Hudson's Bay, the uniqueness of the S.F. concept and the terms of the confidentiality agreement, the plaintiff demonstrated that the items of information were supplied to the Hudson's Bay in circumstances in which an obligation of confidence arose. The overall concept of the store, and the operation of merchandising bulk candy in the fashion in which it was done in both stores, the Candy Lab store was very similar to that of the Sweet Factory concept, and the total package was based on the use and misuse of confidential information supplied to Hudson's Bay, and its unauthorized use violated the confidential agreement and breached Ontario law. The main reason why HBC able to and in fact did put into operation the number of Candy Lab Stores in 1989 that it did was the available information it had from the plaintiff.

headtext.bold: Reasons Given by Court for Award:

para.paratext: Having found that the defendant has committed breaches of confidence and of good faith, coupled with the fact that the overall conduct of the defendant's agents or employees in all the circumstances was harsh, malicious and reprehensible (for example, in deliberately attempting to stall and mislead the plaintiff into supplying information when aware he was expecting an executed confidentiality agreement on basis someone unable to keep an appointment with the plaintiff, to demanding signature of English company to proposed business agreement, that plaintiff corporation post letters of credit, unilaterally putting an unfairly short time limit on plaintiff's executing contract that contradicted date. Solicitors for defendant had specified a few days previously, and then aborting the business dealings, and thereafter failed to return all the documents the plaintiff had supplied to the defendant) the court awarded the plaintiff corporation punitive damages in the sum of $200,000.

headtext.bold: I.C.L. Engineering Ltd. v. Associated Corrosion Contractors Inc.

head.headtext: I.C.L. Engineering Ltd. v. Associated Corrosion Contractors Inc., 1985 CarswellBC 810, 8 C.I.P.R. 217, 10 C.P.R. (3d) 313 (B.C.S.C.)

para.paratext: The court ordered and declared that the defendant company, Associated, and the defendant James Ruggles, hold the partially completed filament winding machine now in the actual possession of the plaintiff, in trust for the benefit of the plaintiff, and that they deliver up the machine to the plaintiff, subject to the rights of any other third party claims to be determined

The plaintiff designed and developed an original, unique fibreglass filament winding machine in the early 70s. The plaintiff used the machine in its business to manufacture fibreglass products and also made and sold the machine to non-competitors outside its market area. No patent or copyright had been taken out or registered on the design plans for the winding machine, but such plans were highly confidential and secret to the plaintiff, which had not authorized or consented to any party or parties either using its plans or copying any parts of its machine in order to produce like machines for use or sale.

The defendant Roberts, a former employee of the plaintiff, after leaving his employment with the plaintiff, obtained employment with the defendant company which was in the same line of business in the Vancouver area as that of the plaintiff, but was no longer active in business. The defendant company delivered numerous copies of the plaintiff's design plans for the winding machine to Arjay Industries Limited for the purpose of manufacturing components for the winding machine, which components were subsequently partially assembled to the extent that a filament winding machine was 90% complete in its construction. The machine was identical, or very similar in construction to those of the plaintiff, and neither the plans and manufacture of the machine components nor subsequent assembly of the winding machine were consented to or authorized by the plaintiff.

The plaintiff only claimed against the defendant company that the partially constructed winding machine be delivered up to the plaintiff on the basis that the use made by the defendants of such confidential and secret information constituted the same, that is, the copies of the plaintiff's design plans and filament winding machine produced therefrom, was trust property in the hands of the defendants, to which the plaintiff was beneficially entitled.

headtext.bold: Reasons Given by Court for Award:

para.paratext: The design plans and filament winding machine were unique, and that the design plans were not only confidential and secret, but also that no party was authorized to use the same to produce identical or very similar machines to that of the plaintiff, and specifically no such authority was given to the defendants or any of them. Whether or not the defendant company, Associated, or its officer, James Ruggles, deliberately or unknowingly used the design plans of the plaintiff, is irrelevant, and the only fact that need be determined is that they did so use the plaintiff's design plans without the consent or authorization of the plaintiff. The defendants did use the plaintiff's design plans in order to produce this partially completed filament winding machine, and did so without the consent or authorization of the plaintiff. There has accordingly been an infringement of the plaintiff's rights to its design plans. As the machine was never brought into production and used, the plaintiff now claims no damages or accounting for profits, but only that the machine be delivered up to it, in satisfaction of the infringement of its rights.
